cons: There is no access to a 401k for union hourly personnel.  The union (Service Trades Council Union and IATSE) is weak and allows the Company free reign to take advantage of the employees.  As an example, the union had its membership vote on a contract that had not even been written.  They offered a one-page summary of the changes in the new contract, yet failed to mention on that summary that the union agreed to terminate the access to a 401k retirement plan. The pension, while offered, is unsubstantial.

pros: Free park admission (when it isn't blocked out), decent health benefits, prestige that comes with working for "Disney"
cons: Constant cuts without regard for guest or Cast/employee experience, questionable leadership, frequent fear of layoffs

pros: Great corporate identity.  Great people.  Worldwide reputation.  Some of the smartest people in the world work for Disney.  People here are genuinely nice and kind.  This isn't an act: it is the people Disney hires.
cons: We don't move very quickly.  We react rather than act.  We have all the problems of giant organizations.  We have chosen to grow through acquisition rather than internal business building.  It is unfortunate that a company once known for innovation is following others so much.

review_title: Enjoy your time at Disney but jump ship at the first good opportunity that comes your way.
pros:
Get the Disney name on your resume.
Get to get into Disneyland or Walt Disney World for free, but note that they have black out days so you cannot always go the day you want.  Oh, and if you go too many times (or your family members do) then they will send you a warning that you are going too much.
Your peers will usually be fun to work with.
Most non-Disney employees will be impressed that you are or have been a Disney employee.
It's easy to be motivated to do a good job because you like what Walt stood for.
cons:
They expect you to be available 24/7.
Disney comes first - before family and friends.
If you stay too long then they will you lay you off.  
They do not like long term employees because they have to pay too many benefits.

review_title: Great people, fun place to work, hard to get promoted
pros: Super fun team of people, great atmosphere, and you can generally be proud of what you're working on. Beautiful Burbank campus, obviously the Silver pass which gives access to the theme parks is an amazing benefit and pretty decent health care benefits.
cons: Most studio home entertainment groups are struggling and this one is no different. Trying to remain relevant, not a strong enough focus on digital and a lot of upper management that's been around awhile and aren't innovative enough to remain relevant. In general the company doesn't do much to promote from within nor work hard to keep the super talented employees it has.

review_title: A bit corporate & antiseptic, but plenty of nice people
pros: Overall, this is a great company & great place to grow. Good benefits, with extra perks like the holiday party for employees at Disneyland. A large number of employees seem to be really loyal & enjoy their work.
cons: At the time, there was a lot of fear & uncertainty in the air amongst executives. This lead to uncertainty in decision-making and confusion over the goals that needed to be accomplished. It's also one of those places where many colleagues have worked together for a very long time, which leads to some hard-to-penetrate cliques as well as personal drama that doesn't need to be part of the workplace. For what it's worth, I don't get the sense that either the fear or the drama are still prevalent.

pros: The pay is a little less then other call centers, but the benefits are huge. They provide great trainers and honestly I've loved my leaders. They do great stuff in the call center to improve knowledge (businesses visit like restaurants and hotels) or moral boosters (themed days, free coffee or snacks, even a few character meet and greets!), if you're not a big Disney person this will not be a good fit, those are weeded out quickly, but if you are this is a good way for a lot of people to learn more and use their knowledge and experiences.
cons: Some phone sales departments are easier to stay in and receive commission easier than other departments. There are a lot of things your performance is graded on, many times it feels like the company does not care if you meet those goals as they did not fix problems an entire department wanted addressed or leave program issues because 'you found a way around it' even though it takes longer which hurts efficiency.

pros:
- appeal of the brand name on your resume
- great perks that you rarely ever get to use. ie free park tickets
cons:
I came in at the worst time possible during all the layoffs. Employee morale was low. During hard times, you would think upper management would be supportive and informed about the changes in the organization .. Instead, they continue to pile on more work load. There is a lack of culture.. It is not Magical nor Delightful. 

People were not the friendliest, especially if you are new. But again, that's probably because everyone is constantly stressed about losing the job and obligated to work overtime.

pros: ITS A JOB;                                                                                                           GET PAID ON TIME
cons: If they paid me a .25 per call I get I would get paid more money than the hourly wage Disney pays me. For every happy guest that comes to Disney there is at least 7 unhappy employees, that need their paycheck to more than what it is. It horrible that they are people that have been with this Company for almost 30YEARS and have NOT reached the 15.00 dollar an hour pay. HORRIBLE

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good discount, Disneyland pass and cast exclusives throughout the year.
cons: Lots of politics, you work hard but not treated equally and fairly in stores. If you speak up you are a target even though policy states you cannot be. As long as money is being made nothing else matters.

job_title: Hotel Food and Beverage in Anaheim, CA
pros: Benefits, when they aren't cut for not working enough hours.  Disney is notorious for promising you full time status, but as soon as peak season is over your hours get cut below the threshold of maintaining full time employment.  Many people collect unemployment because of this.
cons: Very condescending management, that is noticeable from day one.  If you don't join in on their little game you get outcasted.  Management, at all levels, are far away from the day to day operation to the point that they are very out of touch with the demands and needs employees have.  There are hidden cameras all over, INCLUDING back of the house, so CYA.  I am responsible enough to work autonomously, but the majority of other employees are not, so I can see why they have the cameras.  I just wished management had the strength and qualifications to cultivate a positive work environment, but they are very tactful at being condescending.  Biggest phonies and fakes I've ever met, and that is exactly the environment.  You can't call them out on it because they perceive that as misconduct.  Not today satan.  People, stay away from this darkness.  Walt is rolling.

review_title: Fun, yet sometimes political and unstable environment with questionable executive direction
pros:
Disney has it's share of Pixie Dust and the culture and pride in the brand is contagious. 
Upward mobility is possible at the lower levels. 
Can't beat a team outing at Disneyland.
Projects are interesting and a portion of the staff is highly talented.
Plenty of opportunity for classes and professional development.
cons:
Corporate environment with lots of politics and under-qualified managers.
Upward mobility is nearly impossible at the Sr. Manager level and above.
Hours can be long if you succumb to the pressure.
Projects are always late, executives spend too much time in the weeds and layoffs happen frequently.

review_title: I liked working for Disney, but professionally unsatisfying.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
* You get to work for a well respected brand name.  
* Free park tickets for you and your family, plus other Disney discounts. 
* Good day to day work life balance ( some teams the  dev's work < 40 hours a week)
* Friendly atmosphere.
cons:
* Low compensation.
* No bonuses, or stock awards.  You must be Manager or Staff level  to receive this - some rewards do exist but this is very hush-hush.
* No opportunity for advancement, or lateral movement.  Managers do string you along on this.  You do not see promotion from within.
* High turn over, people leave 2-3 years once they recognize nothing is happening to their careers.  
* Politics and Bureaucracy - Long time employees strive to keep the status quo.  Questionable hiring  practices when new positions do appear.

review_title: Disney is a great place to retire but not a great place to advance if you are a minority.
pros: health and retirement benefits are excellent.  work environment is clean and attention is paid to ergonomics.  family-related issues (bereavement, childbirth, etc.) are treated with respect and support.
cons: disney management in its information technology areas are reluctant to promote non-white individuals.  when asked for coaching on how to improve or gain promotion into upper management positions, promotion based on merit and skills takes a back-door to traditional good-ol-boy networks.  what are characterized as "fair and impartial" employment selection processes are in fact orchestrated to promote those who have gained favor with existing management.  management often is not willing to consider other candidates within the company who have equal pedigrees.  when faced with seemingly two qualified candidates, one white and one minority, inevitably the minority is not chosen.  sad.

review_title: Great if you fit in, but lots of people outgrow Disney
pros:
* a relatively less evil global corporation
* nice to work for the Disney brand
* huge customer base makes accomplishments really satisfying
* the park and resort passes are nice, if you're in a position to use them
* It's a largely cordial environment
* helpful co-workers, with some exceptions of course
* the background level of disorganization allows for lots of private exploration of new technologies and offline professional advancement
* great work-life balance
* as a company, Disney will be around forever
cons:
* going through a phase where management is trying to prove they're smarter than everyone else, and they just aren't
* going through a phase where bullying is being promoted as the core management style, with very poor success
* promotions are largely personality-based, rather than technical-based
* increasing amount of bureaucracy
* there's a real tendency for smart people and good managers to outgrow the environment and leave

pros: I have never worked with smarter, more committed people than I did at Disney. The benefits are quite good. The office atmosphere is casual, and corporate policies are somewhat progressive in terms of work/life balance and flexibility. I was genuinely proud of the products I supported and the work I did.
cons: The constant layoffs and reorgs are unbearably stressful, and result in great people being sacrificed on the altar of bad management, while those remaining see their workloads triple with no recognition. The recent shift to an 'open work environment' makes concentration and privacy impossible. Recently stopped offering pension to all new hires.

review_title: Politics get in the way of great products
pros:
- Being part of a well-known and respected brand
- Perks (Disneyland is free, discounts on all merchandise)
- Interesting projects
- Travel budget
- Friendly coworkers
cons:
- Management abandons projects and changes their "strategy" every 3 months
- Politics between studios, e.g. "the engineering team rejected another Disney studio's poor software solution, but if we use it anyway that other studio will like us better and we can then take over their projects! (Just like they took over our project last year..)"
- Design by committee - usually a committee that is not familiar with the project. Slows down development and leads to mediocre results.
- Project decisions are made behind closed doors, direct communication between studios is discouraged unless it goes through approved managers.
- Promotions appear to be completely random; sometimes rewarding talented individuals, other times promoting slackers.

review_title: Steeped in tradition, but steeped in tradition
pros: Working for Disney as a creative employee is really a once-in-a-lifetime experience. The more you get into it, the more you enjoy it. For the true believers, it can really be a great time. There is such a thing as drinking too much kool-aid, but you have to be honest with yourself, suspend the cynicism sometimes and just soak in how cool it can be at times.
cons: The structure of the company itself (at least where I was), is super inflexible. The old guard was relied on very heavily, and unoriginal ideas were the norm. Young, energetic talent was encouraged in word, but not by promotions or raises. Because, of course, it meant that you'd be promoting someone above someone who had 10 more years of experience (even if they were old and stale). This may be different in some areas.

pros:
A fixed contract can get you get away with lots of things, even forgetting to call in sick when you're sick. It just doesn't matter, seasonal contracts are there for volumes, not for quality service.
The French middle management is a constant source of amusement. Their delusional approach to the company, as if it were actually French-owned, really sounds like an involuntary inside joke at some point.
Full of people to meet and close to an awesome city, it makes for a great temporary work experience. Compensation is okay but learn how to save. And just don't plan to stay.
cons:
Workload can range from inhuman to almost non-existent. It all depends on the people visiting each day, and I remember the company forecast to be often inconclusive. And the weather will always make or break the day.
Kids can be so mean.

review_title: Not always the happiest place on earth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Getting to see the behind the scenes creation of costumes. Also, working for Disneyland, you're able to get into the park for free, any day that isn't blocked out, so if you're a Disney fan it's great. If you happen to be a full-time employee, you get to walk in 3 friends or family members for free as well, for a certain number of times per year.
cons: 1. Other than working in a store or restaurant, the pay is much lower at Disneyland for the same type of job outside the park, especially in the creative departments. A lot of employees here have 2 & 3 jobs just to make ends meet. 2. Parking is horrible. Employees must park at their off-site parking lots and shuttle in, yet the shuttle system is slow so you need to be parked and waiting in line at least 30 mins ahead of your shift to make sure you are not late. 3. It's not easy to move up and get ahead in this company.

review_title: DTCI (formerly Disney ABC Television Group Digital Media)
pros:
- Great company benefits 
- Beautiful campus
- Commissary and Starbucks on-site
- Great holiday perks 
- Decent worklife balance 
- Great mentors, highly skilled 
- Ergonomic desks / sit/stand desks
- Great internship program
cons:
- Deadlines always missed, makes bad culture 
- People are a hit or miss so it’s hard to make true and transparent friendships - the people there really come in a full range from bitter and rude to the kindest and sweetest but that may be the case with other companies as well
- Competitive culture but non-competitive pay
- Growth within the company is slow or doesn’t happen at all 
- Very traditional and corporate still

review_title: Java software engineer experienced with mobile and online games.
pros: They use the newest and latest technology.  There are so many groups in Disney that you can explore.  They give you a lot of perks, such as Disneyland passes, good health coverage, education reimbursements, pretax child care and health care expenses deducted from your salary.
cons: It is difficult to get a promotion.  A lot of lay offs.  A lot of groups within the company don't have managers, or they use people who aren't qualify to be managers, because they don't think it's worth the money to hire real managers.  Review process is daunting and sometimes employees are not reviewed fairly.  Human resource is useless if you want to fight your case.

job_title: Sales Guide in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Wonderful co-workers, great brand, get to meet (mostly) nice families. Some good perks.
cons: Has turned our no pressure presentation into a "boiler room" experience. So disappointed that DVC has become a regular old timeshare. They only care about numbers, do not care about true, long time Disney cast members who believe in doing things the "Disney way".  Management will never it admit it, but  they do not care about the cast or the members, just their own job.  The pay for what we do and the stress we are under is WAY below industry standard- very low commission (that keeps getting cut).

review_title: A company that values their talent
job_title: Technical Support Engineer (TSE) in Burbank, CA
pros: Disney does a great job with keeping their employees engaged and happy. Overall, the workplace moral is average to high. There are always opportunities to move up in the company, but the ladder isn't easy. You have to really establish the relationships with people in addition to getting recognition. A salaried employee gets a Main entrance pass to enter disney parks for free, minus any blackout dates. 35% off Disney merchandise. Discounts on Disney vacation experiences and hotels. Employee movie screenings. Clubs and team sports. Community Outreach. Company paid training opportunities. Disney has their own pre-schools for employee children (Long waiting list though). Employee gym at the Burbank location. Good health benefits and 401k matching. Maternity/Paternity/Military leave.
cons: The company is extremely large and covers many lines of business world-wide. So you may have to take calls and meetings add odd hours. Many IT analysts are always on-call.

review_title: Many great workers, useless upper management team reporting to CTO
pros: I met many good friends, my direct manager was awesome; they inspired and enabled our team to work hard and still enjoy doing it. I learned much from them both personally and professionally. Pay was a bit below average for digital media industry however the benefits helped make up the difference.
cons:
Upper management reporting to the CTO believes they can build a world-wide empire of technology with absolutely no experience or understanding of the real world challenges involved; and yet the will not listen to anyone unless they clearly know less than they do, and are willing to grovel / stroke ego (catch-22 resulting in zero productivity and poor decisions). 

While DATG is portrayed as an innovative company from within, any other large media company in LA accomplishes more with less people, less middle managers, and less wasted expense. Don't waste your time. This cruise ship isn't going to actually sail anywhere.

review_title: Here's a New Hit for ABC, The Sinking Ship!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Burbank, CA
pros: Paycheck.  Does that count?  Well, not really, the pay is on the low end of the scale.
cons:
Can you guess I loathe this company?  Once I was the biggest Disney cheerleader in the land.  Now, they've outsourced to India, completely turned Walt's dream into a NIGHTMARE Fantastic!  Upper management is only concerned about making their name appear on a PowerPoint slide to Senior Executives.  The level of training is abysmal (which matches the morale).  HR couldn't give a hoot about the trench workers.  Their job is to protect the Corporate image.  Worst company I've ever worked for!  No one has the fortitude to stand up and say ,'Enough!  Let's regroup and figure out why it's broken' instead their response is 'That doesn't work, let's try this...'  
There's a reason Disney is being called Mouschwitz and Ducchow.  They burn you out, or try to kill you with undue stress.  Who gets the rewards?  Let's just say Bob Iger couldn't spend all the money he gets each year.

job_title: Disney College Program Intern in Orlando, FL
pros: Free entry to the parks for you and your family for both FL and CA.  Accumulated paid sick leave and more free passes in CA. Two-year seniority for CA interns, also help with networking. CA leaders gave me recommendations to email and set up networking meetings for those in my degree field, using them as a referral. No one has done that for me here in FL even though I have asked.
cons: No sick leave in FL. No main gate passes in FL, which means less park entries for your family members. No seniority in FL, meaning you will get the shifts no one wants. No health insurance on the College Program in either CA or FL.

pros:
Movie screenings, the occasional DVD, discount on products and free park entry. 
Large company with so many different business areas and functions.
Opportunity to work with various countries and cultures
Summer hours, when available.
cons:
Extremely top heavy - there are as many Managers as there are non-managers.
Very hierarchical with little autonomy, trust or transparency
Generous pay and bonuses for the executives, with lower levels underpaid
Rely a lot on Disney brand to attract and retain people
Little flexibility, a lot of red tape and the policies (HR & business) are very old-school
Teams are managed very differently depending on a manager lottery, there is no consistency on how policies are applied and employees are treated with regards to training, expenditure and flexibility
Working late is normal for a lot of teams, with not a lot of recognition or reward. It's expected.

review_title: Proud to be a part of it but broke my spirit
pros: The brand is by far the best reason to work here. It's also nice to work on known properties - many are good, some not so good. The park trips are a great perk especially when you realize that people save their whole lives to go on trips to disneyland or disney world.
cons: Leadership leadership leadership. There is no value on making people in leadership roles be good leaders. This is so common in companies though, someone is good at their work or in their field and they are promoted to a management role and are not prepared, do not care, are not held accountable. So good talent leaves and the bad leader stays.

pros: You get to go to the parks on your day off, make amazing friends, and have life-changing experiences.
cons: You have to work a LOT. I was scheduled to work 11 days in a row and almost 12 hours each day once. It's not always that crazy, but sometimes it is. It's not all magic and rainbows, so just know that before you go.

review_title: Don't expect any investment in your skills - You are just a resource
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Glendale, CA
pros:
Generally flexible works hours.
Perks, such as park tickets and discounts.
Great teamwork at the coal-face. Smart people.
The opportunity to work on high-profile web-sites.
cons:
Management is generally poor and, although they will treat you with respect, they ultimately will only see you as a resource.
Politics.
Proprietary technology stacks that make developing and maintaining a robust web-site the most painful and inefficient experience. Any marketable skills you had before you joined Disney will wither.
Politics.
Bad case of NIH (not-invented-here) and a Legal department that will prevent you from even thinking about suggesting using any open-source tools.
Politics. There are politics everywhere - but politics here are as bad as it gets.
Zero investment in your skillset. No technology training (except in proprietary tools) and no external course or conferences. If you're not on the management track then they have no interest in growing you.

review_title: So tight with a dollar that they push their personnel to the brink of quitting/burnout
job_title: Property Master in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They promote young workers from within if you are smart, helpful, and don't rock the boat, but advancing beyond a certain level may require waiting many years....and the advancement progression is not a clear path for any of their employees. It's somewhat sporadic and spontaneous. It still seems to be a growing company within the entertainment industry.
cons: They will give you several levels of new job titles/advancement before they actually will increase your wages. The layers of corporate middle-management are getting pretty thick and everything is dictated by whether it increases/decreases their exposure to liability. Not a company to take risks of any sort.

review_title: The best global media company by a mile
job_title: Vice President Business Affairs and Legal in Burbank, CA
pros: Disney is the best at what it does in almost every business vertical.  A great low ego respectful management culture  and a real focus on the meaning of its brands.  A strong recommend if you can get in.  Many people are truly experts in what they do.
cons: Disney is as effective at managing compensation as it is excellent at everything else.  Employment here is a long term game where you can do nicely if you stick it out.  Mobility into other jobs internally is often tough.  There are some passengers (cushy job with good enough package means people don't leave )  and a machine this large where success is measured the billions means start up/entrepreneurial attitude and energy can be in very short supply sometimes,

pros: I work in a satellite office in Europe. The pros with working at Disney are many: It's a wonderful brand (great conversation opener), the work-life culture is good (that's pretty standard in my country though) and you're never given too much to do. Sports contribution is OK and there is a mental health hotline which is very good.
cons: You have very little to do and to say in satellite offices - that goes for both you and your manager. Everybody is micro managed. You need approval from 5+ people for each step in a project. There is no room for making personal impact and if you don't have anything to do, management does not seem to care. I know several employees that have left because they were understimulated. It's not a creative environment and people who stay, get stuck in the same positions for 10+ years. I love the brand but not the office.

review_title: I love working for this company, however, some things need to be changed.
pros: I get to meet new people all the time, close knit family of co workers.  Always moving.  Things are always changing and always different so it keeps you on your toes!!  Fast paced environment!
cons: Over the years the appreciation for cast members have gone out the window.  Less and less days to use our guest passes that are part of our pay.  Non livable wages for cast. Supervisors are paid less than anywhere else for the amount of work they do.  Management looks out for themselves.  They always say they are there to help and just to call but when you do they are nowhere to be found and you’re told to “make it work”.

review_title: Great content, but poor quality senior management in EMEA rudderless leadership
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in London, England
pros:
Great movies - amazing to be working on such great content with talented people in the US.
The money is good at senior manager level and above - but that is probably why people don't leave
cons:
Some people have never had other jobs outside the mouse house which creates stale, ineffective and often lazy people in senior jobs. The EMEA HQ in th UK feels like a regional branch to the US - who make all the real decisions. You can't have any meaningful power to make decisions in your own market/region. 
The culture at a senior level can be described as toxic - but local teams tend to be lovely and supportive.

pros:
An amazing place to work at, is fun, full of adventure and magic.
The way you can do those little actions to create Magical Moments and the way the same Guests thank you in very creative ways is amazing.
Managers understand (most of the time) and worry about you, your wellbeing and not just about you doing what you supposed to do.
cons: If you participate in any of the Collage or International programs like I did, you'll be living in the complexes they have for that. Transportation there is awful and the price (of the apartment, utilities, transportation) isn't cheap at all, plus it isn't optional.

review_title: More benefits and perks, but lower pay. Wonderful as long as the magic doesn't wear off.
pros: Great benefits, friendly atmosphere. Casual, first-name basis culture. Regular employees get free admission to the parks, and a limited amount of free admissions for friends and family. Great discounts at Disney stores, and many other companies that partner with Disney for discounts. Great 401k with company match (Disney stock, which has been quite profitable).
cons: "We work while others play" is a corporate motto. Unfortunately, we also work while others work. Full-time operations cast members are expected to have 24/7 availability, especially holidays and weekends. Company policies for hourly employees are geared mostly toward the college students and interns that may be restrictive for more mature or skilled workers. Pay is generally lower than competing companies.

pros: Multiple ways of advancing career.  Even our resort president was previously a janitor first.  Some departments promote faster than others.  Free entry into the parks plus discounts.  Lots of fun events and programs.  Benefits are reasonable and company acts like it cares.  Plus you're working for one of the most respected companies in the world with a focus on family entertainment.
cons: Sometimes it depends where you go.  When you start at the bottom, your pay is not great.  Once you move up your hours hardly ever get better if you're working in the theme parks.  Outside the theme parks you can get into normal schedule otherwise enjoy a random schedule.  You can sometimes be at the whim of whatever area you end up in management wise.  You may be on a great team or a not so great team.

review_title: Good Company To Work For That Could Be Great
pros: The corporate office is a beautiful environment that has several amenities for employees.  I found that I was able to take on several projects that challenged me.  Leaders on my team were collaborative, but allowed me to work autonomously with little supervision.  I found that my insights and recommendations were well received by the managers that I worked with.  Part of my role included working with operators in the field and assisting them with questions and concerns provided a lot of fulfillment.
cons:
What would take Darden from good to great would be more progressive people management strategies.  Two things that I would have liked to have seen is a formal career development plan for employees at the home office and the opportunity for more remote work solutions. 

Cutting edge technology is another area of opportunity.

job_title: Attractions Cast Member in Anaheim, CA
pros:
Management.
Leadership Team.
Fellow Co-workers.
Networking. 
Professionalism. 
Integrity.
Development of Character.
Mickey Mouse is Your Boss.
Making Magic.
Goal is to Create Happiness. 
Teamwork. 
Knowing Someone Will Have Your Back. 
Ability to Strive For Higher Roles Within the Company.
cons:
Guests Can Be Disrespectful. 
Pay Could Be Better. 
Perks Seem To Decrease Every Year. 
Nothing to Be Gained From  Years of Commitment.
Raises Are Very Minimal. 
Establishing Full-time Takes A Year or More. 
Scheduling Won't Work With You.  
Difficult to Get Hours in the Beginning and Scheduling Will Make it Tough to Keep a Second Job. 
Company Doesn't Seem to Care if Their Workers Can Make Ends Meet. 
Hours are Random and Often Inconvenient. 
Nine Hour Turn Arounds. 
Negativity From Co-Workers is a Constant.

pros:
- Some of the most enjoyable people you can meet in a workplace 
- Fun volunteer activities 
- Free employee movie screenings 
- Complimentary park admission 
- Opportunity to see your work go out into the world and make a difference
cons:
- Some of the most ego-driven and corrupt leadership practices I've seen in my career
- Highly discriminatory talent management practices 
- Not a merit-based/ performance-based culture; very relationship-driven
- Great amount of population has been there for 20-30+ years. (I'll let you draw your own conclusions from that.)
- No real commitment to diversity and inclusion
- Not interested in providing employees with competitive salaries

review_title: A soul-sucking experience, which helped me value the important of company culture. Peppered with underappreciate talent.
job_title: Director of Technology in Redmond, WA
pros:
Meeting incredibly talented, ambitious, and generous people.

Feeling magical during your orientation.
cons:
Waving goodbye to incredibly talented, ambitious, and generous human beings that have been abused, manipulated, and shattered by a broken, dysopic, and mysogestic culture.

Watching a 50-yearl programmer coming to the heart-brekaing revelation that Disney is not all about caring, friendship, happy endings, and colorful characters with strong morals. 

Disney will never again by synonymous with all things magical.

pros: Disney is one of the most inspiring places to work at. It has the strongest brands in entertainment and some of the best businesses: Disney, Marvel, Pixar, LucasFilm. The Company offers a very diversified range of positions in many different activities as well as great career paths. It provides strong benefits to employees and is overall very respectful of its workforce. The benefits are arranged around flexible time, career development, health benefits and some unique perks such as free access to Disney parks and discounts on merchandise.
cons: Disney's TV businesses are facing headwinds from competition, especially ESPN and ABC. Disney Interactive has proven to be a challenging environment as it went through several restructures. Parks occasionally go through changes and lay offs despite strong business performance.

job_title: Game Developer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
World-class developers and artists.
Artists are so fun to work with.
We made amazing games every year.
Good pay, benefits, vacation, and sick leave.
Intense collaboration and ownership.
Getting to work on amazing stories and IP.
Bringing your kids to work and letting them try to break your game.
cons:
The entire studio always in survival mode; if one game flopped for any reason we'd be forced to find new jobs. Such is the nature of game development studios, generally.
Breakneck schedule, year after year; difficult to take time off.
Yearly 3-4 months non-stop crunch; dinner in the office then back to work; Saturdays too.
Always the promise that next year will be better, but it isn't.

pros: There are many perks working at The Walt Disney Company, including (at the time) pension, Disneyland passes, and there truly is something special about the origins of the company. There is plenty of training and learning opportunity, if you make the time to take it. I made many great, long-lasting friendships at this job. Pay was decent and I cannot complain.
cons:
Opportunity at Disney ABC felt arbitrary - some folks were promoted rapidly, while others were passed over
Siege mentality - up and comers worked and fought their way to a VP title; once there, they spent their time protecting their turf, or taking turf from others. This is especially toxic when "operational efficiency" is the ruling paradigm

pros:
-Once in a lifetime experiences
-Fun and creative work environment 
-Discount and free park tickets (3 per employee) 
-Opportunity for growth over time
cons:
-They will schedule you horrible hours for first 6 months or so (example: work 3pm-1am, then back in at 5 am because they only need to give 3 hours break in between shifts)
-Issued points for calling out, allowed 3 points before issued a reprimand with repercussions, being ill is not an excused absence 
-Not the friendliest people to work with, lots of character performers are "tired of smiling" all day and don't want to make time for small talk on breaks 
-You will do fur characters, amount of time varies per person (I did fur for 1.5 months, a friend of mine did 3 months, depends on need for face character you were hired for)

review_title: Great place to work but no progression
pros: Good benefits - free Disney park tickets, decent pay and holiday, Disney sample sales, movie screenings, additional day off at Christmas, 35% Disney store discount
cons:
Most people love working here so they never leave, this results in no opportunities for progression and some stale and lazy employees who don't do a lot but know they have it good!

Favouritism amongst management - different rules for different employees.

If you're executive level don't expect to progress to manager, it's very rare as no promotions available

review_title: How may I be of service?
job_title: Senior Club Level Concierge, Disney's Grand Floridian Resort & SPA in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Park Benefits, Career Opportunities to Transfer.  The perks of being able to join in and see many of the great opportunities Disney has is very amazing.  Getting to be apart of the magic and creating a magical experience for your guests is truly rewarding.  Being able to move around to different departments and work with many people of diverse backgrounds is fantasmic!
cons: Poor Developed Management, Status, Unions that control and save way too many lazy employees.  The way that management talks down to you and how in-experienced they are.  You could literally have a college degree or a Ph.D. and be competing for the same jobs as a girl that has worked there for two months and does not understand life yet.  The Leadership Casting Call is a waste of time and politics!

job_title: Film and Television Development Associate in Burbank, CA
pros: Fun people to work with. Working on the lot is a good way to make connections. Disney brand helps in some quarters. More than any other lot I've worked on Disney had more events (many family friendly/focused for obvious reasons) for their workers.
cons: Disney has a long standing rep of paying its below the line people poorly. I've found this rep to be true. For the hard core Disney fan they may find the tradeoff worth while but, like a Star Wars geek working at Skywalker Ranch, they know they can get talent based on the Disney name. Simple supply/demand causes them to not have to pay well. Keep it in mind when applying.

review_title: Great Place To Work, but Not A Career Unless You Get a Desk Job
pros: The community is great, all the co-workers on your level are amazing.  There are free passes for the park and discounts on merchandise. A discount is provided for the MTR fare and an optional discount monthly pass.
cons:
There are no raises for park performers, not even to account for inflation. Unless park performers move into management, there will be no raises or advancement.
They ask for feedback once every two years in a closed off manner, via multiple choice questions on a computer, without a way to leave open ended suggestions.

There was no staff development while i was there, but that may be changing. Many of the managers have never been in a park performance position so it's hard for them to empathize with concerns.

job_title: Director, Quality Assurance in Glendale, CA
pros: There are hard working people who put their best every day. Great IP and excellent campus
cons: Leadership cares about themselves only. Saving money means cutting some good people so executive leaders can have extravagant trips / travels. Creativeness is dead in DI, no one makes a good use of the extraordinary IP that Disney-LA-Marvel has. Politics is the key to survive and learning the system to be 5+ years is what important to most of the employees who's been around too long and can't stand to change the technology they are using or the processes being used. Change isn't good thing, don't try it if you are new comer, you will be part of the mid-year layoff.

job_title: Advance Sales Associate in Kissimmee, FL
pros:
You are able to bring joy to people every day. 
Most of your coworkers are amazing people who will support you, challenge you and help you get to places you will never dream you could have gone.
Travis Carey, amazing guy if you get to work for the vacation club you will get to meet him. He is one of the most amazing people I have ever had the pleasure of meeting. 
The job is simple, but not easy, you get to have fun with it.
cons:
Some of the changes they implemented over the past few years. While still a dream job, it has lost a little of the pixie dust. 
Some of the management, but changes have been made I understand hopefully for the better.

pros:
Fun and fast paced place to work.
Outstanding, inspirational  properties to work on
Lots of challenges and variety as Disney is constantly acquiring new properties.
Good benefits - bonus, healthcare
All of the people are of high quality with great work ethics and can-do attitudes.
cons:
Can be pretty slow moving with complex sign off procedures for everything from travel to workflow.
Strategies are not communicated as well as they used to be, this leads to a lack of focus on what is really important.
Increasingly difficult to grow your personal career within the organisation.
Team headcount is very tightly controlled or even static/reducing meaning that when workloads rapidly increase resource does not keep pace.

pros:
-On the whole good people trying their best
-Good work life balance for some, though others might disagree.
cons:
-Meetings led culture, action is slow to happen
-Management get rewarded for their bad decisions. Some consistently make the wrong call, but instead of being moved on will be incentivised (with bonuses) to save money (i.e. make people redundant). This happens a lot but is scapegoated as 'industry-wide challenges'. 
-Management are deaf to what their employees know about the business. Information is always filtered in a favourable way before it makes it to decision makers. 
-Lack of career progression, and when it does occur HR have a cap on salary increases for internal promotions. This means you will quickly be hugely underpaid for your level of responsibility and compared to the wider market.

job_title: Member Services Advisor in Celebration, FL
pros: Health benefits are good, free Disney park admission (unlimited for self, limited for friends/family). Air conditioning and a chair, something that most Disney cast (parks) don't get.
cons: Extreme micromanagement.  Feeling like a robot rather than a person. Mandatory overtime, all the time.  Being evaluated based on numerical data alone, rather than by how friendly/helpful you are to the members.  High stress environment. Always being watched/monitored. Low pay.

pros: a lot mentioned benefits a available only for permanent employees. free pass to resorts & parks as a cast member, content screenings for staff,  cafe vaucher to have a christmas dinner (once a year), free coffee machines + fresh milk, canteen, kitchen facilities (fridge, microwave & kettle); discounts at disney store + christmas discounts; indoor reatil sales; opportunies to volunteer for charities; bring your kids to work day; work and travel programms available like for example an opportunity to apply for work at US disney park and resorts over summer;  1 year of sabbatical throughout your entire career at disney; life insurance while in service; possibility to work from home if needed;  benefits such as pension, holidays, compationate leave, sick leave and other alike benefits.
cons: a lot of staff retention strategies with no real career plan in place which leads to minimal opportunities for carreer progression and mobility  or financial motivation.

job_title: UI/User Experience Designer in Kelowna, BC
pros: I loved the people I was directly working with—such a collaborative and hard-working bunch. We really made great things together and it was awesome to come into work everyday to build things for our audience that was so passionate for our product. I love that there was an annual UX summit internally which helped to bring together so many people doing the same stuff. It was inspiring. I also appreciated much of the leadership I interacted with that understood game development and caring about people.
cons: Unfortunately higher management went through so much turnover constantly, it was really hard to gain momentum in one single direction. The strategy in the interactive games department fluctuated so often that it was difficult to see the outcome of any given strategy.

pros: A creatively driven company at its core; one that inspires and impresses with its ownership/dominance of the market.  Highly driven, competitive, and economically sound.  A place where you will find great talent.
cons: Sheer size of the organization results in high degree of bureaucracy.  A lot of cooks in the kitchen for every discipline.  Decision paralysis resulting from too much time taken on consensus building.  Resistance to change in many respects, traditions that hold back new ideas.  Changing career paths or crossing over into another area of the company is difficult.

review_title: Probably one of the best companies to work at. If you work in US office.
pros: Very stable from my point of view. If you work hard, it will pay off. Good salary and benefits. Great atmosphere.
cons: This is a big company so bureaucracy in many areas. Very difficult career progression. They tend to hire external management rather then grow their own. If you work outside of US in regional offices like I did - there is zero support to continue career in US. It feels like you're not part of the great international company how they like to call it. In fact it is a myth. No matter your experience and what you did for the company. They just don't keep up with what Walt Disney used to believe in - hire best talents out there.

review_title: Bullying culture at all management levels
pros: The Disney 'brand'. The fun perks such as screenings, merchandise sales and park passes.
cons: Privvy to much and experienced some bullying from many levels of management. Certain staff 'went through' assistants like pairs of socks and treated junior staff appallingly. Rather than act upon such treatment HR were keen to let those same people behave in that same way thereby costing the company in new recruitment costs, payoffs and alike. Disney is a big company and there are some very good people. However knowing that even at the executive level this type of treatment of staff is allowed means my time there left a bad taste in my mouth. Hopefully the new UK head will shake things up a little.

job_title: Marketing Specialist in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Perks include discounted cruises, free guest passes, merch discounts. HR does a great job offering benefits (such as heavily discounted backup care for children) that other companies don't---it was hard to leave for that reason!
cons:
I worked in corporate, and had no work/life balance at all. I easily worked 60+ hours per week, and there was never any end to demands for more. It was very difficult to balance being a parent with working, which is ironic for a company with family values. 

Also, almost everyone I interacted with had only known Disney as an employer--their entire career was with the company and often with one team. This meant that they weren't open to change and had very narrow thinking. Disney is proud of their culture, but sometimes the insularity can be a drawback.

review_title: The best employer I've had in the US so far!!!
job_title: Food and Beverage Hostess in Orlando, FL
pros:
-unlimited access to all parks and attractions for free AND you can invite a guest to go for free too
-the best, the most understanding, polite, considerate, reasonable managers that I've met
-excellent work ethic and corporate culture
-superb facilities, clean, safe, impeccable
-the best training in customer service you can get in the whole wide world
-the happiest place to work at
-tons of other perks!!!
cons:
-my job was paid very very low, but I don't know about the senior positions salary
-not for people, who just want "a job to pay bills", you really have to give your all and best to this company, but it feels good!!!

review_title: Uneven management, shallow promises, and repetitive projects mar and otherwise enjoyable work experience.
pros: WDIG had an intelligent and laid back workforce.  It was easy to find peers that knew more than you but did not compete  for accolades and attention.  Very few managers were clock-watchers and allowed flexible work schedules.  Given the above, one must take special care of one's career else it may remain sedentary, sitting on the shelf, gathering dust.
cons: When compared to one another, supervisors were uneven -- for example, annual reviews from one may be intense while another may skip the process entirely.  Perhaps related: there seemed to be a revolving door for managers.  During my tenure, I had three managers within 9 months.  Salaries were not normalized, making for some unusual gaps and questionable promotions.

review_title: A great place if you're self motivated and love new problems to solve.
job_title: Game Designer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Avalanche hangs onto its Indie roots in terms of day-to-day structure. This can be a great environment for people who are driven or who really care about shaping the game. The studio is also run by people who care about and love games. The directors are approachable and honestly great people to work with.
cons: This tie to its past can also be a con due to lack of efficiency and clear communication between departments. How things are structured and work here don't necessarily translate to the greater industry. Additionally, conflicts of interest arise where producers are also tasked with owning the vision of a project.

review_title: Word on the street was that DIG made a change...don't buy it...it's still a huge bureacratic mess
job_title: Data Center Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: The only reason I worked for DIG was for an opportunity to learn more about the Disney company and what may be available...since a lot of what goes on in Disney is behind closed doors, being a bit closer helped in some ways.
cons: The director I worked for during the 2006 year was purely incompetent.  The fact that they allowed him to rule as he did is beyond me.  They lost a lot of great folks including myself.  I have over a dozen years with MS and other free thinking groups, the fact that the person I reported to was an ex-govt sector employee with little imagination (i.e. you take your orders from me and that's it) was purely a match made in hell.

review_title: The Ups & Downs of Disney Store Magic
pros:
1. The discounts
2. Strictly for Disney geeks
3. The best co-workers anywhere.
4. The legacy, the dream, Walt Disney's vision.
cons:
1. Inconsistent management
2. Lack of competent managers
3. Parent company disregard for The Disney Store contributions to the company
4. Consistently have to try to accomplish tasks given to us without the proper equipment or materials to get the job done.

job_title: Guest Service Manager in Orlando, FL
pros: Disney promotes to create and foster a truly inclusive environment for all Cast Members. I joined the Walt Disney Company as part of an international program, after completing my secondary education in Germany. My leaders treated me as an individual, developed me and where knowledgeable about my job. Personal and Professional Development was important to me and The Walt Disney Company offeres classes at Disney University, Web Based Training as well offering education al reimbursement.
cons: In the parks and resorts, workloads are dependent on season. In my former line of business this sometimes lead to opportunities with work and life balance. This is an industry wide challenge and I do not have any suggestions resolve this.

review_title: Hired to be agent of change, stymied immediately (by those who hired me)
job_title: Senior Forecasting Analyst in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Work load is manageable and the workplace is generally stress-free.  The culture encourages co-workers to be friendly and personable.  If you enjoy the parks, then the unlimited pass is a very nice benefit.
cons: Coworkers seemed to fall into two groups of Disney experience: 3 years or less with the company or 10+ years.  My interpretation of this dichotomy is that (1) young professionals become frustrated with the corporate bureaucracy and many antiquated business practices (and leave) and (2) since Disney is one of the few private companies that still offers a pension, the "lifers" cling to their position (and protect it)  until retirement.  De facto, it appears that Disney prefers very loyal employees over very apt employees.

pros: Great stable company, good people, decent medical benefits, great work life balance, family friendly company, very nice office
cons:
Some of the perks are not readily available if you don't work in SoCal or Florida. 
Politics can be tricky 
Reorganization has led to a lot of the best people leaving due to the chaos and culture clashes.

review_title: Don't work here unless you want to work lots of hours for little pay
job_title: Entertainment Technician in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: It can be a fun place to work and outsiders think you're cool because you work there.
cons: The organization is sclerotic to the point of not being able to correct procedural problems that have existed for decades.  They tout the fact that they promote from within but they promote based not on what you know or how good of a worker you are, but on how many hours of overtime you're willing to work and how much abuse you're willing to take.  They only want yes men.  They are committed to paying their employees as little as possible and do not give employees performance reviews or have any mechanism for raises once you've been hired at your starting rate, other than to compete for a different higher paying position.  To be considered, you better be working 6 or 7 days per week for years to prove to them that you're worthy.

review_title: Better than my last job, but that's not saying a lot.
pros: Well know brand.  Good benefits.  My peers are nice and helpful.  The brand is great!  The benefits are good if you are a salaried employee.  I love going to the parks for free!
cons: Management not good at leading.  Very negative.  Expectations are not expressed clearly and they change without notice.  A lot of micro managers work here!  Too many company regulations that stifle creativity.  Don't hear a lot of postive things.  Everything is always what you are doing wrong.  Little recognition for what you do right.  Not much support to help you succeed unless you are already a success.  Then, you can do whatever you want.

review_title: Intellectually stimulating, but tough environment for morale since economy tanked.
pros: Great reputation and worldwide brand recognition; lots of pride in making magic happen for guests and consumers.  Among many long-time employees and cast members, strongly expressed desire to keep Walt's dream alive.
cons: Be prepared to work long hours (not uncommon at many companies, but it's engrained in the culture here).  Studios/film business is notoriously subject to not only the economy, but to whether the last few films are flops or hits.  Lay-offs have abounded lately.

pros: It's a great place to meet many people from all walks of life, the corporate culture can't be compared to other jobs I have/had. At the end of the day I am happy to work for this company and making positive guest experiences.
cons: Management keeps changing every 6 months or so, I am seasonal and working a couple months out of the year there's always new managers on the team. I have well over 10 managers who I rarely see during shifts so it makes me question what they are actually doing on a day-to-day basis. Working in the sun is horrible but I knew what I signed up for but just wish that I was in the sun less than 3 hours at a time.

job_title: Fast Pass Cast Member in Orlando, FL
pros:
Great atmosphere! 
Fun Coworkers
Able to "create the magic" that so many people come to experience at WDW
FREE admission to the parks, as well as free parking and discounts on merchandise and hotels.
cons:
ALOT of walking
ALOT of standing on your feet all day
You will deal with unruly guests who are irritated at things that are out of your control
Can be easy to get confused with the electronic employee system that Disney uses at the park.
Was a far drive for me
the pay isn't the best
Have to act happy all the time, (can be a con, was a PRO for me!)

pros: I've worked for Disney over 10 years and in general it has exceeded my expectations. The benefits are decent but have been reduced or have more employee cost in recent years. I have worked in different divisions in different roles which has given me a great appreciation for the company over the years. There are definitely many opportunities to experience the Disney brand which makes the job uniquely Disney.
cons: Disney may be "the happiest place on earth" to the public but within the company, it is mostly like any other company. It is a job but you can make a lifelong career with Disney. The compensation is decent but compared to other companies, it tends to be less.

review_title: A once-great company falling victim to endless political maneuvering.
pros: Discounts on Disney merchandise, annual passes to the parks, screenings (if you can get yourself invited - you have to 'know' the right people.)
cons: Unbelievably political - almost a caricature of itself. A 'creative' entertainment company that secretly thrives on bureaucracy, favoritism & nepotism. The rank & file are overworked, with many doing the work of 2 people for months & even years. High stress & low compensation when the actual working hours are considered, no bonuses. You even have to pay for food & drinks at the company holiday 'party'.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros:
Working for Disney is all it’s cracked up to be. It is so great working for a company that brings so much happiness to people all over the world. The finance unit is integral in developing strategy and supporting the operations of WDW. So it is great to have such greater influence on the clients we support. 

It is a very collaborative environment that still fosters autonomy in your work. It is rare to see micromanaging. There are many avenues for personal development and opportunities to climb the ladder. Despite being a competitive Fortune 100 company, there is still good work & life harmony, so not crazy hours. It’s about getting the work done. And besides the stimulating work, you work for Disney, so that’s cool.
cons: There still are some politics.

review_title: Individual work experiences really depend upon which team you belong to, whom you report to and with whom you work.
pros: The educational reimbursement program is amazing as it reimburses 700$ per unit, which makes top universities an option for educational growth. Work from home and other work/life balance opportunities keep me happy, and I am able to work from home as often as once a week.
cons: In some groups there is a lot of conflict and mistrust. Often, promotions aren't merit based, and seem unfair. Job roles and responsibilities change from team to team, and create a lot of confusion and conflict. HR is really varied- there are some amazing people in that group, and there are also folks who make others feel misled about their job offers.

review_title: A great company but a lot of office politics
pros: Great projects to be a part of, free training courses regularly offered in a range of fields.
cons:
People tend to "sit" in their roles, meaning many people join when their young and refuse to leave such a reputable brand.
This leads to many employees who have been at Disney for many years feeling they are superior to other employees despite their lack of industry experience due to only working for one company in their career. In my experience this has caused problems for Disney's growth and approach to projects.
Office politics is high. Be careful what you say at all times, especially on email.

review_title: Hyper competitive environment for no upwards growth.
job_title: Patterning Process Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: I like the people the company has attracted. Everyone I work with is above and beyond an all star in their field. I do also know it’s rare to get to work in the art field and have a consistent paycheck.
cons: Hyper competitive work environment with no room for upward growth. At least in costuming there are little to no job openings. All of our middle management continue to get spread thin and increase their tasks without increasing their pay or status. For anyone just starting in the field the ability to move up is next to none.

review_title: A wonderful atmosphere for unique individuals who truly love smiling and serving others.
pros: Teaches personal growth and professionalism.  Most standards are unparalleled and highly admired among other companies.  Many different lines of business to venture out and grow.  Accountability is good.
cons: Pay can be frustrating (depending on position) as most Resort Park Cast Members usually work two jobs to live.  Scheduling can be a problem at times.  Guest satisfaction can take precedence over Cast Member retainment.

review_title: Good Place to Work if you're in the Right Department
pros: The company on a whole is good, it all depends on what department you work for. I've had the pleasure of working with people in different departments and have seen how great an environment it can be and I've seen how hard work can pay off, if you are with the right people. I was rewarded by other departments, sadly, never my own.
cons: The department I worked in (Security) was a boys club. There wasn't any way to advance up the ladder - the position you got hired in was where you stayed, regardless of how hard you worked. If you don't play the game, you get punished.

review_title: Great Opportunity with Limited Room to Grow - Parks (Disneyland)
job_title: Attractions Cast Member in Anaheim, CA
pros:
-Working in Disneyland & being apart of the Walt Disney Company
-Having the opportunity to make guests and kids feel special, daily 
-Understanding that you work for one of the worlds best known companies
-The perks include free entry every day as a guest (with valid ID card), discounts on food, guests tickets, merchandise, etc. 
-Seeing the structure of a profitable organization, in which executives and stockholders profit plenty
cons:
-Roughly 25,000 part time and full time employees...do the math on your chances of standing out and joining management. 
-A majority of cast members talk trash about other cast members, rat other cast members out to management (thinking they'll get ahead in some way), and straight up talk trash about guests. Such behavior is immature, unprofessional, and happens in every corner of the theme park.

pros: Great brand.   Lots of very talented and passionate people. Good benefits. Competitive salaries.
cons:
The Solutions Architect position is misleading at Disney. It is not a very technical role and the primary focus is on estimates and high-level diagrams.  

For someone looking to stay in the weeds, this is not a good position.  You lose the skills of a Software Engineer, Application Architect, or a typical Solution Architect.

The morale within the Solution Engineering group, which is the group that Solution Architects belong to, is very poor and management does little to improve conditions.

Growth within the group is very difficult and few people are promoted.  Pursing opportunities, career  growth, and improvement  are also not encouraged.

review_title: Great company, for growth - both personal and professional!
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Orlando, FL
pros:
Well respected and well-reknowned company with plethora of resources.  You can stay a professional lifetime and expand your horizons across multiple "industries".

Even though it's a massive company, I never felt like a "number".  I truly felt like the company made me a better person - and I had a voice.
cons: It is a massive company.  So, if you want immediate reaction  or results - you may get easily frustrated.  Change takes time, communication takes time, results take time.  But only because it is a well-oiled (large) machine and processes are respected.  It is bureaucratic, more similar to a governmental agency - but most Fortune 50 companies I'm assuming operate in a similar function.  That's why they are successful.  Success takes planning and patience.  However, it can be frustrating.

pros: Great company with unrivalled franchises and products. Training and development courses are very comprehensive and professional. Career progression and movement is very good at junior to middle manager level. Company benefits are good and the working environment is inspirational if you are passionate about media, film and consumer products.
cons: Promotional opportunities at senior level strangely are much harder to attain. Not all roles are openly advertised internally in comparison to other large multinationals i.e Coca Cola. Senior decision making can be slow and due to too many levels of bureaucracy. Not as results driven as imagined causing delay/missed opportunities due to risk aversion/politics.

review_title: You Might As Well Go Into Politics
pros: OK benefits, almost market pay, many really great co-workers, the prestige of saying you work for Disney (most people's favorite part, let's be honest), relaxed dress code.
cons: Extremely political environment (that is Disney-wide, sadly--there are literally Disney-sponsored classes you can take to try to learn to navigate the political minefields at Disney), no meritocracy even though that is what they claim, useless review/development process that is mainly for show, small raise pools that have to be divided, weak middle management (Directors, VPs, etc.) afraid of innovating/taking chances/input from below, a few people with a lot of power who maybe shouldn't have all that power, no career path unless you are good at "playing the game."

review_title: WDIG is a great place to work with amazing growth opportunities.
job_title: Human Resources  in North Hollywood, CA
pros: WDIG allows you to pursue individual, team, and company goals.  Senior management gives you the tools and resources to succeed; but you have to take the lead to get things done.  The environment is changing and senior leadership recognize that our culture has shifted, so they are investing in remodeling our building to better meet the employee's needs.  That shows they hear us and are taking action.  Bottom line: Disney has very talented people working on exciting projects; people want to succeed so everyone works very well together to accomplish our goals.  Finally, Disney is huge so you can work for Disney, ABC, ESPN, etc and everyone supports movement across the brands.
cons: compensation and benefits are below average in comparison to our competitors.

pros:
The people you work with are for the most part really happy to be working here. There is almost always some type of an event going on. People tend to never leave the company. Have several employees in our department that have worked for the company for 10,15, even 20 years. 
A lot of discounts and benefits just for working for the company. On site dry cleaning, shoe repair, watch services. These types of benefits make your personal life easier.
cons: Since it's such a huge company it's really hard to make changes and budgets are constantly being scrutinized.  Salary is below market value for most positions. Very corporate.

review_title: Wonderful experience with amazingly smart people and terrific products to work with.
pros: Prior to 2009, the combination of a growing home entertainment industry and strong products helped fuel a highly profitable division.    Smart people and great products from Disney/Pixar,  ABC, Disney Channel and others made this division a top notch place to work for.   Disney Home Entertainment drove a number of great innovations for the company including great retail presence, amazing franchises, and product innovations such as the Disney Movie Rewards program.
cons: As with any Disney division,  individuals still need to find ways to showcase their talents and find successes that can be noticed.   After 2009 and the studio restructuring,  the atmosphere became more conservative and difficult as the business continues to decline.

pros: Working with great products, Fun on-campus events, Park perks, being "part of the magic"
cons: Very heavy office politics come into play, and your opportunities for advancement are based largely on who you rub elbows with rather than the merit of your work. At the Director level, nepotism is rampant, you eventually find out that most of the heavy hitters come from the same companies. Do not attempt to bring in new ideas, or you will be labeled an outlier or disruptor. Drink the Disney Kool-Aid, focus on making the right people happy, work at giving off the perception that you get things done (without actually doing much at all), and you'll fit right in.

pros: The time I was there was really great for me. The leadership at the time was very good. I enjoyed the work, which was challenging, and I liked most people with whom I was in contact.
cons: I'm sure there is a difference in career opportunity, culture, etc. between the different divisions of the company, I was at DCP. There's a hierarchy like any big company, so often things operate inefficiently, can be a long wait to advance your career, political atmosphere. The current morale has suffered due to organizational changes.

review_title: A dream role to play with a lifetime of memo
pros: Culture, fellow Cast Members, fun benefits, opportunities, and like most companies, it is what you make of it....and I made the most of my 25 years in roles that allowed me to live and travel around the world
cons: Disney is not a,pay leader...the fun benefits do make up for a bit but if you crave cash and an ever rising salary you may be disappointed but hey...you can get into the parks most anytime you want....have a magical day

review_title: It's  a well-organized machine with great benefits!
pros: The company structure and the benefits that the company offer definitely outweigh any challenges that I faced. The dozens of annual Park Passes (and I didn't work for The Parks), discounts, and even as a Part Time employee I had medical benefits!!!!! The company encompasses so many departments, businesses, and locations advancement is definitely available. Loved it!
cons: The company can be so big and so corporate that you feel lost in the bunch and your department can feel out of touch.Employee recognition was also not a primary practice, but that may have been just at my location or department.

pros:
-It is a great place to start your professional career
-You can learn the best of marketing and consumer products
-The team is very passionate and people love their jobs
-You have a lot of benefits as an employee for example free tickets to the parks, free samples, very nice desks, themed decorations everywhere, free movies every month, lots of holidays, etc.
- It is really like working in wonderland, you could personalize your desk and the senior manager's offices where all decorated with their favorite characters.
- Lots of corporate responsibility activities, team work, etc.
cons:
As it is a great company my salary wasn't so high, but it was worth it because we had a lot of benefits.
Difficult to get a job there, as a high number of people want the same job as you.

pros: The personal and friends/family sign-ins are an amazing perk. Discounts on merchandise, food, and hotels are great too. I love my job and I love being able to make happiness and magic for the guests. No two days are the same, even if you plan them to be. Time flies while I am at work and I have a ton of fun! I love going to work everyday!
cons: THE PAY. My department is unionized (a lot of them are) and you start out a few cents over minimum wage no matter what your experience is, and we increase 3% each year. I haven't been able to move up as quickly as I had imagined. Parking S-U-C-K-S and it is just getting worse.

review_title: Good company to work for..........as long pay isn't important to you
pros:
Disney looks great on your resume.
Great work life balance except at Corporate.
Fun industry to work in.
Free passes to the parks and discounts on food and merchandise.
Low stress.
Friendly co-workers.
Disney still has a pension which you are immediately vested in.
cons:
The pay is a joke and don't think you will get in there and work your way up to a huge pay raise.  I knew someone who worked their way up from Analyst to Director and the largest raise they ever got was 8%.  Disney just does not pay well.   

The pay is my only major complaint every other negative about Disney you will get at every big, mature company.

review_title: Great Company- Depending on your position
pros: Great benefits, name recognition on your resume, perks include getting into parks and Disney discounts.
cons: Depending on the area you get put in you could be on the fast track to no where. My area is nothing but data entry drones. I want to learn and be in the amazing culture everyone raves about but I have had to fight for every learning experience I've gotten. The company has too many managers and not enough people to do actual work. In my area alone I have 4 immediate supervisors while myself, one other team member and an intern do the every day tasks.

pros:
-Lots of hours + overtime even if you're considered part time
-Work with nice people
-Free entrance to parks, free parking etc
cons:
-No guests interaction so you're not creating 'magic'
-Understaffed
-Management at times do not care how much work load there is
-Poor treatment from management 
-Heavy work
-Hands will get sore after every work day
-Co-workers can be negative most of the time
Keep in mind this experience is on my department. As far as I know, the other steward departments do not get this much negativity. They seem to be fine. Our department is a problem.

pros: Solid stable company with good benefits. Work atmosphere is generally happy and there is a good demeanor and teamwork among employees.  Solid structure and multi-dimensional in terms of the corporate setup.  Once you start working for the company they generally want to maintain the high performing employees within the company.  Room to move around to different departments of varying backgrounds.
cons: Seems difficult to advance since there is only a set number of positions and new departments are few and far between.  Also only senior level employees are eligible for year end bonues apparently which is frustrating for lower levels.  The department structures can be rigid and the unwritten rules of hierarchy are laughable at times and concerning at others.

pros:
Well-managed...friendly work environment...respected amongst co-workers...open-door policy with management...the team-effort style...
It's a good company that offers solid benefits...very family-oriented. a.
cons:
Hours - but that's common anywhere in the television and radio world, especially with news.
I, personally, work 3am-12 noon with Friday and Saturday off.
Time to advance - the people who are at Disney, at least the location I am at, stay at Disney for a *long* time.
Half of the people there have been there for decades, so if you want to advance, it'll take a while, to say the least.

review_title: Fantastic brands (shows), great company overall, but some significant concerns about work environment.
pros:
Fast-paced, cutting-edge environment working with strong, nationally-known show brands and talent.
Many talented co-workers.
Access to pretty much anything in the entertainment industry due to the Disney and ABC names.
The Silverpass (free Disneyland/Disney Parks access)!
Excellent benefits.
Oppotunities to work on innovative projects (but could be moreso).
cons:
Highly political.
HR is there to protect the company, not act on your behalf as an employee.
Advancement opportunities decrease as you move up.
Pace can be punishing, and negatively affects work-life balance (but that's TV, not Disney-ABC as such).
Splashy achievements often recognized and rewarded over solid, year after year "get 'er done" work.

review_title: When you wish upon a star, makes no difference who you are…none of your ambitions will come true.
pros: Wearing many hats on a cable level affords opportunities to expand skill set.
cons: Zero pay for performance bumps for top performers who wear those many hats.

review_title: Amazing Talent in a Typical Corporate Environment
pros:
Incredible pool of talent. Strong art culture. Good benefits. Flexible schedules. Current projects have been very successful.

Opportunity to work on high-profile properties that look great on a resume.
cons: At first the culture seems collaborative and egalitarian, but the more time you spend there the more you see that management is very top-down. Dissent is discouraged and deference to authority is emphasized, but in a Dolores Umbrage kind of a way. No real ownership of the work -- a small group of leadership signs off on all work. Not much opportunity for career advancement. No interest in community involvement. Outside of the games industry few people are even aware there is a Disney Games studio in Salt Lake City.

pros: Great job; was treated well, got free access to the parks and discounts as well. Absolutely loved the role I was assigned--I probably wouldn't have minded doing that job for the rest of my life. My managers and co-cast members were awesome.
cons: When you're a CP, you're not taken as seriously as other employees. They work you hard. I averaged 50 hour weeks. Because I loved my job, it wasn't too bad but it was tough to work two weeks straight without a day off. There are other CPs who hate their jobs and really struggle--just because you work at Disney World doesn't mean you'll love your job.

job_title: Network Site Administrator in Oak Park, IL
pros: Typically your coworkers are great people. Everyone is usually very excited to be working for the company. There is a great feeling of team work.
cons: The politics within the business groups tends to hamper the work the staff is trying to do. Management at the corporate level does not appear to be interested in balancing the desire to increase profits with the needs of the people doing the work.
