Staff is seen and treated as a resource to be quickly discarded when it helps the bottom line of the company.

job_title: Project Manager/Business Analyst in Glendale, CA
pros:
Shuttle to take you to offsite Disney locations for work
Van Pool if you can get it.
cons:
Two people sharing a small cube with noisy phone meetings all day.
Extremely stressful work environment with no quiet space to get work done
Overworked employees in my office, and several others around.  
Micromanagement of work adding to stress.
No overtime allowed even though workload was unreasonably high.
Not a single perk except slightly discounted merchandise at stores.
Not allowed to visit Disneyland even though we did work there several times.
There are no discount tickets for staff to Disneyland.  Hard to believe.
No covered parking even in hot sun. 
Movie discounts are better at Costco for their own employees.

review_title: Good but used to be great
pros: Disney is one of the most respected brands. Good benefits. Most of the fellow cast members are awesome.
cons:
Disney Vacation Club does not like to think of themselves as "timeshare", yet all of the recent hires in management come from old school timeshare companies, and act very differently than your typical Disney Cast Member. The professionalism has gone away, and many long time, and extremely talented sales people have left in frustration. 
It is sad, but if they want to be a typical timeshare company, just do it and stop pixie dusting it.

review_title: I love being a Disney Intern!
pros: My supervisors are the greatest, super nice and you learn so much just in the first few weeks you're at the job.  In terms of finance/accounting jobs, its a much more fun environment to be in with similar pay and benefits, than say...a financial services company like the big 4.
cons: The company doesn't give you a lot of vacation time.  Maybe if they boosted the benefits package a bit, only 2 weeks off per year really is too little and borderline slave driving.

pros: Very diverse product line and locations offers some internal variety, strong consumer brand, financially strong company
cons: Like with most major corporations - VERY political, little mentorship for future leaders, most are overworked and under appreciated, taking risks in encouraged but failure is not handled well, , change is constant and often uncoordinated, high stress, and career development is the responsibility of the employee.  They are will to let people with many years of service walk without concern.

pros: It's very easy and fast to be self-employed because you control your self because if you failed your own life will failed so that's make in the strength way he show how you manage people give you maturity if you feel your live will be failed so all the time you need pay attention,you need to be focused for me it's the best reason to be self-employed.
cons: Sometimes it's very difficult to connect with the society because our spirit  different is not easy when you by services you need to be patient and safety so isn't Willy easy .

pros: The Walt Disney Company was a wonderful experience that I had as a  cast member. They are very good to their cast members and the experience that I had their working for so many years was a wonderful one !! the human resource department was a wonderful outlet for me as a cast member in order to talk to someone who worked in the apartment and work through issues although very minor we're always taken care of and I appreciated the help and the guidance that they gave me while my tenure at Disney.
cons: I don't have any cons 2 give as per se. My experience was so great that I have nothing negative to report.

review_title: WDIG is a great place to work very family oriented
job_title: Tools Programmer in North Hollywood, CA
pros: Great salary, can't beat working for a came company.  The group that I am in is really good for career growth.  My manager absolutely rocks.
cons: They do not hire anyone directly, everyone is initially hired as a contractor and they rolled over into a ful time employee.  As a contractor you do not get any benefits so that is another negative.  The other thing that is both a plus and a minus is there is no micromanagment, so if you're somebody taht needs to be told what to do every day than this probably isn't the job for you, but if you can find things to do, this would be a great job for you.

review_title: Amazing, unlike any other large corporation
pros:
Great work-life balance 
You're working for a very creative company and the culture really encourages you to think outside of the box, tackle new challenges and pursue growth opportunities 
The brand draws a very talented group of people, who are very passionate about what they are doing
You're working for Disney! 
Despite being a very large company, Disney does a great job of creating a culture that feels like a small company.  You can make a change without having to secure approval from a gazillion leadership teams.
cons:
There's no clear career path.  It is up to you to plan your next move, not much guidance or resources available. 
It is equally hard to move within the company as it is to get into the company. 
Frequent restructuring in some business units.

review_title: Great Environment to Work In… Terrible Hours
job_title: Part Time Cast Member in Anaheim, CA
pros:
Best retail experience you'll ever have
Love the Mission Statement and the Company
Opportunities to be creative through events, storytelling, and Disney knowledge
Volunteer (Voluntear) opportunities
Great benefits (i.e. Disneyland admission, guest admission, discounts, etc.)
cons:
Little upward movement towards management within your own store
Shifts as short as 3 hours long
Call-ins are a nightmare and leave you unable to plan your day or week
So few hours, most CM's are working 3-7 hours on average post-Holiday season
High expectations from management, but little feedback on how you're doing until review time (also working once or twice a week leaves you unable to actually improve)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Leadership at The Walt Disney Company really want to create a culture of great leadership principles that would make the company and Studio a great place to work IF they could get all leaders to abide by those principles. The Studio is relatively well organized from a technology, operations and distribution stand point. The people are great to work with.
cons: Some of the senior executives at the Studio say they embody the spirit of TWDC leadership, but they really don't and are ineffective at leadership.  Like all Studios, there are a lot of politics, especially as you go higher up the ladder.

pros: Working for Disney is a feather in your Cap.
cons: Welcome to PC Culture 101. Creativity is stifled because you just regurgitate licensed properties. It's every-man for himself culture. So if you stick your nose down and do your work and make sure everyone sees it then you should do well. It's a good transition company to work for. Let them train you so you can get a better job somewhere else.  All the senior leaders are wedged into the best spots. So good luck advancing unless you are prepared to sacrifice home and family for some brownie points. I wish I could be more positive but ya.

review_title: Be responsible for making your career your own within the company's goals.
pros: great benefits for professional staff, both hard (insurance, 401k, commuter, etc).  and soft (discounts, etc), interesting and changing work.
cons: Cast Member experience varied greatly by where you worked and for whom you worked.  Such is the life at a world-wide conglomerate.

pros: Disney has some of the best benefits and perks compared to almost any media company. They have a good orientation for new hires and people are very welcoming. The ongoing training for managers is excellent. And HR is very supportive in advising management.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy - many layers of approval - in order to get things done. If you are coming from a start up, you will find this a challenge. It's very hard to get an idea off the ground. You will need buy-in from multiple stakeholders - consumer products, legal, etc.

pros: Disney is a truly different experience. You get to work with kids and talk about Disney movies all the time. It's great to bring a smile to each persons face by creating a little magic.
cons: They have nearly no full time employees in the Disney Store, only management. They do not allow employees to have a good work life balance, basically open availability is required. Holiday's can't be requested off. Trading shifts is frowned upon and most of the time straight up forbidden. Don't ask any questions and make sure you wear Disney's rose colored glasses or your chance of moving up within the company will be greatly diminished. If you want to work for minimum wage, be subjected to ridiculous standards, have issues you bring up dismissed with little or no concern, and be unable to spend quality time with family around the holidays, this job is for you.

pros: Silver Pass is awesome for going to Disneyland with friends.
cons:
Quite possibly the worst place I've ever worked. There's so many reason to avoid this job that it's hard to know where to begin.

Zero advancement opportunities or chances for a raise.

Horrible middle management with zero empowerment or motivation.

Incredibly top heavy, at least six executives more than need be.

Paid about $30k a year below market value and was literally laughed at when I asked to have my wage adjusted for inflation last year.

Zero alignment from leadership on strategy. You would get one answer from one executive in one meeting, and minutes later hear an entirely different answer in the next. 

No basic kindness for new employees. My manager didn't even show me where to find supplies, let alone where the bathroom was.

The leadership have almost no game experience and are running a game team. Let that one sink in.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Valuable brands (e.g. ABC, ESPN, Disney, Disneyland, Walt Disney World, Bassmasters), strong focus on media, family-friendly atmosphere.
cons: Basic systems architecture is antiquated. Application architecture is antiquated. IT architecture is antiquated. Sometimes it is amazing anything still performs, but perform it does at a surprising high scale. Salary and benefits are not competitive with the rest of the tech market. Disney suffers from a bit of the Microsoft hubris (working here is a privileged, therefore we don't need to offer competitive salary and benefits).

pros: The perks of theme park entry, company-paid parties and lunches are wonderful. A person can take pride in the company's name recognition and the quality of the overall entertainment that the company produces. You feel the satisfaction of contributing to something good and memorable. Pay and benefits were comparable to the tech industry elsewhere.
cons: Medical benefits steadily and substantially reduced during my years at WDW. Early on, I was very aware of a class difference between hourly and salaried. Later, the difference seemed even more acute between salaried and executive. Executives would be promoted in "critical positions", while all other pay was frozen. Layoffs were once unthinkable, then rare, then more common. Gossip and favoritism was a lot easier to see after several years.

pros: Working at Disney you get to meet lots of people from all over the world, make long lasting friendships, which is guaranteed to happen. And you well never know how much connection you have to move up your career until you have used up all the connections, which won't happen. Plus Disney looks good on any resume period.
cons:
Your starting pay will be pennies, close to nothing and unless you have a second job or something  or someone that can help you financially, you'll go broke before you can move up the Disney ladder. 

Costumes not uniforms! are hideous. Not even a therapist could tell your beautiful. 

Dress code violations? you'll find your in one everyday. That how many there are.

The cons list could go on, but it's so much more effective to see for yourself and be the judge.

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros:
Access to the theme parks.  Behind-the-scenes knowledge (for the curious).  Pride in the brand.  You become popular with old friends and distant relatives.

Also, the I.T. organization is large and generally follows reasonable and prudent best practices for software development and systems maintenance.
cons: In I.T., way too many middle managers.  Information is closely-held.  Advancement requires significant role-playing and patience.

review_title: Magical! My location made the working experience great.
job_title: Sales & Merchandise Hostess in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great floor leads and managers in merchandise locations. I worked in the busiest store at Disneyland, and work was always fun and exciting even on the craziest of days. Lots of opportunities to create magical moments for guests and families. Easy to get days off and switch shifts. Point system for sick/late days is fair. Free admission is a huge plus.
cons: Low pay because the company knows people like working for Disney. You definitely work there because of the environment, not for the paycheck. Fortunately I was just there for an internship, and wasn't trying to support more than just myself with the pay.

pros: Fun job, lively people, different every day
cons: Your schedule is different every day of every week, parking redirects happen way too often, pay is terrible, get yelled/cursed at daily by guests. It also takes too long getting in and out of work (yes, cast members have them too); we park offsite at a parking lot not always owned by Disney (sometimes angels stadium or Honda center) and then get in a shuttle to the parks. We then wait to have our bags checked by security to get on property. From there, you either take a backstage shuttle or walk to your work location (up to 10 minute walk long depending on the location). This whole process can take up to 45 minutes on a bad day, so you have to get to work extremely early every day to avoid being late.

review_title: Amazing company....enjoy coming to work every day!
job_title: Business Operations Manager in Burbank, CA
pros: Great people, leadership is terrific, inspiring, positive culture, great development, growth, and collaboration. I love working there and am lucky to be part of a great organization like Disney. I hope to finish my career at Disney. Good benefits and soft perks overall. Great tuition program
cons: The salary will likely be a little less than you can earn on the open market but the soft perks if you love Disney are exceptional. Wish they matched more on the 401k but the company provides great benefits overall for employees.

review_title: Good place to work if you're senior staff.
job_title: Marketing Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The brand name opens doors, and it looks good on a resume. Company has good benefits.
cons: There is a serious lack of middle management. If you start there in an entry level position you will not get promoted unless you leave and come back. The organizational structure of the company is mostly senior staff and their assistants. Therefore, assistants end up doing managerial work for little pay and a title that may reflect prevent higher positions in the future. While the Disney brand is well-recognized the name can only get you so far. Also, there is very little interaction among employees and management is very top-down.

pros: It is one of the best internships I have ever experienced, also the highest paying internship. The experience may be a little tedious, but there is definitely room to grow. Tip: Ask questions, the management team loves to see someone eager to learn+passionate
cons: Respect comes a long way, sometimes when someone in a high position notices you are intern, they take advantage of it. I've made numerous numbers of copies, sat on the computer trying to fix minor ms power point/ word problems because no one else wants to do it.

review_title: Great place to start in entertainment
pros:
Great brand creation - This is self explanatory - they know how to tell a story and make characters people remember
Great training - Disney University and ways to transfer company culture and knowledge is impressive and scalable 
Great people - Disney attract talent and your peers will be smart and creative
Great Service Culture - the parks are masters at creating and maintaining an experience.
cons:
Can't get promoted more than one level at a time no matter your qualifications/job needed.  
People often leave and come back to get around it.
I believe in paying dues, but if you are qualified, you are qualified

review_title: Byzantine process, but good people and interesting work
pros: Good people to work with and some of the business units are on the forefront of technology.
cons: The Corp. IT department is outsourced, slow and some of the groups in Disney will have nothing to do with them.  Process and organization structure is Byzantine and get's in the way more often than not.

review_title: Good benefits and privileges. Restrictive for production and low pay.
job_title: UI Designer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Fun benefits like free passes to Disneyland and DisneyWorld.
Food is provided for you for all three meals.
Caltrain Go pass is provided for free, short walk from the station.
Flexible Hours in my team.
Friendly employees in all immediate teams
Family friendly atmosphere.
No cubicles but desks instead, keeping a view of each other for open communication.
cons:
Salary rates are NOT competitive.
Slow production cycle, going to India and back.
Upper management has no idea what is going on.
Lots of restricted issues with using high hitting IPs.
Hard to get in contact with upper management.
Communication concerns go to a black hole with no replies.
Studio-wide meetings are often cancelled with no explanation.

job_title: Custodial Guest Services in Anaheim, CA
pros: They hire from within, so there's lots of opportunity to change departments and move up in the ranks, they give great access to the parks for you and friends/family. Raises are annual, based on a percentage, as given by union contract.
cons: You start as Casual Regular and your hours aren't guaranteed. They give hours based on seniority so if you're new, you may not get many hours. Because most of the cast members are younger, it may seem like a dramafest. You have to join the union. Only give benefits if you're Casual Permanent, which you need to wait for openings for, as well as do an interview.

review_title: Hostile work environment, abundant corporate greed
pros: The connections, if you happen to meet some of the genuinely kind people who just do their work and go home and don’t get ‘involved’ in social situations at work. The experience, and the word Disney on your resume.
cons: Hostile work environment. I wouldn’t want any of my friends or family to work here. Some sexual harassment, very much social exclusion, huge age gaps which lead to more exclusion.

pros: I enjoy the people I work with and the company as a whole.  The benefits package is good, I don not know what to compare it to since this is my first job but I am happy with it.  The benefit of going to Disneyland anytime is good to, although it completely opposite of where I go to work and i don not go too often.
cons: The departmental management, they fail at personnel issues.  Rumors of what management is going to do circulate around the office and I do believe the management realizes this and they do not address these issues.  There is also to motivation to work any harder than the person next to me because the rewards are not appealing.

pros: Unlimited opportunites to advance your skills by working in many varied lines of business.  Depending on your business unit's management, the opportunity to freely utilize the skills you were hire for.
cons: Expectations and compensation vary widely throughout the company.  There is an attitude that Disney can pay less because they are Disney and people will just want to work for them.  Disney has not fully embraced non traditonal work schedules.  They still have a "brick and mortar" attitude towards employees sitting in an office 40 hours a week.  In thier defense, some business units have more fully embraced 21st century work models.

job_title: Senior Producer/Digital Strategist in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work.  The Diversity (ethnic, ages, etc.) made for a great work environment.  Learned so much during my time there.  My husband became very ill when I first started and they were accommodating and very kind the entire time.  Overall one of my greatest
cons: It took 3 weeks for me to get a computer when I started, so I had to use my personal laptop.  Sat floors away from the rest of my team so I felt isolated.  Needed to travel more than I was led to believe.

review_title: Great legacy to uphold, but efforts sometimes hampered by corporate policy.
pros: There's a lot to be proud of working for an established entertainment company with such a recognizable brand.  Exciting projects and wonderful people for the most part.  It's rare that I'm embarrassed by the movie titles to which I've contributed.  With Pixar, Marvel and LucasFilm in the mix, the future looks fairly bright.
cons: Corporate strategies and hierarchy do not seem to place a premium on filmmaking, only on building brands.  And we can't seem to make it through a two-year period now without layoffs, or the threat of the same.  It's bad for morale and takes away from employees' desire to do great things.

review_title: Good company to work for - few complaints
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: They go out of their way to immerse you in the "Happiest Place on Earth" ideal. They pamper you with every amenity. They're kind and warm, and they hold the highest respect for the creative abilities that landed you with the company.
cons: Disney suffers from the same ailment that every multi-national conglomerate suffers from. It's just too big. Business units are like small societies. They have to vie for resources to the detriment of the entire organization. And because it's so massive, trying to get something simple done can often quickly can get blocked by your typical bureaucratic processes.

review_title: Don't think because it's Disney that its fun
pros:
- More professional than other schools in the TEFL industry. 
- Free passes to Disney parks. 
- Training done at the beginning of orientation is good.
cons:
- Huge workload. It's not just teaching kids, there is also a ton of admin work that you won't find in other schools. 
- Inadequate staffing means that you are always being pressured into covering shifts or not exercising your annual leave. 
- No communication, strategy, or respect from top management. 
- Disney culture is extremely political.
- The company is too sales focused. Trainers are quasi-salesmen.

job_title: Seasonal Cast Member in Woodbridge, VA
pros:
Great Discount
Love of the brand- this is the biggest pro for some people but trust me when I say my love for Disney did not get me through the horrible management that made my life hell there.
Like it says on the title it's Russian Roulette. You might get a store with great caring management or you might get shot in the face.
cons:
Management incompetent, unreasonable and uncaring about employees. They made working there a living hell.
You will be made to work extremely hard with little recognition and I was personally constantly humiliated
Be prepared to expend a large amount of energy  24/7 smiling and talking in high voice and performing. If you aren't a performer this isn't the place for you.
Very con-artist behavior, you are told to scam  guests as much as possible.
Few hours
Low Pay

review_title: Fun and inspiring company that offers great benefits but non-competitive pay. Makes you want to come into work daily
job_title: Computer and Graphics Specialist in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The workplace at Disney is unrivaled. The diversity of its employees make it a fun place to come in and work on a daily basis. Additionally, the company offers a job for any artist or skillset. Meeting and interacting with them on a daily basis makes the place memorable. Whether you're in a front-end guest interface role or a back-end everyone contributes to 'making dreams come true'. The benefits are also stellar. The 'disney difference' encompasses more than just complimentary park entry. Cast members are rewarded and recognized. Great deal of upward mobility and growth.
cons: The pay at the company is almost laughable at a bottom level. For higher level management, execs is very respectable.

review_title: Working at the Disney TV Division
pros: Disney is a huge company and is always looking to expand its reach by investing in technology. This helps create new opportunities for anyone looking for a position within the company. Great culture and lots of good people.
cons: It can be very difficult to advance to a higher position.  A lot of people stay put where they're at and unless a department is expanding, a promotion within the group may be very difficult. Sometimes it works out for people, and many times it doesn't.

pros: You work for a prestigious company and a legendary brand.
cons:
The corporate culture is horrible. Managers treat employees like children, using archaic and outdated policies to keep control over their little fiefdoms. The company just instituted a "flexible schedule" policy but left it up to each division leader as to whether or not it would work for their team. Guess what. Our manager decided it wouldn't work and dismissed it out of hand. Nice.

Hard work and excellent creative work is rewarded with... oh, wait, it's not rewarded at all. Employees are constantly stabbing each other in the back in order to make themselves look good and to position themselves for table scraps from above. It's a toxic and dysfunctional place to work.

pros: Great perks such as free passes for the parks, discounts on resort stays and merchandise. They offer good benefits too.
cons: They don't pay very well. They pay bare minimum. And I haven't seen any raises in pay each year. It's hard to move up in the company. You have to know somebody that knows somebody to get a better paying job. Remember that your fighting thousands of other cast members to get a job. And don't expect a constant schedule, you never know when you will be working and be prepared to work over 40 hours.

job_title: Disney College Program in Orlando, FL
pros:
-Free Park Tix for self however limited to how many you have for friends/family.
- Classes
- Meet and Greet events with higher ups
-If you create a network you could build a solid career with Disney
-Meeting some of the best friends you'll have in your lifetime.  My best friend who i met on the CProgram lives about 3 hours out from me and we hang out as much as we can when we can 4 years later.
cons:
-You work a lot
- you work the hours that most FT and PT Cms dont want
-little pay
-pay for your room and board 
(Just remember that this job is about creating a network than it is about gaining money in your pocket as a college student)

pros: The magic you get to help create here is unlike anywhere else in the world. Coming to work everyday, getting to see the fireworks, hear the songs we all love...it pulls at your heartstrings.
cons: Like anywhere else, it's still a job. It's difficult to climb the ladder here, & a lot of people will step on others to get where they want. The company also ALWAYS believes that the customer is right, and I've seen many a cast member leave the company because of this. The guests are untouchable, and unfortunately, the cast members are the ones to pay for it.

review_title: Satisfaction at Disney depends on you Manager and the group you work with on a daily basis.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Burbank, CA
pros: The prestige of saying you work for Disney is one of the best advantages. When or if you decide to leave, having Disney on your resume is an advantage. Another perk is that you receive free passes to the parks.  Initial pay and benefits package are competetive in the industry.
cons: The hours can be really long.  Senior Management (in some departments) is extremely dismissive of the employees' needs.  In my department, praise and raises were few and far between unless you were one of the favored.  Training is really hard to get in the company despite an online training system.

pros: As you might expect, there are a few great perks that come with working for Disney - theme park admission being the best. It is fun to be "Part of the Magic," at least for a while.
cons: The "magic" wears off pretty quickly, so working for Disney can sometimes diminish one's high opinion of the Disney brand after a while. The culture is very hard-driving, with a lot of emphasis on face time and putting in long hours.

pros: The opportunity to interact with guests and make a lasting memory for them was one of the best reasons to work for Disney. The benefits needless to say were great!
cons: I am a very hard worker and friendly. I was so excited to work at Disney! I am going to college and wanted to make a career there. However, the company buys your soul. It is VERY poor pay which they do make up to a SMALL degree with the great benefits but there is none of the coworkers even knew my name after a month. My personally assigned manager had no idea who I was. It was very very disappointing to see how the operation runs. I never would have guessed.

review_title: Magical, creative, and some leadership frustration.
job_title: Creative Development Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing heritage, storytelling, innovation in the correct division, and a culture that is changing back to what Walt created in the beginning.
cons: Upper management tends to make fear based decisions due to pressure to make wall street happy.  Too many senior leaders are Managers and not leaders. Lead mostly by MBA majors that know only how to manage people, money, and risk rather than lead, inspire, curate, guide and motivate.

review_title: Great co-workers terrible upper management that says one this and does the opposite.
pros: Coworkers, salary and working conditions. The "Peon" workers are some of the best people I have worked with. The same, however, cannot be said for Upper management. The diversity of products means you are rarely bored and always challenged.,
cons: Senior management is a pack of lying wolves. They will look you in the eyes and tell you everything is great all while axing jobs for no reason whatsoever.

pros: I thought that Disney provided a great work environment for their employees This included a spacious office with great views, free snacks, access to a beautiful commissary and gift shop. There were great perks to working here as well including amazing benefits, discounts, and not to mention free Disneyland admission. I also loved that the company promoted professional development and growth.
cons: I was not happy with work life balance at Disney. I found that I was answering an excessive amount of emails and phone calls outside of working hours and on weekends. While this is understandable if you are a salaried employee, as an hourly employee I did not feel like I was compensated well for my time outside of work.

pros: If you want something nice listed on your resume - accept the internship...but that's all you're getting. i've been Interning for 9 months for two separate departments and its the most mundane job I've ever had. The first two days I was brought into meetings and then following those two meetings it was dead silence. I do absolutely nothing except come into work and collect a paycheck. I, on occasion do some Ad-Hoc work - but other than that. I do absolutely nothing ...and you may think that is a prize package but it becomes seriously depressing. Coming into a job, sitting for 8 hours and it sucking the life out of you. I've spoken to other interns and this is pretty much the case across the board. There is zero sense of responsibility. Coming from several other studios and/ or internships where I actually did work, was trained and held accountable. I strongly urge you look elsewhere. Don't work for ABC
cons: Go to HBO or somewhere else.

pros: I was pregnant when they hired me and there was no discrimination.
cons: However new hires along with College Program students are stuck with the closing shifts. I worked on main street in magic kingdom and if the park closes at 12am, our store stays about 2 hours later until the last guest leaves and we have to clean up the store. I had many guests complain to me that they were very upset to see me working there such late hours. You really don't have much say in your schedule and all you can do is hope you get morning shifts or find someone to trade with you.

job_title: Strategic Sourcing & Procurement Specialist in Burbank, CA
pros: Looks great on a resume. Excellent training opportunities. Good perks. Great name recognition
cons: Some people get paid a lot and do very little. Company too large to do much about mid-management problems. I expect some managers in sourcing receive kickbacks. In some cases competitive bidding is a joke. Overall the company does well, but could do so much better if more attention was paid to purchasing and procurement.

review_title: Good experience, wouldn't do it again
pros: Meet a lot of people, company culture, free admission into the park, random holiday discounts, managers are very caring and nice to the hourly employees.
cons: The worst part of working at Disney is the scheduling department. I was going to school full-time and showed them a hardcopy of my schedule and they still required me to work an hour after I got out of class. This is Southern CA where traffic during rush hour is unbearable. Because my managers were so chill, they waived all my tardiness for me since the people in the scheduling department think they're important even though they don't realize that going to a university is over $20k a year!!

review_title: The most unhappiest place on earth.
pros: Great brand recognition.  Coworkers are great....only because everyone shares the same misery.  Easy place to move around....but it will be the same archaic bureaucracy depending on which group you move to
cons: Poor leadership.  Top heavy.  Goals are unclear and often unrealistic. Executives have no idea what is going on at the lower level.  Work long hours because leadership does not set out reasonable expectations.

review_title: Disney is a great place to launch a person's career
pros: A great place to work with many different businesses and the opportunity to meet many different professionals.   Everyone is polite and kind and creates a great environment to work in.  The Disney brand is maintained by all its employees.
cons: Disney is an American company that does business abroad.  It's not a multi-national company where it takes into considerations the inputs of employees overseas.  Also, employees in the US seem to be promoted much more quickly than in overseas because of certain caps on titles (e.g. no more than X VPs or Y Directors or Z Managers.

review_title: Casual work environment operating like a start up
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in North Hollywood, CA
pros: Bright teams and try to deliver value through innovative software systems. The teams are lean and Agile is employed.  There is complimentary beverages and tea and on Fridays they bring in bagels for everyone.
cons: Difficult to get interviews when applying online.  Sometimes the people from the business can be difficult to work with because they feel they have so much seniority to make any request they want anytime.

review_title: Executives have little understanding for what is truly important to the Guests.
job_title: Guest Service Manager II in Anaheim, CA
pros: Fun, a bit of glamour, flexible hours, good benefits.
cons: Very little support from senior leadership to get the tools and resources we need to do our jobs well and provide the best Guest experience. The administration building gets all the luxuries, while the actual operating areas get the leftovers.

pros:
-Good benefits and perks but you must be hired full-time to have access to a majority of them.
-Great products and being surrounded by beloved Disney characters.
cons:
-Poorly run organization and working environment managed by corporate partners.
-Employees are undervalued and unappreciated at every level.
-Hours are often "On-call" and usually slashed midweek making personal budgeting nearly impossible.
-Would only recommend this specific location as a secondary job, temporary solution or a last resort even in this tight economy.

pros: Disney season pass, free screenings, the product is interesting (ie movie titles)
cons:
- office politics are absurd. Everyone is backstabbing each other and in defense mode. No one takes responsibility for anything. 
- one for one ratio of manager to SFA which leads to micro managing
- no flexibility or appreciation....it's not a work hard play hard environment. It's a work hard and keep working culture
- not treated respectfully...will give you a project at 5 pm on a Friday and expect you to complete it before going home 
- job is super easy and you don't have to use your brain...basically a vacation (with political stress)

review_title: Love your job and you'll never work a day in your life
pros: Working in attractions was fun and enjoyable.  The castmembers became great friends of mine and I loved going to work, most of the time!  Disney has pretty nice benefits, including park access for you and your dependents.
cons: Costuming never has what you need in your size...  Hours can get very low during the slower seasons.  Many college-aged kids work here and can be immature.  Guests can be rude but you have to grin and bear it.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow!
pros: I worked for the Disney company just under 13 years before I left.  I started right out of HS and was able to grow as a professional through many different positions there.  Top notch training and some of the best leaders I have ever worked for. Great benefits.
cons: Internal equity.  As someone who worked there for so long (and in HR so I knew what people around me were making) I saw some inequality in the salaries.  They should pay the people who have dedicated so many years to the company the same as those hired from the outside.

review_title: You want to love it, but they make it difficult
pros: Benefits are a plus. It's also great that it's not a suit and tie required company.
cons:
Like any large company, it's super bureaucratic. There are a lot of supervisors that are completely out of touch with their department members. New supervisors get hired because they are favored, not because they possess qualities or the skillset that is needed to manage certain teams. 
There is a lot of turnover in terms of the executives, as it is in all entertainment fields. 
Very slow to change - the company as a whole has a lot of employees that have been here for a long time and they are very slow to adapt to the changing times in this industry.

review_title: If only they'd open their wallet...
pros: Great company and people work there.  Typically, the people are very passionate about what they do here.  Teams usually hire for good fit as well as technical skills.
cons: Comp isn't as high as other places.  High pressure to continually meet numerous seasonal deadlines which gives short windows in which to do actual work.  Lots of heat when it comes to culture and justification of time.

pros:
Flexible work opportunities
Employee cinema screenings
Dental and medical benefit
Generous pension
Free Disney park passes
Summer hours
Fun team
Great brand to work with
cons:
Old technology
No training development because of budget restrictions 
No Christmas parties (!)
Political hierarchy 
Inept middle management
Restricted headcount so often under resourced
Limited career development
Stale employees who have been at Disney far too long with limited external experience
Each department is managed differently so experiences for employees are mixed and not always fair
Old building that's falling apart
Always going through redundancies
Poor HR leadership

job_title: Financial Analyst in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The perks.  I mean, how can you beat Disney World?  It turns into a weekend activity for the family.  This was one of the reasons I moved for Florida to take this job in the first place.  Instead of Disney World being a major vacation, it turns into something like a day at the movies.  I find that my family can travel more since we don't have to choose between Disney World and something else.
cons: You lose a little of the magic when you see Mickey day in and day out at the water cooler.  I also find that it's a little uncomfortable to negotiate salary.  But then again, that could just be me.

job_title: Chief Executive Officer/Senior Consultant in Goiânia
pros: In this type and size of company we have the possibility of working in different areas, allowing a view of the overall context of the client companies so providing specialized service of good quality
cons: The company is small and needs capital to expand their activities thus limiting up the number of clients served. Moreover, it operates in different segments which requires large research effort.

review_title: A disappointment.. the way supervisors treat their employees is unprofessional.
pros: They seem to provide good benefits to their employees once hired.
cons: Some of the management does not know how to communicate with co-workers without degrading them and putting them down. There is not enough information sharing. You are only allowed to see a small window of how your work fits in the big picture but are not given enough relevant information on other areas of the company in order to do your job effectively. Disney does not provide training, or at least did not for me, and then they put you down and yell at you for procedures you were never told.

review_title: Has its moments being full filling
job_title: Production Tech in Los Angeles, CA
pros: For regular staff employee it is good. After one year service, may transfer providing there are openings. Extended education is offered. Being part of public recognition is good as well as invites to some company activities.
cons: Even though there is a company policy manual, it is not supplied and/or told where to find it. It is just stated that it exist. If I knew about such policy prior, I should call HR a lot sooner on some problem in our department. At least my remaining fellows now have their own copy.

review_title: The experience of a lifetime is a career with an organization that brings smiles to millions around the world everyday.
pros: The best reason to work at Disney Studios is the opportunity to work with people everyday whose passion for what they do is a shared experience.  The Disney cast members are the people who carry the torch and ensure that Disney's innovation and excellence in entertainment lives on.  This excellence can be the experience of an adrenaline rush from a roller coaster ride to the action on the big screen.  Everyday, someone, somewhere is being touched by a Disney brand.
cons: A commitment and dedication to hard work is a given, and the rewards are immeasurable.

pros: The networking opportunity that the college program offers is irreplaceable. The value that the program adds to your resume grants you opportunities no other company can. This is an internship where you live, learn and earn within the happiest place on earth.
cons: The general treatment of college program participants varies from specific work location, but overall the college program participants get the bottom end of the shifts, often the closing ones. Some full time and part time cast members treat college program participants like dirt.

pros: Benefits. The ability to go to the Parks and all the discounts you receive. Disney is opening its own health care facility for its employees and families in the Orlando area. This center will be open 7 days a week and a real nice convenience for employees to use their health care dollars.
cons: Bureaucracy as any large companies. It is all about 'relationships' in Disney. Mainly they recognize you as to who you know instead of what you know. Moving around within the company is easy, especially if you know people in the areas you want to move to. There is a big stigma about offending somebody even if you are trying to do the right thing,

pros: Disney fosters an incredibly creative environment that attracts top tier talent. The IP's are outstanding from the original Disney content to high-profile brands like Pixar, Marvel and Lucas.
cons: Bureaucracy and politics abound. This is a big ship with a lot of infrastructure and competition at the top level for power and control. This all trickles down. Given size of the company and the myriad market interests, changes can take a long time to be visible.

pros: Good health and dentist benefits
cons:
CRM marketing team is constantly outsourcing to agencies and not allowing in-house creativity or innovation.
Old school 'safe' marketing that is ineffective and behind the times.
The output is PowerPoint presentation and no substance, no sign of meaningful kpi analysis or value to the company. The culture within Disney, sadly allows and encourages this and it us accepted as normsl. No one is free to challenge or improve, you simply do what has been done before. If you want to improve and progress, this isn't the right environment.
HR team are scared of senior management.

review_title: Disney is a great place to work and learn.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Disney is a solid company from on-boarding to training.  The benefits to working for Disney are numerous.  There are many opportunities to train and build new skills.  There are many different divisions to transfer to if you can not get a promotion through your current division.
cons: Disney being a large organization means that it can be very top heavy.  There are over 1,600 people with the title VP or better.  Many have been there several years and do not work as hard at there job.

pros: As a former character performer, the thing I enjoyed most was the opportunity to have a meet and greet with the "Make A Wish" children. In addition to this, I also found the opportunity to meet people from all over the world and work alongside them rewarding and exciting.
cons: Disney is known for the magic it brings, however working there it became clear early on Walt's dream was not being well kept up. Rather than enjoying time with each guest, as a character performer, it was more about getting through the line of guests as quick as possible.

pros: great learning experience.  many opportunities to learn from senior executives. Disney has the best products and many fun perks like park admissions and movie screenings, etc.
cons: long hours are expected in legal. there isn't much chance for promotions. most young lawyers leave for higher salaries for the same work elsewhere.  lawyers don't seem valued, only creative types but the lawyers are necessary and it doesn't make sense to train them and then have them leave for another studio.

pros: Good atmosphere, great and nice people, good benefits, looks excellent on resume. When i was applying for other jobs, due to lack of advancement I had many people call back because of Disney on the resume. Its a great resume builder. Company is family oriented, not high paced, well relaxed, business casual. Good parties, some lunches paid for.  Not really cut throat, if you show up and interact with people you will do very well. Company is very social.  A lot of family people work for the company, fairly young. Learned a lot from other people. Lots of fun, not difficult to do well.
cons: Not competitive, hard to advance, no accountability.

review_title: Disney - a pretty good place to work (unless it's one of the parks ... i couldn't imagine
job_title: Web Producer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: looks good on a resume. also, tons of other divisions to move to once you get bored with where you are.
cons: rarely promote from within. corporate and overly politically correct mentality reduces directness and results in a loss of common sense. also, politics - if a higher-up doesn't like you, you'll know.

job_title: Disney.com Games Production Manager in Burbank, CA
pros: The name will get you in the door at other places guaranteed. Some of the people are really talented and you can form great connections at the company. It is also a large company so you get to experience seeral aspects of the entertainment business.
cons: I would say the management sometimes overlooks the staff and getting noticed becomes a political matter. In other words, the culture forces you to get more political than needed, if only managers would notice who actually does the work.

review_title: You don't have a Magical day
pros: Great to have on your resume
cons: Need to to be able to play "the game" and be comfortable with office politics, kill or be killed politics exist between many of the departments. Can be very difficult to advance because of this. Inadequate management that hurts the employees and culture overall. Not competitive in Salary. Disney is notorious for underpaying employees. Not good at work/life balance.

pros: Great people, at all levels. Fun product to be a part of and the legacy it implies.  Successful folks go in with some experience and focus on what they want to do. If you've got that, the place can be fantastic to network and develop your career another step forward.
cons: This is not the place to come if your are unsure or looking for something to help you decide. People are stretched pretty far, no time.  Politics are rampant due to overall insecurity. Crazy making.

pros: Great benefits, most holidays off, theme park admission (except when blacked out) .Lots of mandatory overtime. Shift bids based on seniority.
cons: Very stressful. The members are very demanding, but this would not be as big a concern if you did not have to deal with the leaders hovering over you while you are trying to work. Extreme micro management. It seems like they set you up to fail instead of succeed.

pros:
The Company is good and gives all the freedom to Employee, but that depends on your manager. If your manager is good then you will love the job.

Awesome HR policy and good benefits.
cons: Bad Manager may not allow you to work freely. There are departments where Husband and Wife are working in same department because they have good connection with the associate director. This is against company's policy yet it is being allowed just because they have a strong bond with their respective Associate Director.

pros: Working for a fortune 100 company is a great experience and will teach you how to handle being a fish in a large sea of cast members. It looks great on resumes.
cons: Don't forget that you are just an intern and that you will not be getting paid. You have to be ready to work, just because you're working for Disney doesn't mean that it's all fun and games. I saw a lot of ppl get burnt out that way, but as someone who loves to work to achieve goals, I enjoyed it a lot.

pros: Great company with various lines of businesses for one to explore, learn and grow. Many of the individuals who work here are so creative, smart, and very strategic. Company culture is positive, uplifting, and professional. There are structures and processes in place that create balance and stability, but the company isn't too uptight where it feels overly stuffy and conservative. Also great benefits and discounts available for all 'cast members'.
cons: They can really only promote if headcount is available which can make it very difficult for someone who wants to be on the fast track in being promoted and elevating their role every 2-3 years.

review_title: We are part of the 'magic'...We work hard to make people smile around the world!
pros: Brand recognition...! No matter where I have been in the world - when I say I work for Disney people's eyes light up! Disney also creates the very best entertainment in the world - bar none. We are part of the 'magic' that is The Walt Disney Company. Also, people at Disney are very smart and very bright.
cons: We work VERY hard! Limited resources for the increasing volume of work. Very hierarchical company with many layers of management. Very passive-aggressive culture. However, with that said, I have worked at Disney for many years and it is an amazing company.

review_title: Brand recognition where few companies can match the scale, but, internal politics are horrible
pros: ESPN, Disney, ABC, ABCNews, the brand recognition.  There are few companies that have the scalability issues that Disney has because it's a massive media company.
cons: The brands are awesome and it's incredible to be associated with these brands.  The upper level management is horrible.  They don't watch after anyone but themselves.  It's a CYA kind of environment.  There's no accountability for anything that you do.  There's no autonomy to do any work.  It's a great place to get some experience, but, certainly not a place to work a long period of time in.

review_title: The place could be so much more.  Forget the stockholders and make movies
pros:
They hire some o the best in their field.  The people are great.  You don't have to spend a lot of time in a social situation explaining where you work.
You get a pass to Disneyland
cons: The politics here are difficult.  I truly wish one could find the right job in a company this size.  Unfortunately you can get stuck in the wrong place.  Ask for a good salary up front.  It may take a while to get to where you want to be.

review_title: a magical place that sadly doesn't pay enough
job_title: Lobby Concierge/Cashier in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: I truly enjoy my job. There are some great perks too, like almost unlimited free admission to the Disney parks for yourself and a limited number of free admission passes to get family/friends in. You also get discounts on merchandise, food, resort stays, and cruises. I moved up pretty quickly my first two years with the company but then I pretty much plateaued because they company wasn't holding anymore of the training courses I needed in order to get promoted. The health coverage options are really great too.
cons: You work early mornings, late nights, weekends, and holidays and the pay is barely enough to get by.

review_title: An amazing work environment, but hard for those looking to move up.
pros: The company culture is exactly how you'd imagine Disney to be, on the whole people are very friendly and positive. There are great perks like park entry, company events, or free screenings of movies (great for families). There's an all right work-life balance, depending on when your department's busy season occurs. Education and volunteering is strongly encouraged and it's simple to get involved and participate in those activities.
cons: Like others have said, moving upward in your career is a waiting game and it's easy to stay in the same position for a long time. Internal company website is hard to navigate. Some managers may have unreasonable expectations contingent on how down-to-earth they are.

job_title: Software Development Engineer In Test in Seattle, WA
pros:
Work life balance
Great team members - smart, helpful!
Scrum team
Worked on awesome technology
Really felt like I was contributing to Disney.
cons:
Wanted to convert to full time,  but there were no openings.
Other team that we collaborated with had no QA staff.
For a while I was working with an SDE.  This was great... I could code, he would do the manual tests and releases.  Then we couldn't replace him.
They did not have budget to replace my headcount, so they will not have QA for a while.

pros: This is a great company to work for - people are proud to work here and are smart and driven.  It's exciting to be a part of what this company does and, if you work hard and are savvy about how to work well with others, you can have a lot of success and growth.  There's also a good amount of flexibility, depending on who you work for.
cons: You need to be politically savvy and manage through a lot of consensus building.  The company can take time to socialize and make decisions.  The hours can also be long.

pros: You get to get into the park for free, and half off of hotels! You get to meet amazing people and have great experiences.
cons: If you are working in the parks or resorts moving up is very slow. Management prefers to pick people who are their favorites and not who are qualified. Polices and safety rules are greatly changing and simple things that you do off the clock are considered "horse play."  This is a great job for someone who is just finishing college or needs to have another way to pay for school. Would not consider this for a life long career.

pros: It is definitely a very fun place to work and there are so many branches in the company that you can probably find a job anywhere within the company that apply to your interests.  You get good benefits so this is great for those that have a family.  In the corporate setting, I have not heard of many 'lay offs' so job security is good.  They have great educational benefits and pay for your school granted you submit your application on time.
cons: Because the company is so big and it is not a software company - Disney's pay is mediocre.

review_title: Disney is a great place to learn 21st century media company management.
pros: It's the best place to learn how today's media/entertainment corporations really work from a stable industry leader that has mastered the art of synergy and strategic development of intellectual property for emerging media.  Disney also develops emerging media platforms, brings bleeding edge technology to our movies, web presence and theme park guests.
cons: Navigating the corporate landscape isn't for everyone.  Knowledge of the politics of entertainment is key.  It's not daunting or unmanageable but long term employees practice a high degree of workplace savvy in order to have the career paths they are passionate about.

pros: Some truly excellent employees. Decent opportunities for training. Flexible hours, casual dress code, free snacks and sodas. Great place if you are not concerned with career or responsibility advancement; lower-level tasks are often clear and simple.
cons: Underperforming upper management that is disassociated with employees. Poor communication between departments. Useless middle management. Very few opportunities to shine or create positive change in the organization. Rarely rewards high performers.

review_title: Great family feel, but not the best salary.
pros: There is opportunity for advancement as a manager to those who do not have a college degree.  Great team building and support system with the Disney way of conducting work as well as great benefits and perks for employees such as park passes and discounts.
cons: I have worked in the Entertainment department for 15 years but the company won't let me bridge my years of service because I dropped to seasonal status for a short period of time. However, if I had quit the company entirely and got hired back I could bridge my years of service. Also, the pay is not good when compared to the job/workload and comparable positions.

review_title: Great Company, Great Benefits, Chintzy on Pay
pros: Disney is a fantastic company that offers a lot of opportunity, benefits (Healthcare, shmealthcare...who doesn't like going to Disneyland?!?), and support.  It is a warm, inviting, and encouraging environment.
cons: Their pay structure leaves a lot to be desired.  Disney Interactive specifically is looking for Silicon Valley-caliber talent while paying Midwest wages.

pros:
Big money for Servers, Little kids love it, Great benefits-- getting into the park, discounts
Very good co-workers, work hard party hard lifestyle
Managers care even if they do not know what they are doing sometimes. 
very cool experience for younger people.
meet people from around the world in orlando and get to know different cultures
cons:
You don't have much control over your schedule. Very hard to go from part time to full time. There are virtually no benefits for part timers
Long 12 hour days, There are sometimes 'mandatory' late opens that you are informed about right before close

pros: Experience at a world-class marketing company, learning to work with whiny 'creative' types, exposure to some of the best (and worst) executives, fantastic resume builder
cons: Highest average deviation of competence I've ever seen.  From top to bottom, Disney employs some of the most talented people I've ever met, and some of the least qualified as well

pros:
Working for a well known company is fun. People's eyes light up when you tell them you work for Disney, then glaze over as you describe what you do.

Weekly Paycheck
cons: The benefits and vacation are sub-par compared to most software companies in the Seattle area. Management is pulled in many directions due mostly to the view that technology is a cost center rather than a business driver.

pros: Everyday, working for Disney was a new and fun experience. Interacting with guests is so much fun and almost too easy at times. EX; What's your favorite ride, favorite character, movie, etc. There is never a dull moment interacting with guests at Disney, and this is what keeps bringing guests back on a yearly basis.
cons: The biggest downside is the pay. But if you work for Disney,  you aren't working there for the wage, you are there for the magical experience that you get to bring to guests on a daily basis.

pros: Meh - experience is a good thing and Disney is good on the resume
cons:
Meh - the work environment can go from good to bad in an instant with the expectation that everyone will become a stepford "This is the Happiest Place On Earth" robot...

be prepared to check your brain at the door or suffer for thinking and having a point of view to help the moral of the company and ultimatley the experience of the employees....SAD!!!

review_title: Very fun place to work, awesome experience to work in a place I loved.
pros: Great benefits (who says no to free admission to Disneyland/Walt Disney World), discounts on merchandise and food, you play where you work and work where you play
cons: The point system is very unforgiving in Disneyland, Walt Disney World is much more forgiving as they don't weight them as high as Disneyland

review_title: Great Place to Learn and Move On
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: It was a great place to learn what it's like to work with world class IP and amazingly smart people in a massive, global company. Spending a few years there was like earning a Stanford MBA. The perks and benefits are second to none, but don't let those things charm you into losing focus on what really matters.
cons: It was difficult working with "acquired" executives because they were only focused on self-preservation (to buy time until their contracts vested) as opposed to innovating and contributing to the Disney legacy. The senior management landscape is extremely political and treacherous. Management only really cared about profit and therefore missed out on some big opportunities to create beloved and evergreen products.

pros: Autonomy if you want it. Leadership courses. Many resources at your disposal. Ability to move around the company and learn many disciplines. No shortage of opportunities for development. Stock options make up for the low salary in good market.
cons: Salary quite low, hours quite long. Sometimes teams can be understaffed to the detriment of the business. Promotions quite difficult and often not commensurate with work and accomplishments. Nearly impossible to own a win which is a pro and con as it highlights teamwork but makes it difficult to reward individuals.

job_title: Guest Relations Cast Member in Anaheim, CA
pros: Guest relations allows you to have some amazing interactions with guests along with the ability to provide them with anything they may need. If you are passionate about Disney this is a great place to work.
cons: Some of the tough things about this job is that guests may not always be the friendliest people. It can be very difficult to deal with some concerns, and partnering up with other cast members is sometimes necessary to ensure the best possible outcome.

review_title: Been an excellent employer, future now unclear
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent work life balance. Excellent colleagues. The company seems committed to serving its customers well, so you can be proud to work there. Very little politics. Most managers willing to let technical staff drive technical decisions.
cons: Manager quality can vary; some are excellent, but some are mediocre. Pay is okay but not top notch... some attrition to better paying area companies. The recent reorganization has hurt morale. People are unclear on the company's commitment to the Seattle office and its products.

review_title: Once great and very promising; doomed to failure under current senior management
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Hollywood, CA
pros:
Working with great people on world-renowned intellectual properties
Excellent company-wide benefits in a wide variety of areas
Prestige of association with a world-class company
cons:
Senior management that does not value Disney culture, brands and passion
Overly complex technology, some based on decade-old legacy systems
Bureaucratic processes that require extra time and effort to accomplish routine objectives
Asking too few people to do too many things and have too much responsibility
Group is the "stepchild" of Disney and is not respected by many other business units

pros: A very fun and satisfying job. Plenty of excellent perks including free admission to any Disney park in the world (except Tokyo) and plenty of discounts off other travel opportunities in the Walt Disney company. Guest Relations is the face of the Disneyland Resort and comes with a sense of pride along with it.
cons: Job at time can be demanding mentally. Guest Relations has to deal with guests who are demanding and can be extremely rude towards you. The pay at $11.60/hour is another con as well but you know very well going into the job your pay.

pros: Great Opportunities, to make magic for others. meeting new people all the time.
cons:
When it comes to guest Disney is unparalleled, unless your an employee  then is when the disney smiles fade,
and employees are treated like machines. Lack of compassion toward its employees. 
your are seen as a number rather than a person. Managers have a false sense of respect for you , and have 
 been known to professionally Sabotage ones reputation if they don't  like you!

job_title: Learning and Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: Extremely smart people to work with and you will learn a lot.  People have pride in the company.
cons: It's a hierarchy of leadership and as a leader you are not  empowered to make decisions and act.  Everything must go "up the flagpole" for approval.  Subordinates must flex their communication style to their bosses in order to be "heard". There is also a widespread feeling over the last 2 years that jobs are not secure.  And most recently actual downsizing is occurring.

review_title: Met a lot of awesome people from all around the world.
pros: You got to meet a lot of great people working for this company and I'll never forget the awesome experiences that I had working at Disney, I would differently go back.
cons: When things started to get worse in our region, everyone started to leave because no one wanted to put up with the people that were left. Also, recreation is a very tightly knit group and rumors like to spread a lot, so be careful.

pros: You get to work on some pretty cool properties.  Good health benefits and free tickets to their parks.  Access to some good training materials.
cons: It is a big company with lots of red tape for working with all those awesome properties.  They aren't willing to take risks.  Safe bets are the only bets they make.  Creativity is great, so long as it fits within the red tape and is a safe bet.

pros: Good company, great benefits.  Fast pace environment with lots of great opportunities to excel.  Follow ITIL methodology and currently using service now for CMDB.
cons: Lack of executive direction.  Very political and most leaders are managing up.  Large push to move everything to the cloud and outsource all IT services to India based companies.  Disney like all companies are about the money

pros: Big company with a lot to learn if you take the initiative. All the 5 business units have a separate culture which is good and bad. Looks good on resume.
cons: Need to to be able to play "the game" and be comfortable with office politics. Not much management training is available which leads to inadequate management and hurts the employees and culture overall. Not competitive in Salary. Disney is notorious for underpaying employees.

review_title: Great company but things get lost in all the changes
job_title: Lead Game Services Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Surrounded by intelligent and creative people and the Disney enthusiasm is a strong presence. Great benefits and ability to make a lot of connections within Disney.
cons: Due to bad decisions from higher up, lack of knowledge between departments and products, people and opportunities for promotions/recognition are often severely delayed or lost in the shuffle completely. The strict structure for promotion unless you are in the higher ranks already is detrimental to morale.

job_title: Reservation Agent, Vacation Planner in Anaheim, CA
pros: They offer you free trips to San diego zoo,Sea World and some vendors bring in lunch
cons:
High stress,High turn over.If you are not a good seller do not take! If you are in the bottom 20 twice you will be separated from company! If you have 1 disciplinary  even for dress code or bottom 20  say bye bye to that raise that is actually call a cost of living pay! transferred from Disneyland they get their cost of living increase no matter what!if you get a new phone system train everyone don't hand out a sheet of how too!
Phone system sucks if you are not doing well in sells  Document any problems and send to home email!They will try to get rid of you with out proof you could possibility lose out on Un Employment

job_title: Vendor(Foods)/Coordinator/Front Desk Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: The incentives and discounts are great. Local apartment complexes offer discounts for monthly rent for Disney employees. This helps balance outt he lack of stellar pay. Many discounts given that makes smaller salary offered compared similar/same jobs at other companies somewhat acceptable.
cons: Disney seems to have habit of listing many jobs as part time even though they're actually full time and requires full time availability. This is common practice with them even for professional experienced level jobs depending on position. In a month 3/4 weeks I would work 40 hours and then the other week I'd cap out at 30 hours.

pros: Disney discounts, Disney Parks pass, opportunity for growth, no formal dress code (would say “smart casual” to “business casual”)
cons: Blockout dates on park entrance, has problems of any large company

pros: My team especially was great. Love company events, general attitude with workers across the field, great exposure to different parts of the business depending on your team.
cons: If hourly, worked overtime with no overpay as standard. Bonus are standard and not based on merit. Leadership teams aren't trained to do actual work (Im talking about the even the lower management). Boys Club, so beware little girls, especially interns.

pros: The opportunities within such a large organization are endless, between divisions, and even across disciplines. Its fun to contribute to well respected entertainment experiences, and you get to work alongside some pretty neat teammates and partners.
cons: As with any large company, there is a lot of red tape and procedural burdens. In general, but not in every case, the price you pay for the stability of a career within a well established company is a lower salary than you may get at a start-up or elsewhere perhaps.  We run scared of liability too much, both in terms of our consumer facing products and services, as well as our own internal practices and programs.

review_title: The Walt Disney Studios is and innovative and creative place to grow a career in the Entertainment Industry
pros: It is a positive work environment that fosters creativity, innovative use of technologies, and has a strong leadership team.  It also creates very positive family oriented entertainment products.
cons: This isn't really a downside... simply a comment... The Walt Disney Studios, and most of the businesses across Disney expect a lot from their staff members... the hours are long, expectations for performance are high, and the tolarance for mediocracy is low.

review_title: Great company to work for with good perks and great brand recognition.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Glendale, CA
pros: Ample training budget, company will pay for relocation expenses, and Disney perks are great for a family. There are several segments to the business and it depends on which segment you work in as to how happy you'll be. They're all different and feel like separate companies at times.
cons: Pay is lower than working for a start-up. Disney legal is very strict about what you can/can't say about what you've accomplished while working for Disney. I would like to contribute back to the community on open source projects and that is very hard to do.

review_title: Being on the frontline to make magic
job_title: Attractions Host in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Make magic to everyone. Other cast members are great to work with. Lots of Disney perks for yourself and friends and family.
cons: Hours can be hard to come by for part-timers, unless you have been there for quite some time. Not paid enough for the hardwork that you do. Job can be strenuous: working outside, dealing with unruly guests, no consistency between management. Hard to move up in the company unless you are willing to transfer around and sacrificing seniority.

pros:
-Steady and reliable work and paychecks. 
-Decent union protections keep horrible management at bay for the most part.
-I met some of my closest on the job friends here. People I still keep in touch with after moving out of state. There are some really great people working there.
cons:
- Below scale pay for profession.
- HORRIBLE working culture that is exploitative and predatory. This is primarily the fault of bloated middle management creating an environment of competition for good assignments instead of shared goals and creativity. 
- Predominate culture of "You should be grateful for this wonderful job..."
- You have to drink the disney Koolaid to not be driven mad by the cult like atmosphere.

pros: The only benefit of the company is recieving complimentary admission to Disney theme parks.
cons: There is a lot of favoritism that goes on in this company. No one even tries to hide it. The more work you are responsible for the less credit you recieve. It's really hard to get promotions and raises unless you are your manager's favorite employee.

review_title: Started off with some great opportunities, went south with constant layoffs
pros: I enjoyed working there with amazingly talented people. I found that I was able to grow when I showed interest in building a career.  Of course Disney has some wonderful benefits too.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs sent top talent packing and left many including myself unable to advance. Not knowing if your job was going to be there every 90 days made it difficult to live a life.

pros: Benefits like access to the Parks.  If you are full time , it has excellent benefits
cons: When you work Part time  during  slow season, good luck getting hours.. I feel you have to beg   management for hours or you have to constantly look on their website for available hours, very stressful when you have to pay bills with no  work available  in sight.

pros: Disney/ABC is a great brand.  Who wouldn't be proud to be a part of something so highly regarded?
cons: There are a lot of old-school ideas and people who have been in the same jobs for many, many years... the thinking isn't particularly progressive or exciting.  Things are done a certain way because that is how they've always been done.  There is a lot of hierarchy.

review_title: Magical Experience; Pay Could Be Better
job_title: Merchandise Host in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The interactions with the guests is the best part of this job. Working at Disney always put a smile on my face and the atmosphere in the parks was always so much fun. Having the power to put a smile on someone's face was always so rewarding.
cons: The pay is not the best. People don't work at Disney for the money, but it definitely should be better. If you are the sole provider of your family and working in an hourly, entry level role, you will need to work overtime on a consistent basis in order to make ends meet. There are always so many people wanting to work for Disney, the advancement opportunities come slowly.

review_title: Enjoyable yet Stressful in the Disney Store
pros: A fun environment. I always said that I got paid to sing Disney songs and play with kids. It's a very easy retail job, even with my title as manager. Good for people who are okay with always moving.
cons: Almost 0 opportunities to advance unless someone above leaves. I was lucky to get to where I was after years of being a part time cast member, but they pay was still so low that I couldn't sustain my life if I continued there. Also the people I worked with were frustrating. Some didn't want to work, others made little groups or cliques in order to cause drama almost as if we were still in high school.

review_title: Overall, a great company to work for
pros: The benefits at Disney are by far the best of any comapny I have ever worked for.  The prestige of working for a company as prestigious and diverse as Disney can go a long way with other career paths. I did have a personal situation arise that took me away from work and Disney responded quickly and fairly.
cons: One must start at an entry level position and the salary is not the best.  Based on current economic conditions, Disney is horing many quality employees which makes upward mobility with a 5 year time frame difficult at best.

pros: great work life balance, really nice down to earth people, free Disneyland entrance pass, pension, executive fitness stipend at director and above levels, pride of association with a great renowned brand, fun and interesting work
