cons: talent is amateur on the online side, the sites are pretty crappy and clunky, direction/strategy is unclear, promotions are mismanaged and nearly impossible unless you threaten to quit, base comp is severely under market, management does not do much to make employees feel valued, HR is not helpful, nearly impossible to fire people who are not competent

review_title: Creative people, good training, excellent benefits, great discounts
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Good training opportunities
Overall, great, creative people to work with (everyone seems to have a strong talent expressed outside the office - many with entertainment avocations) 
Excellent benefits
Disney VoluntEars offers many ways to donate your time and talents
Excellent discounts on parks admission, hotels, and merchandise
cons:
West Coast locations have more telecommuting opportunities than East Coast locations.
Some business units are a bit "silo-ed" amd would operate better with other units if there were more chances to encourage cross-departmental interaction.

review_title: Extremely fun but not necessarily a place to advance your career - unless you're In with the right people.
pros: Great benefits, super fun environment in a passionate and family friendly company.
cons: very cliquey, not particularly good at making fast decisions or cutting through red tape.  Is such a big company that its very very easy to get lost (in all senses).  I'm not convinced it's a place to grow your career - they didn't seem in a rush for anything.  Nor was there any encouragement to grow, develop or even question some practices (mainly around processes and how things are done)

job_title: Software Engineering Director in Glendale, CA
pros: The benefits are great. If you are a Disney fan, this can be Shangri-La.   The company is enormously profitable, and is willing to spend money to make money.  This is a very large company, and the different divisions can have very different characteristics - so it's quite possible to find a job that suits you somewhere.
cons: Large bureaucracy.  Most projects have a lot of stakeholders & gatekeepers.  A lot of long-time employees whose job is to maintain the status quo and say no.  It can take a long time to get simple things done.

review_title: The World Famous Disney College Program
job_title: Disney College Program in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros:
Great perks; as in nearly-unlimited access to the parks and guest tickets/big discounts for friends and family. 

Networking opportunities and the ability to move up to a professional internship heavily depend on your field of study - those with more technical degrees will have a better success rate than the liberal arts.
cons: Often treated very poorly by upper management and/or whoever does your scheduling. Over the course of my program, I was scheduled for anywhere from the minimum amount of hours to 60+ per week. Late closing shifts are the norm for college program kids.

pros: You get to schedule your own day.  You can break when you want as long as you can get your work done.  Allows you to spend as much time with guests as you want.  Best part of the job.
cons: Is a lot of outdoor work in the Florida sun.    If you struggle with stopping guests to ask questions, avoid this job at all costs.

pros:
A good company to work for and learn from especially if you're ready to invest yourself, you may not always feel that you get a return that is *proportional* to your investment, but you *do* get a sensible return nonetheless.

I'd especially advise it to anybody that is in love with the Disney brand !
cons: As always in big corporations there is some room for improvement regarding communication. There are inter-departmental management/communication/competition issues as well.

job_title: Manager, Corporate Communications in Burbank, CA
pros: There is an endless amount of opportunity within The Walt Disney Company and all of it's lines of business.  From Media Networks and the Studios to Parks and Resorts and Consumer Products, there are so many great people and great career paths to explore and pursue.
cons: Working at a company as large and complex as Disney can be a little bit intimidating at times, but I think learning how all the parts of the company work together and impact each other is an amazing experience and completely invaluable.

review_title: Over all, pretty good.  The pay is lower than other places, but the job security and Medical benefits are pretty good.
pros: I like a good challenge and my work delivers something new every day.  When I know my work is being seen all around the world it is a very satisfying feeling.
cons: Because of the lower pay here, they can only attract lower quality management.  The system set in place to evaluate employees is totally worthless and seems to have no effect on how people are promoted.

review_title: not at all what i expected
pros: The insurance (only optional for full time) is very cheap and pretty good. Getting in free saves a lot of money assuming you would be going to the park whether you work there or not.
cons: The hours are terrible, there is no flexibility when you need time off, the heat in Orlando is insane during the majority of the year, people treat you like crap because you're in an amusement park even if you're a college grad, the managers treat people like garbage, there is no communication, backstage facilities are terrible, scheduling is uncooperative, advancement is limited unless you're a serious ass kiss, and the pay is lousy on any scale under Area Manager.

review_title: The evil side of Disney movies is how it goes behind the scenes
pros: good for college grads, exposure to many systems, complicated architecture
cons: Not family friendly, suck every bit out of you they can, whatever you allow, politics rule, mgmt not qualified and mostly just robotic and terrible, puppets to higher management, pay stinks to start, company takes advantage of lack of competition of IT (they rule Orlando) work to treat workers poorly, they do not give you choice of what projects you work on, will ruin your skills if you let them by sticking you in place they need someone, then won't let you out as they do not want to train someone else.  Treat people over 50 horribly.  Really alot of evil behind the scenes.  Long-timers say company has gone continuously downhill in last 20 years as a good place to work.

pros: I could not have started my career at a better company.  I was allowed to carve out my own career path with the support of great mentors and coaches.  If you are a self-starter and willing to take on bigger responsibilities there are opportunities worldwide. You are allowed to take risks as long as you have a "Plan B" as backup. The combination of pay and benefits was just above market for the area I was working. The Compnay treats employees who travel a lot for business really nice. Love the Mouse
cons: If you want to advance, you have to live for the job.

review_title: An incredible experience that everyone should have.
pros: You are able to do things for people that you simply are not capable of doing in retail and service industries anywhere else. Giving away merchandise to make someone's day magical, working with disabled guests to make their vacation memorable, or assisting with Make a Wish Foundation to name a few.
cons: You are never paid well unless you break into the ranks of corporate or executive staff, but that's not why you are there.

pros:
Vastly creative and full of fun. Mission is to make people happy with games, apps, websites, etc.   Very high standards for users having magical experiences--everything had to work properly.

As part of the Walt Disney Corp, the benefits were outstanding. Amazing health insurance options, 401K matching, pensions, etc. And of course discounts for Disney products, and free access to theme parks.

Also, the corporation is very generous: encourages employees to volunteer time and energy, and to donate to less fortunate. Feels great to work for such a place.
cons:
Salaries are on the low side. (I took a rather large pay cut for my job.) Very small cost-of-living raises. For those whose jobs didn't include bonuses, the salary remained basically the same for as long as they stayed on.

Too many reorgs and layoffs. The high tech division went through massive changes, multiple times. Many people had more than 3 bosses in 5 years. Teams were often exploded, with most people let go. There is no way for other Disney teams or division to look up employees via skills, so it is extremely difficult to move to a different job within the company or the Disney corp.

Many of us had no career evolution available. So even if we didn't get laid off, there wasn't going to be any better future. For older folks who were satisfied with their salary and the benefits, that was okay. For younger people, who need to have a ladder to rise, this was disappointing, as there are many jobs that have no higher positions.

review_title: Great brands, products and people, but very poor company culture.
pros:
Amazing brands and products. Really good learnings and exposure and an invaluable asset for your CV.
Great colleagues to work with.
Good health and dental insurance, Disney store discount and free Disney Parks access.
cons:
Pretty poor company culture with junior employees overworked, under-payed, frustrated and with incredibly slow/almost impossible career progression.
Overall treats employees pretty poorly; in my 2+ years within the company I have never been offered a team lunch, and we even had to fund our own Christmas dinner/party, which it's unbelievable considering the strength and consistent success of the company over the years.
Pretty political and hierarchical management structure.

review_title: If you want to make a difference - go elsewhere - you'll be happier.
pros:
I agree with most of the comments submitted below. It is important to note that the Studio works and operates very different than other divisions. So, if you don't like one division, you may be happier in another division. 

1. You can't beat the IP The Walt Disney Company has.
2.  Pay and benefits (monetary) are decent if you are Sr. Manager and above. (But still not comparable to other large organizations such as Amazon, Google, etc.
cons:
1. Pay lots of $$ to hire a majority of their workforce via Accenture or EY, eventhough they end up botching projects, overpromising, under delivering, and leave the studio with the bag. All the while ignoring their own workforce employees, who actually have a vested interest in the business.
2. Don't bother to foster growth and learning amongst employees. Culture fosters apathy and resentment and complacency.
2. Do not attempt to bring in new ideas, or you will be labeled an outlier or disruptor. Most of the people who actually care and want to bring in good ideas often get alienated or worse, get put on terrible projects until they can no longer bear it.
3. Upward mobility is nearly impossible. The title you come in with is most likely the title you will keep. (Although their is no problem increasing workload while cutting staff)
4. The consensus is that in order to move up.. you have to first move out. So, I've decided to move on. Perhaps I'll be back another day.
5. Many executives of Director and above are complacent. They get large perks to stay but neglect to foster the growth of their teams, or to continue to grow, be innovative or work on making the culture the "Disney" culture that the public sees.
6. Very political. Restating what a previous employee said because it rings true, "Very heavy office politics come into play, and your opportunities for advancement are based largely on who you rub elbows with rather than the merit of your work. At the Director level and above, nepotism is rampant, you eventually find out that most of the heavy hitters come from the same companies. "
7. Very disorganized and siloed because of competing priorities (and nasty politics). There is no one clear voice, or mission. Although it is written on paper and in an email, the executives nor the staff truly honor it. So, it gets passed as just fluff.
8. Executives talk the talk. But don't walk the walk. Meaning, they talk about making progress, being innovative, having a great culture, providing and fostering growth. Yet, when tough decisions need to be made - they hide behind middle management. If all goes well, the executives win. If not, the executives don't own the responsibility and the middle manager loses his credibility or worse yet, his/her job.
9. Behind closed doors, females are undercut and looked down upon for "being too nice". If you are not a part of the "boys" club, forget it. 
10. If you have a family and are a mother, forget it (especially if you are Female). Expect to be looked down upon from most of the male (and oddly enough single female) executives. They expect you to work the same way as your single counterpart, otherwise, your big projects get taken away, and like #2, you get put on horrible projects until you are forced to leave.
11. HR is corrupt in Disney Studio. There have been many complaints of harassment from quite a few females and most have fallen on deaf ears, ignored, or again #2. Therefore, many females have opted to leave because there is no recourse.

review_title: You won't get rich working at Disney, but it's still a great resume builder.
job_title: Finance Manager in New York, NY
pros: reputation of the company. free entrance to all parks. discounted resorts. generally happy people. company is doing great under Iger, performance of company is great. paid every week. automatic cost of living increases.
cons: slow to promote. slow to do anything. no bonuses until director level. not very generous regarding compensation. lack of a formal review process.

review_title: TImes Square store pays good compared to other NYC retail stores. Great place to work
pros: Being a Disney cast member looks great on any resume. You will have the ultimate customer service experience and fast pace ethic (in this store in particular). Great schedule flexibility.
cons: More selling involved compared to Walt Disney World (they usually do not allow selling strategies). If you are expecting a full time position, do not expect it in the beginning. Word of advice: They will usually schedule you for 4-5 hour shifts. Over that, I personally would get a little tired of it so if you prefer this as a part-time, make sure your availability limits it to that.

review_title: Disney India used to be a great place, but no more
pros:
Great brand
Slightly better than average industry salaries
Good exposure if you are able to network with counterparts outside India
Post acquisition of UTV, new brands beyond kids and families
Great Studio presence and hit movie slate
cons:
Office culture lacks support for innovation and diversity
Day to day work is ridden with politics in the India office
Internal networking is important for career growth
Very little connect with global post acquisition of UTV
HR processes are not transparent
There is no parity between global and local positions, designations and roles
No work-life balance. Employees are expected to respond to e-mail and requests even when its not critical beyond work hours or on holidays

review_title: Truly Great Company to Work For
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Great benefits, amazing perks, supportive leadership, magical corporate culture, true sense of being valued, respected & empowered
cons: Pay is not great (but the perks/benefits can make up for this depending on your situation). Like any large company there can be bad apples (both co-workers and leaders), policies you disagree with from time to time, day to day job frustrations, and it is a business so there is still work to be done despite the temptations of fun to had

pros: Complimentary admission, good discounts, good opportunity for income in tipped roles, supportive management, fun atmosphere, many company sponsored treats and perks.
cons: Part time employees are stretched as far as possible without giving any vacation, sick leave benefits.

pros:
• Work-Life balance 
• Excellent sense of team work as it is embedded within the culture of the company 
• Outstanding perks
• The company prides itself of the employees 
• True sense of diversity 
• Excellent projects 
• Family feeling 
• Disneyland (parks) Silver Pass; it deserves its own entry in addition to the perks entry above
cons:
• Limited and slow growth 
• A bit bureaucratic 
• Despite the good pay; it's not the highest in the industry 
• Things take much longer to get done
• Lousiest IT support

review_title: Apply now to varnish the Titanic's deck chairs...
pros: Being part of the Walt Disney Company has some clear appeal and upside, and having a chance to create great product that will be welcomed by a worldwide audience is an unique opportunity.
cons: Unfortunately, this part of the company is roadkill compared to the Parks, ESPN, Pixar, etc. such that the leadership team isn't staffed with the sharpest tools in the shed, and at the top-level of the company they have bigger fish to fry than worrying about what sort of madness might be going on here.

review_title: A churning mill which, while putting out great products, tends to not care about the employee.
pros:
Quality product and brand.
Wonderful teams of people who are invested in their projects.
cons:
Constant contracting of employees to questionable levels.
Starting out employees as "interns" and continuing this "internship" as legally possible.
Moving employees to "contract" for as long as legally possible and avoiding hiring on people.

review_title:
No chance for career development
No chance for increasing salary
pros:
Offer good medical coverage insurance for all employees
On time payment
cons:
No development career based on professional achievements
No training for employees since 3 years ago
No international possibilities
No local empowerment
No clear information about salaries for positions
Part time requests due to maternity are penalized with no further development career
No enough qualiffied Senior Management
Promotions and recognitions are very limited and sometimes the way they are given is not very fair or at least clear. A lot of managers were promoted tiem ago just based on the time that had been working there, but not because their achievemnets or contributions. This has created a very bad management team in some cases.

Salary is not very good either compared to its competitors in Spain.

pros: Great benefits, main entrance pass and a company that overall exceeds expectations.  Some businesses are better than others.
cons: I expected a corporate environment but the politics are more challenging than expected.  I believe the success of the company contributes to a culture where people are afraid to say no.  While failure is not an option, nor should it be, I've seen management overpromise and then throw their people under the bus when it was impossible for them to deliver.  Avoid certain areas of corporate until the leadership is held accountable for their underperformance.

review_title: Good company perks but strange culture
pros: People leave work generally on time, summer hours, perks like free entry to the parks, cheap cinema tickets, on-site cinema, good health benefits, international environment, enough work for everyone.
cons: Heavily cliquey culture. Hierarchical, autonomy is limited, change is not welcomed. It would seem that many people work there for the sake of the brand and not the work offered. Large company means lots of red-tape and the 'Disney way' is often quoted when you offer solutions or approaches not tried before. Unorganised, chaotic, lack of structure, overcomplicated and onerous processes. Management can be non-committal and invest little in their direct reports, lack of ownership and accountability, not many development opportunities. Not results-driven.

pros: Disney is a great company to work for mainly because of the Brand.  Everyone knows your company and is interesting in discussing it.  The perks are ok as well with the parks and discounts.
cons: Maybe this is specific to my department but the hours normally are pretty long.  Also, it is difficult to understand where I am in regards to recieving a promotion.  I've noticed that those who get promoted are those with supportive managers and some managers promote more than other managers

review_title: Mentally exhausting. Long hours. But hey it's Disney? ... No it's ABC
pros:
Just like most reviews, you get free park entry. Most employees are ok to work with. Pretty good benefits. It's ok.

If your young and want to spend 95% of your time at work, this job is what your looking for. You have as much work as you can handle and more. You'll be a robot in no time.
cons:
If your a person that wants or needs a good work/life balance and wants to be able to have input on projects this place is not for you. 

Management uses mentally exhausting and demeaning tactics.


Just think hard about accepting, do your research.

review_title: Work Hard to Get to Play Hard
job_title: QSR Food & Beverage Cast Member in Orlando, FL
pros: It is not an easy job and can be stressful at times (dealing with thousands of guests a day),  but the feeling is indescribable. I felt like I was making a difference in my guests' lives. My fellow cast members were amazing and the benefits certainly outweigh any cons.
cons:
Sometimes management felt disconnected from the other cast members, as if they have forgotten what it is like to be hourly. Not all managers - perhaps 3 out of the 5 I had at my location and role.
Hours were harsh, but that is to be expected.

review_title: Guest Services Representative II (Disneystore.com Call Center)
pros: Slightly fun atmosphere. Opportunity to learn good office skills. An abundance of experience to gain from the many lateral movements and cross-training offered. Health, Dental, and Vision is also a plus. Free park admission is always nice.
cons: Being a call center based in Memphis, the pay could use a boost. There are many call centers in the surrounding area that offer starting positions that pay almost $2/hr more. There is NO room for advancement...only lateral moves. Leadership creates positions for who they want, not who deserves.

job_title: Fantasyland Merchandise Coordinator in Orlando, FL
pros: It is a fun atmosphere to work in and the other Cast Members a friends who will be apart of your life forever. Its a great place for your first job or if you only need to be part time.
cons: You work long hours and are underpaid for the work that you do, you can move up in the company, but it isn't easy to do, you need a lot of experience. Also you do not get major holidays off even if you request it's not a guarantee.

review_title: Old untalented industry veterans in management making bad calls.
job_title: 3D Artist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are some very talented traditional artists. The cost of living in Salt Lake is fairly cheap. The lower level employees are very fun to work with.
cons: Bad pay, management, and no room to grow. There are artists that have worked at the company for 10+ years that have not been promoted to a senior level. Making movie title games can be very uninspiring. The employees that take the crap and refuse to leave only do so because they want to live in Utah.

job_title: Entertainment in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros:
It's a brilliant place to work, full of some of the nicest people and most amazing entertainment technology.
Disney training will stay with you for life and can help you get jobs afterward.
cons: Low pay, hard work and hard hours. For a company that promotes family values on the surface, they would do well to treat their Cast Members better and pay them a living wage.

pros: Relatively stable company with good perks and salaries.  The Disney name opens doors in your career and when dealing with other companies.  Good vacation, bonuses, and other perks.
cons: Every department is its own Magic Kingdom, with little communication.  Lots of poorly integrated divisions with conflicting goals interacting with each other.  You will spend as much time maneuvering inside the company as you will in the marketplace.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Awesome coworkers. Many people have worked here for over 10 years so you get to know them well. 
Good talent 
Cost of living is low in Utah
Free soda. 
If you're hourly, there's lots of overtime to cash in on.
cons:
A long time ago a group of people realized that their management had fragile egos and mediocre ability and thought, "hey we're mediocre and have fragile egos too" and thus avalanche software was born.

Cronyism is out of control.
Tons of talent to fill important roles but guess who gets promoted? So the good ones leave. 
No relevant work experience? No actual skills? Bad with people? No problem. We're buddies right?  Let's make you a senior director.
We've been losing the best talent for a while. Chased out by small people.  
But if you like brown nosing and stroking egos you'll go far. This place runs like a weird cult.

Most of the great people aren't in a position to make a difference
Outdated tools and technology. Just look at our game. 
Mediocre products with cherished characters = $$$. Why make a good game when a crappy one will do? 
Management isn't in it to make good games. Just a way to make tons of cash. 
Frustrating working on a game where they only want to make it good enough to fool people into buying it. 
Passive aggressive workplace. Don't be fooled by all the smiles and nice guy acts from senior leadership.  
Don't expect a big bonus. They have lied about bonuses many times to get people to work lots of overtime and then not delivered. 
There have been several families broken up from the stress of overtime 
Since upper managers are the only ones getting big payouts they never leave. 
There's no career opportunities.
Maybe good for an internship if you're starting out, but don't stick around for more than a few months. Just long enough to get it on your resume. Don't believe the promises.  I'd work on your code skills or demo-reel full-time instead of making a kids game that won't really open doors for you anywhere in the industry. Despite all the hype this game isn't respected by developers.
Lots of infighting and back biting in times of stress, which is almost the whole year. Teams attack each other because management is untouchable. No oversight. 
Yearly dev cycle is rough
Disney interactive shuts studios down left and right. With marvel and starwars out of the way...this product probably won't last much longer. layoffs around the corner.
Management takes the credit for all successes. They blame employees for their own bad ideas.
Incompetent managers are promoted. 
Repeat the same broken game making process every year. Nothing changes.

pros: It's a lot of Mess over here and over there, not too many things or places to poo at. They have very few toilets available.
cons: It's a lot of poo working here. Especially as a bus driver if you need to go poo your stuck with people on your bus and then you can't go unless you decide to go in the seat. We have few options to go to; plus they want you to call for permission only on the way back from a drop off. I'm sorry but my bowels are not controlled by my mind. Then you call and they say we already dispatched you can you go when you get back from the new dispatch. This could be 30-60 minutes later. Pending your bus doesn't break down or you get stuck in a resort that is blocked by another broken bus.

review_title: Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media
pros:
Good Disney perks like park passes and store discounts.
Fun morale events.
Nice office space with satisfactory equipment.
Willingness to spend money on tools to help accomplish longer term goals.
cons:
Remote executive oversight is intrusive and often at odds with product team needs/goals.
Health benefits are sub-standard for technology industry.
Failure to follow-through on needed and sometimes verbally promised promotions.

job_title: Marketing: Disney Streaming Services in New York, NY
pros:
Beloved character, timeless stories, the best in sports and major player in the future of video consumption.

Entry level will quickly learn basic digital marketing strategy and work alongside determined, smart and talented team members.

Office space is limited.

job_title: Senior Producer in North Hollywood, CA

Either way, management is terribly ineffective, and they take it out on competent employees so that their own incompetence doesn't shine through. Absolutely the worst job experience I've ever had -- and that includes the boss who threw staplers at me.

review_title: Align with a mentor/champion within your first 6 months or leave

cons: Executive leadership is stale, as VPs and above rarely leave, and internal movement at the executive levels is limited. Internal networking is key, especially if you are not a diversity candidate.

review_title: The Walt Disney Company is a magical company
pros: Disney has great perks and compensation packages and allows employees to balance work-life duties. They take pride in having an educated and enthusiastic attitude towards employees and encourage new ideas.

review_title: This is a company you will be proud to be a part of

pros: An amazing Company with strong values and a drive to take care of their Cast Members! The Walt Disney Company is truly a dream come true! I look forward to my return with the greatest Company on Earth!

job_title: Bus Nanny in New Plymouth, Taranaki

job_title: Disney Reservation Center in Orlando, FL

review_title: Honestly an incredibly Toxic and Helpless Job
job_title: Motion Graphics Designer in Burbank, CA

cons: Management, Bias, Sexism, Continuous brushing off and pacifying if you go to your management when you have any large concerns, Supervisors, Toxic work environment,

pros: It is the company we expect them to be from a public eye. Conscientious, environmental, sustainable, global citizen, and awareness of their important role in the world. One can be extremely proud to be associated to such a company.
cons: The politics and money, like every company, can distort the individual's role and contribution. Also, where human capital is a chess board and sometimes dehumanized and sacrificed for the greater good.

pros: The insurance is decent, the facilities are great, you get to go to Disneyland for free and take three friends.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Dropping the company name at social events elevates one's status. It's going to look good when I leave to have worked there. Free Disney passes and stuff. It's TV! It's rare to have such a job at a major company.
cons: I want to go into great detail, but doing so would pinpoint me and I need the job for now, so I am going to be vague. There's a lot of Mad Men sexism, tolerated racism, incompetence and improper borderline harassment. Promised promotions that don't happen because the person who made the promise has mental issues.

pros: You feel great working to help members get dream vacations, the pixie dust , treats, Swag for kudos that come with the working for the company such as free passes and the ability to call Disney world home, the empowerment to help the guest. Management treats you well and tries their best to make youy feel valued.
cons: Pay to work ratio is low, it's hard to keep a family, be ready to struggle to make financial ends meet and not be able to keep a second job. Due to mandatory overtime, you are treated like an adult with great respect but the management created metrics to use as a tool to make you work like the system needs you to. Management has no control over changing the system because they fear rocking the boat and indifference is rampant throughout the company as a whole. Metrics take precedence over the service of great employees/ Guest Service. Many quit or transfer out  to avoid getting fired from their jobs due to these metrics (hence high turn over). Very few make it to a good retirement. Metrics are a form of micromanagement. Management could work harder to induce real change and motivate positive. Going to the bathroom got me points until I learned to work the system. Points that add up to getting you reprimands hence an opportunity to not get a raise. A feeling of you are replaceable and not important in the long run even though you are told your are essential to the operation and management treats you really well.

pros: Disney is an amazing media property to work on, and the company is good at getting developers the tools and capabilities they need to succeed.   And everyone loves a free pass to Disneyland.

review_title: Not bad but not the greatest
job_title: Senior Web Developer in Orlando, FL

pros: You can get very lost in the system, and remain unrecognized for years. Reviews are designed to enforce consistency, not to recognize and reward great productivity.  Longevity is guaranteed if you keep your head down.

pros:
vast and diverse technological environment, the company is in just about ever line of business

no shortage of interesting projects to work on

a great place to expand your technical knowledge

Lack of communication across different organizations within Disney leads to a major duplication of efforts

Executive/Senior management seems disconnected from Engineering staff 

Communication is hindered by an overabundance of collaboration tools

Salaries for the same positions outside of Disney are growing rapidly and HR department fails to acknowledge this, leads to high turnover

pros: Great diverse international company with a host of stellar franchises and hype properties; and the opportunity to meet people from across the globe. As relocation is encouraged, the company gives you the ability to work in many parts of the world

job_title: Disney Vacation Club Sales Guide in Lake Buena Vista, FL

That is no longer the case, managemen - including onsite as well as VP have turned this into regular time share. job_title: College Program Cast Member in Orlando, FL
pros: Park perks, fantastic co-workers, making people smile and kids believe in magic
cons: It is ALL about location- if you get placed at a bad location you'll have a bad time on your program. The job type also doesn't matter, I was custodial then retail, my friends were QSF&B. Custodial and QSF&B are the "worst" jobs but most of us had a great time, the issue is the leadership at specific work locations.

pros:
Incredibly diverse organization. Parks and Resorts gets to work with everything from business intelligence, machine learning, and predictive AI to e-commerce, guest experience, and once in a while... Mickey comes to work.

FTEs have some great perks and discounts so if you like the Disney Parks, that's huge.
cons:
There's a lot of churn here- particularly in the VP and above level. Some major initiatives take a couple years to get to fruition and it's not uncommon for leadership and priorities to change before a major effort is completed. 

Additionally, in the Seattle office, if you aren't a developer, there aren't very many opportunities for you.

review_title: Mostly positive, though there is some room for improvement
pros: Benefits -- though you pay into them, they offer pretty much all your standards and then there are free passess to the parks, deep discounts on Disney merchandise, things like that  Then, depending on which part of the company, VP's get a few more benefits -- annual physical (though your insurance generally covers this) and such. They also offer a ton of online courses on various business-related issues as well as in-person management training.
cons: They can get a little "review" crazy. At one point, we were doing employee reviews every six months. There isn't much on the con side.

review_title: It's not as magical as it looks like
pros: You can feel honored to work in the biggest entertainment company in history. It is a quite good company to work for. Employeed are very well treated. Even though salaries are not very high compering to other companies, the benefits are pretty good.
cons: In local markets in pretty hard to grow. In the US and UK markets opportunities come very often, instead. Strategies are pretty much designed by the regional teams, so not much to contribute in. You can feel frustrated as a professional, if you are the kind that curiosity and some ambition.

pros: Great benefits, opportunities for both personal & professional growth, strong brand, lots of diversity, ability to stay with one company but do multiple different jobs, easy to establish a network of people in all lines of business to help achieve goals, company culture ensures everyone develops excellent guest service skills, great internship programs for college students to start their careers
cons: Large corporation where you can sometimes feel completely replaceable, long work hours if you work within theme park operations or resort operations, being the company is so large it is hard to know all the answers to guest questions & you are taught to very say "I don't know"

pros: Good benefits, silver pass to resorts and parks, holiday pay and double time. Excellent commuter and public transportation incentive program. That's about it
cons: Voluntary lunch waiver which is actually not that voluntary. Low salary. Horrible office culture. Managers will throw you under bus literally if they could. Treatment and low morale of employees which is just depressing and doesn't make you want to stay long there. Thankless and boring job but that is the nature of broadcast network operations which are fully switched to automation now. Red tape i.e. need approval from 7 bosses to reboot your PC that just crashed.

pros: Its a great place to do what you love. Who doesn't like making kids and families happy! You feel as though you're making a difference when you know your product is safe for kids. The pay was good and so was the vacation and sick time.  They also have really good health benefits.
cons: It can be stressful at times, and it is hard to move up from the position  or department you entered into.

pros: You get to say you work at Disney.
cons: Upper management is constantly trying to figure out how to end your job there and give your  work to the lowest bidder in India so they can show a lower expense budget.  They aren't concerned with quality of work or helping the internal clients they work for. They look down on them. It's a hostile environment for years now.  Upper management is ONLY concerned with the bottom line and their bonuses for giving your job away.  If you drop dead working, that’s 1 less American salary to pay. Don't put yourself through it.

pros: Work-life balance is great. HR actually helps you handle problems with management and will help you to find a way to handle personal emergencies. The people there are ridiculously talented and hard-working. In-house lunch means you don't have to eat out if you don't want to.
cons: Management makes it very hard for everyone else to do their jobs. Ego and pride make it nearly impossible for management to admit they don't have any idea how something works and to let the professionals they've hired help them to understand it.

pros:
Great company overall, great respect for employee's work/life balance, great perks - many of which I pleasantly discovered along the way. Simply being hired seems to further open the already open floodgates of other companies trying to hire you when you work as a software engineer in California (LA area specifically). For single guys reading this, there is also a good amount of attractive girls and as long as eye candy isn't a negative distraction for you personally this can be a good thing.

Really nice campus and people, not a lot of negatives I can say about Disney. If you are interviewing with them or was offered a position...take it. Unless you have an established history of working with the world's largest companies and would need to do more research to see how Disney stacks up against them, then this will be an immediate "pro" that you will feel when it comes to the doors it opens if you are ever in a position where you have to look elsewhere for employment, and with all the constant layoffs that seem to be quarterly from my experience having the Disney name on your resume never hurts. Although most websites seem to say every 6 months, don't count on it being that long between layoffs. I don't mark the dates of every layoff we had since I started, to me it felt pretty much seasonal.
cons:
What seems to be quarterly/semi-annual layoffs is huge. I'm not sure if this is a coincidence but this also lead in some areas and to some degree a negative and delusional environment at times.

Negative in the sense that certain people seem to be so afraid of...whatever they are afraid of that they are willing to lie and throw others under the bus (via reasonable-doubt), than to take responsibility or get things done. Not to name names or specific projects but there was one example where team A failed to communicate something to team B and team B giving team A a failing grade on something they were asked to evaluate. This mis-communication was minor and affected little to nothing since the task would have been needed down the road when team A was actually ready for it, but the attitude in the resolving meeting was team A's manager coming in hot trying to put the blame on team B, team B correcting them and calmly explaining how there was no actual issue and that the work in question would simply be done when team A felt they were ready, then team A feeling relief and comfort once given the reality of the situation and assured that it wasn't a big deal or would be a negative mark on their team.

To help paint a better picture without naming names or projects, imagine a manager coming into a meeting visibly upset and on fire, tries to put the blame on team B, have team B easily and quickly shut this attempt down, then turns to his/her team and literally walks down the line trying to get someone to fall on their sword for a non-existent problem so that they take the blame (and thus gets it put on their performance review, which ultimately means you'll face losing your job depending on your manager's personal feelings about you), just to have the other side of the table point out that the "issue" is such a minor thing that no one was concerned about and simply wasn't a big deal. At that point the fired up manager, which was at fault for the actual miscommunication, shows a sigh of relief akin to someone about to lose their home to not paying their mortgage that just won the lottery. That is the type of "I will do anything to protect myself from admitting fault, even when the issue is simply in my head and is not a real thing, or is a real thing but not a big deal" that you might see. Others include using reasonable-doubt strats to flat out lie to put another person under the bus, even if that person never did what was said or the person saying it simply having no idea what they are talking about. And when this is proven or shown, don't expect it to matter if your manager doesn't seem to like or respect you anyway. Yes this seems suspect and sketchy but once you realize HR's job is to protect the company rather than deal with managers and their suspicious on-going behaviors, which is the nicest way I can put it, then you can't be surprised to see how certain decisions or actions are taken by those that take it.

Delusional as in, and this is just my opinion and perception, that people rather bs an issue rather than own it, deal with it, and move past it. For example a certain title was rejected by Apple due to its method of trying to use IAP; a violation of rules which any iOS developer should know about (sorry if that sounds arrogant but Apple's rules are pretty straightforward to those of us that work as iOS developers). Rather than admit time is needed to fix the mistake and just simply delay the game the necessary amount of time, the individual running that project ensured the higher ups the game will still make the deadline even though it was obvious to all of us that wasn't a realistic possibility. The day of or the day before the submission due date needed to ensure we can make the release date (I forget which) and it was finally delayed for needing more time. I always felt that this could have been a situation where someone(s) messed up but rather than just own it and do something about it, they bs their way to bidding time that just wasn't there. Of course I could be wrong but that is how it looked from my perspective. You'll see a couple questionable things like this that makes you wonder if the "situation" simply is a case of person A trying to save their own butts from what is likely to be the boogie-man rather than any real threat, even for minor things, rather than being a situation where they thought they could get it done but was wrong. Again I could be wrong since that was a situation from my perspective based on what I personally observed.

You see a number of questionable things and it doesn't seem like it comes from the top since the top in every company I've been too, including Disney, tends to take the position of "it is what it is, we'll deal with it" and it is those managers in the middle that treats everything, even minor things, like it is a cause to enter World War 3. It is those managers that fall under what I am describing that DI needs to take a look at and take action against, especially when their competency and even integrity can be easily shown through strong evidence to require HR and higher up's attention at the very least - and this is me being nice about it.

Even with that said, not to mention the ton of things I could say but don't have time nor motivation, I still recommend joining if you are offered employment if you are ok with the idea that it might only last between 1 and 3 years due to the very unstable nature of the company. Simply working for Disney (in my case DI) and living in CA pretty much has a number of companies trying to steal you away (which might just be my experience but it was profound). And not just small companies but big ones such as Facebook, Google, Activision, Amazon, etc will eventually have people reaching out to you for opportunities within their companies.

No matter how long you are there, as long as you have a good team of people you feel you can trust - which was true for me until I joined the last team I was put on in the aftermath of one of DI's restructuring where I felt I couldn't trust the majority of the personalities there, then you will likely be fine. Of course I don't have experience working in every single department or job title, but what I have experienced I would recommend to others since Disney as a whole is a good company that will have many doors open for you simply by having had worked there.

The highest individual I had any direct interaction with was Nikki Katz and she is, in my opinion, a very smart and level-headed woman that is great at her job. Most higher ups like her at DI gave me this impression that they are good people with a lot of talent, drive, work ethic, etc. My only issue is with a few individuals lower than them on the hierarchy. Any run-ins I had with the CEO was random and candid, like holding the door open for each other, but the impression I get is that he is also a good guy and works hard to try to make the company the best it can be.

The wage was not great, for the amount of work that goes into the job, the hours were unpredictable, and they never worked around my schedule. If you work at Disneyland it has to be your #1 and only priority. Some people are in school and make it work, but it's difficult.
