job_title: Associate Software Engineer in Glendale, CA
pros:
You aren't just encouraged to share new ideas, you're expected to (even if they're a bit weird). An awesome change in comparison to other workplaces that ask you to keep your head down and stick to existing methods without asking too many questions. Ideas are currency at this company.

Tons of free classes and courses online and after work through DLearn, funded by Disney for employee growth. Constant growth and career development is emphasized strongly here, so if you're an ambitious professional in your field, there are many extra offerings to help you get where you wanna be. (You do have to seek them out yourself, but there are dozens of awesome courses ongoing all the time.) 

Community is also highly emphasized, and there are lots of on-campus clubs and groups that meet throughout the workday. Even if you have an adjunct interest in a field unrelated to your job, I haven't had any trouble finding support from supervisors to pursue those interests in classes and club memberships.

Depending on your team and management, your mileage may vary. But changing departments and even careers is definitely possible here, and it's been emphasized to me by higher-ups that there is no shame in changing paths if we feel better suited doing something else. I've never had so much support and so many resources in my work life before joining DI. The Disneyland silver pass and 35% merchandise discount definitely don't hurt either.

Food in the commissary is good and cheap, and facilities provides coffee machines and snacks on every floor. There is also a Starbucks on campus.
cons:
Different floors/department/teams are treated very differently. I know of one or two floors that definitely do not share my beaming opinions of our facilities provisions or fair treatment by management. A change in structure to ensure motivating management styles across the board would be an excellent investment for DI.

Don't discount the other cons listed here-- I just haven't found any yet.

review_title: If you want to progress do not work here
pros:
- health/dental care
- free pass to Disneylands all over the world
- flexible hours
cons:
- zero progression opportunities from middle management down no matter how hard you work
- bullying culture
- work is not varied. Small cog big wheel culture e.g. there is a person who is responsible for only watering plants
- middle management who struggle to progress themselves will take credit for your good work
- cliquey 
- other than Disney passes, no good perks - at Christmas we pay for our own lunch etc
- generally have to go through lots of people to make decisions but that's expected with a valuable brand
- lots of unmotivated staff who have been there for their entire careers with no progression

review_title: Be careful what you wish for
pros: meet a lot of new people, work with awesome people, occasionally do something for a guest to make their day, do something very few people get the chance to do.
cons: Low Pay, Management knows and does nothing for employees yet pretends they do, applicable labor union does nothing to aid covered employees. Turnover rate is extremely high; Within a 3 week period, on average 3-4 people announced their departure from the department or from the company. This happened fairly consistently

review_title: Not exactly the happiest place on earth
pros: The company treats their employees well, if you enjoy the parks, the perks are good. The job felt as though it had a lot of security if you want to work in a cubicle for the rest of your life.
cons: There are many segments within TWDC, I worked in corporate. Therefore  I found the work to be very mundane and boring. Anything that was pushing any boundries was watered down through the lengthy chain of commands approval process, which was exhausting and zapped my drive to create and be creative within my job.

review_title: Horrible communication with some "mean girls" culture
pros: Some compelling content to work on (mostly coming out of Pixar, Marvel), attracts driven people (usually at the Manager level or below)
cons: Nasty upper management - very hierarchical, territorial and siloed. Although it could be seen as positive to retain talent, it actually hinders growth of managers/senior managers. There's also a very old-fashioned view on how companies and teams should operate. Many people feel stuck. Lots of people are interested in leaving.

review_title: the Disney store - Office  - Ok place to work
pros:
nice product
friendly staff - did not experience much office politics
looks great on CV and has the wow factor
Pay is average in comparision to  Merchandising/Buying Market
cons:
can be very slow at at times except for christmas when sales shoot through the roof
IT systems are basic
for Merchandising/Buying the experience is not as strong as Fashion companies
Stock Range is only bought 5 times a year instead of Weekly 
Poor communication from management

review_title: great co-workers, friendly studio lot, strange dept environment
pros: terrific co-workers, studio lot is a friendly environment, friendly mgmt, reverence for the history of disney, interesting projects, pleasant studio lot setting
cons: strange dept environment where there's little open communication & many didn't feel involved in meetings regarding their specific projects in development. very political, always in fear of another dept reorganization & the rolling of heads again.

review_title: Fun job, but not for long-term
job_title: Seasonal Merchandise Hostess in Orlando, FL
pros: Pros are that working as an associate at Walt Disney World is extremely organized. I have a new retail job where I keep thinking how terribly disorganized they are in comparison to my time at Disney. Also, you get to meet other associates from all over the world. This is a great part-time job (with obviously tons of perks - free park entry, etc.) for college students. Also, you never have to worry about not getting hours! It's also really simple to give away or trade shifts.
cons: The main challenge my first summer there was the really late hours, sometimes I'd stay until 3am.

pros: Great company, bonuses given for performance as well as profit sharing. Company values the cast members and guests like family. Would relocate to continue with the company.
cons: Red tape made it difficult to make good games, or even get one started. Upper management made some bad divisions early on that led to massive layoffs.

review_title: It was the some of the best and worst days I've ever had. I would do it again.
pros: You get lots of benefits although the pay is not great. If you're a disney fan, it's worth all the money you would spend on vacations there anyway.  The training provided is the best I've ever been through and I met some of the best people I'll ever know.
cons: Guest service is rough.  People will yell at you and management was terrible in certain parts of the parks.  They wouldn't advocate for you at all and didn't really care about your life.

pros: Great opportunity to interact with guests on one to one basis without being in a theme park..  Continual training to stay on top of guest and industry trends.  Great perks( theme park admission, discounts). Great opportunities to cross train and move around company.
cons: Pay, standing for long periods, some "costumes" or uniforms can be a bit unfashionable but on plus side the company pays for laundry service.

review_title: Low pay, no possibility to move up/grow
pros: Health benefits are really both good and free park admission (when you aren't blocked out, which is most of the time) is fun
cons: They are notorious for paying much lower than the industry standard, across all depts and there's very little to no possibility to move up or out of your department. Also, the fact that they allow (obvious) men to wear make-up and dress as a woman, yet harass another man because his hair may be 1/4" too long is ridiculous.

review_title: Disney has it's flaws, but is still an excellent place to be.
pros: Great creative energy. The brand name alone opens a lot of doors, and the history of the place makes for a fun working environment.
cons: They have kind of become the Yankees-- old and slow, trying to buy their way back to the top rather than developing good projects organically. They had to buy Pixar because they couldn't do it themselves, and people who were at Disney before the merger feel a bit like second-class citizens.

pros: There are some extremely bright people who are generally great to work with.  The work is interesting and they are willing to take risks and try new things more than other studios.  When I decided to move on to a new opportunity they were extremely supportive and have given me great recommendation since then.
cons: A couple of bad managers exist that are tough to deal with.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Glendale, CA
pros: Great perks (free entry to parks, movie screenings, 35% discount). Admiration for the brand
cons: Career development is the responsibility of the employee. Corporate environment is very political. Perception is everything. SFAs are glorified assistants. Established employees can leave without pause or concern b/c everyone wants to work for Disney.  Management not trained properly. Disney doesn't foster engagement among staff (no relationship building activities). It's an entertainment company in the business of making money and not enriching the lives of employees or the community they collect dollars from

pros: I worked for TWDC for 6 month as an intern this year. The company's working atmosphere is so friendly to us. We had free film tickets for the company's movies. I learned a lot about teamwork.
cons: The salary is a little bit low although as an intern it won't be high anyway. Must also be able to work under pressure and handle a large variety of things. Must be quick to learn.

review_title: Nice People being subjected to constant layoffs
pros: The people I worked with there at the VR studio were brilliant.  Lots of very smart programmers and some big name projects to work on.
cons: I wouldn't recommend going to work here.  Employees are brought on to work on a single project and laid off when that project ends.  As soon as the project is done get your resume ready and bail out quickly.  Management regards employees as a liability and you will live in your office cubicle.  It's not a total nightmare but your time would be better spent somewhere else.

review_title: Disney overall is great, but there are some problems.
job_title: Barista in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Disney looks after cast members. Good perks. Ability to transfer within.  Unique workplace.
cons: Minimum wage means working many hours to make ends meet. It is hard to be recognised unless you are a personal favourite or friend of one of the managers/coordinators. Workers at my location are undisciplined and many do not care about serving guests the 'Disney way'.

review_title: Love it but little room for growth
pros:
Amazing work environment
Supportive team
Surrounded by smart people
Proactive attitude
Lots of chances to learn and network
Insanely collaborative
cons:
Understaffed
Promotions based on seniority rather than performance
Fear of the changing landscape and the difficulties of adapting

review_title: Don't be there more than one year.
pros: The working conditions are the best. Everything is how it should. As a programmer, I think I worked overtime like once or twice a year.
cons: Very few options to grow inside the company. It's amazing for staying there for one year and then leave. If you stay longer, the institutional inertia will harm your career. Very hard to do something new. Management is technologically illiterate.

review_title: Great Company to work for. Management and Producers need some work.
pros: Company is great. Work life balance is fantastic. Software used is always current versions. Hardware was also always up to date (monitors, cintiqs and computers).
cons: Producers thought they knew better than the audience. They didn't listen to people playing our games and in the end basically drove the company into the ground. Your ideas never mattered, if you weren't part of the "cool kids" group your input wasn't taken seriously.

review_title: Making magic is wonderful, but know what you're getting yourself into
job_title: Character Performer in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Getting to see guest reactions to the "magic" is extremely special. Bonding with fellow cast members about shared experiences often leads to lasting friendships outside of work.
cons:
Some managers do not care about your well-being. Find the managers that do. 
In my specific department I often became ill because of the required costume. It is nearly impossible to have a set schedule unless you are full-time, and even then scheduling may switch you around to fill holes. Takes a great deal to move up in certain departments, risk of getting "stuck" and complacent in front-line job.

review_title: With its nurturing and innovative corporate culture, this is one of the best companies to work for in the industry.
job_title: Flash Designer in North Hollywood, CA
pros: Disney has an excellent benefits package and seemingly limitless perks from discounts at restaurants, movie theaters, and gyms, to free admission to Disney Theme Parks and Resorts. Coworkers are extremely competent and always willing to help and nurture your own growth as well as the company's overall growth.
cons: Numerous divisions and chains of command can sometimes slow certain requests and processes. Innovation is constantly encouraged, however, and forward progress is still a main priority.

job_title: Anonymous, But Work A Lot With Project and Program Manager  in Anaheim, CA
pros: Disney invests heavily in developing their Cast Member's skills and abilities.  There is ample opportunity to work outside of your comfort zone and learn new areas of business.  The company in general has a great culture of collaboration.  If you are in a salaried position, you will be given the opportunity to work with other people in a team setting to further company goals.
cons: It is a big corporation, a lot of bureaucracy.  Important projects can take months, even years, to get programmed while you wait for management approval and budgeting etc.  Then, once it is approved and in the system, you will have to go through the whole process again with a group that should really just be implementing solutions.

review_title: Fun Place to work but not to make money
pros: It is a great, fun place to work.  Interacting with guests and fellow cast members is fantastic.  A lot of team work with the cast members to make the magic.  Seeing a guest who enters Disney property is magical.  You also have unlimited enterance to the park which a great park for those times which you need a quick lift me up.  They offer room discounts and tickets for the members of your family.  There is also discounts on purchasing Disney merchandise. Training is great especially for customer service.  Once you learn Disney customer service there is no other way to do it only the Disney way.  Overall, it is the best place to work.
cons: The downside is that there is no room for growth.  Even if you have a degree you don't get promotion.  It's who you know not what you know.  I've been on 10 interviews inside and always get excuses why I didn't get the position and none of them make sense because I am overqualified for the jobs applied for. The salary is just above minimum wage when starting at the bottom.  Working full-time means they can put whatever schedule and you really do not have a say in getting time off.  Managers really don't have people skills and don't communicate with cast members.

review_title: Looks good on the resume, but you need to leave to advance
pros:
-Free park access will make you a hit with friends and family
-Good discounts on merch
-People light up when you say you work for The Mouse
-While unbelievably unlikely, you could get a job at Pixar or Imagineering one day
cons:
-Low, low, low pay compared to other studios
-Huge variance in pay between divisions for the same work (DIMG pays interactive people 25%+ more for the same role at the Studio)
-Some of the worst managers I've ever worked around
-HR actively discourages employees from moving around the company

review_title: It is a place with lots of opportunities.
pros: It is a place where a variety of career opportunities can be pursued.  The benefits package within the company is one of the best in the country.
cons: Due to an above average benefits package, the compensation usually is on the low side.  You also need to be active in pursuing growth to keep from being pigeon holed into a particular role within the organization.

review_title: Low Wages and No Work Life Balance
pros: Free park passes and discounts on vacation club locations
cons: No work family life balance.  Too much of a sweat shop environment.  Low wages and long hours.  They cater to the retirees or college program kids that will work for nothing, or they recruit from other countries that want to experience the American dream.

pros: Great work perks (Disney passes, etc), flexible schedule, and good work/life balance.
cons: The bureaucracy is getting worse due to the DCP/DI merge. It's a big popularity contest just like in high school - if you are liked by upper management you will get promoted in no time. I guess I'm not a fan of brown-nosing. Strong talent is often overworked, overlooked, and under-appreciated.

job_title: Director of Sales and Marketing in Denair, CA
pros: The Industry is tremendous.  It provides the opportunity of doing international business from the culture to logistics and payment terms, there are great challenges there.
cons: There is always pros and cons to any position. In this position the cons was the size of the company.  There were much more opportunity if the company would had a business model that would have allowed additional growth over and above the 4-fold growth that I provided during my tenure.

pros: Great work environment and staff, facilities are very decent and decor is uplifting. Benefits and perks are great, who wouldn't want a main gate pass, especially if you love Disney.
cons: I was very disappointed with the pay. A company making so much money does not treat its employees well in this regard, I would have stayed and grown with the company if it was at least a living wage...it was not. They want great attitude etc but many are stressed over the pay.

pros: They claim to be a 'Family' of employees which is great... however I saw several people fired when some of the old 'family' of employees ( politically close to management) became available to work again and their replacement 'family' crew members were immediately let go. The management  makes you think your part of the team and matter. But..
cons: Very political hires and fires. The management is not aware of the value of experience because most all managers have been hired and promoted without experience in the working crafts and actual 'working-production' process. They are promoted mostly due to their sex (female) and or LGBT affiliations.

pros: Yearly passes to the parks. The fellow employees are very dedicated hard workers who tryly want to make magic come alive for its guests.
cons: As a part-timer, your schedule will be all over the place. If you do have to work 3rd shift they will give you additional money per hour. There is a lot of information to remember and it can get very overwhelming. There is a high turnover rate.

pros: The culture I work within really respects UX as a part of the success of the business, so my position allows me the ability to speak into priorities of what we should focus improving on within the company's products.
cons: If you have faithfully worked there for many years, its very difficult to negotiate wage increases and promotions. You have to work one full level beyond your job title for at least a year or more, and consistently, to be considered for it.

review_title: Make sure check out the culture of the group....some groups are more friendly than others
pros: Very talented people and free disneyland passes and discount off the very pricey disney merchandises.  I had great colleagues and everyone works very hard.  Nice buildings and offices.  The salary was not bad but you if you figure it out on a per hour basis, you are not making that much.
cons: Hours hours hours!  Forget your personal life if you work in Finance.  Management style is hostile and competitive (i'm sure that is group specific).  The egos are very big companywide.  Their system is lacking for a fortune 100 company and it makes your job that much harder.

pros: Great boss, able to travel internationally. Team was great and very easy to work with, felt lucky to work in our Finance group. I enjoyed working in my group and seeing other departments that we worked with.
cons: Very political. Heard other groups can be "sweatshops". Not much into promotions and compensation recognition. Too much red tape. Too many "heads" and everyone wants to have their say, but no one actually sticks their necks out.

pros: Great benefits and a nice sense of history to the place.  Overall, they promote a sense of community with the entire company.  They hire the best people.
cons: It's a very secretive place to work.  The upper management doesn't communicate all that well with what is expected of them.  Very aggressive environment.

pros: The team that did all the work was talented and dedicated.
cons: Upper management consisted of people that had not made games before. They treated the team disrespectfully, without recognition for their hard work, and replaceable. They kept the entire team as contractors, threw in a large number of out of state FTEs when the project was nearly completed, re-orged the team, then fired all the contractors who had done all the work

pros: Some nice perks. Access to parks, discounts, etc. Health insurance is decent. Some opportunities to advance for the right people.
cons: The ones that are classified as the best employees are the ones that have figured out how to manipulate the system. Forced to work extra hours with not a single thank you but get caught in traffic and show up two minutes late and you get your head bitten off. Unfair treatment by managers. Extreme examples of favoritism are common. Not family friendly. Expected to come into work even when violently ill. Terrible company to work for if you place high priority on things like your family's health.

pros: Good atmosphere, fun environment and changes daily.
cons: Mid level management is unprofessional, non motivating, quick to blame their shortcomings on staff. Work matrix is a joke, favortism is rampant. Sales reporting tool is rife with issues, what is unfortunate, management signed off on this failed system and expects 100% performance with reporting system that pretends to be modern, but is Jurassic at best and worst.

review_title: Good Job to have. Very easy to lose.
pros: The Benefits are almost unlimited. Plenty of chances to win raffles free tickets, free park admission including yourself and family. They will take you to explore parks during training and leadership is great. They don't hover over you or bother you.
cons: Almost anything said wrong to the Guest can get you fired. You can be working there 15-20 years and one day its all over due to something-you were accused of. They hold written exam(Knowledge Assessments) which you can lose your job over. Great Job performance wont help pull you out of anything. Cooperate out of touch.

review_title: Managers can make or break your experience
pros: Fellow employees and some manager are great! The good ones actually care about you and are willing to help if you’re going through a rough time. The Disney family culture is like no other job I’ve had and I’ll always miss that.
cons: If you have a bad manager it can completely ruin your experience. The good news is you can always transfer to another location/role but it sucks if that’s the place where you wanted to be.

review_title: The Strongest Company in the Entertainment Industry
pros: Disney is the only true brand in the entertainment industry and its worldwide reach and visibility (coupled with the fact that it's the second most recognizable brand globally after only Coca-Cola) mean that no matter what your job function, people are suddenly interested in what you do...not to mention it looks great on a resume.  The company is extremely strategic in its direction, and even the highest level initiatives are communicated to all staff; at the corporate level, there's a lot of exposure to different groups as well as executive management.  Disney is a company that champions innovation and creativity, and those values are reflected in allowing employees to really work beyond the scope of their direct job responsibilities to lead projects and initiatives regardless of role.  Benefits are excellent, including unlimited admission to Disney theme parks, and "celebrations" are a big part of the culture.  Disney is a Fortune 100 organization that, while huge, really goes out of its way to make every employee feel like a member of the family.
cons: Although management is taking agressive action to combat this perception, including introducing virtual workplaces and flex scheduling, the work-life balance in many groups isn't great, and you're often expected to work very long hours.  The pay is very competitive for the entertainment industry, but well below market value in other industries.  The company is also extremely decentralized, so it's often difficult to gain exposure to other business units and employees who aren't in your group...many roles are extremely siloed (but the company definitely champions internal growth and rotational exposure to all lines of businesses).  There's little uniformity in business practices, policies, etc. between the different businesses, so it can feel a little overwhelming.  Also, everyone is extremely well credentialed and best-in-class as Disney believes in strategically hiring the best talent for every role, so be prepared for a very competitive corporate culture.

review_title: The magical world of Disney could be even more magical sometimes....
pros:
Nice people and fun products. It is wonderful to bring magic in children's and adults' life!
I am really proud to be part of the Company .
cons: Salaries and Promotions are not the same all over the world and sometimes, within the same office for the same position you will get different salary, benefits, bonus.

review_title: Great  Place to Work - A Few Bad Eggs...
job_title: Animator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great Disney benefits and discounts, animate on Disney characters. The directors are very kind and encouraging. Creating children's games is fun and appealing for animators.
cons: Some people became "too comfortable" Often heard "well we can't do that" in one form or another pertaining to the character rigs. Often this carried over into programming where you would submit your animations into a black hole waiting to hear back, only to find that they never realized your animations were in.

pros:
- Disney is an incredibly inspiring company to work for
- Disney-related perks and cross-company ties
- Pay and benefits are very reasonable
- Good, solid resume-building opportunities for a major recognized brand
- Vast amount of intellectual property and material to work with
- Strong and professional human resources practices
cons:
- Executive leadership is incredibly unstable, and very weak to non-existent middle management exposes it to all levels.  Major political turf wars trickle down the reporting structures and lead to transparently bad decisions.  High management turn-over leads to frequent re-orgs, highly reactive strategic shifts, and perpetual wasted effort.
- Constant threat of frequent and far-reaching layoffs implicitly encourages self-serving and defensive behavior between groups.  The fear drives people not to succeed, but to ensure there's always a reason another group can be seen as more of a problem.  Large parts of the division are effectively paralyzed, engaged in an endless cycle of risk mitigation and defensive planning.
- This is not a technology company.  It is an entertainment company that happens to employ people with technical skills.  Technology is aggressively managed as a fungible commodity.  A need to play within this power structure means technical leadership is often less technically competent the higher you go.
- The company size, bureaucracy, communication overhead, and love of endless discussion with frequent travel makes it very difficult to reach the consensus necessary to make bold decisions or chase emerging technology trends.
- The focus on risk aversion and short-term profits means one must typically look to other divisions to provide the inspiration associated with working for Disney.

review_title: If you value your time and your sense of worth, do not work here.
pros: Free Disneyland around the world (excluding Tokyo) with employee discount on cruises.
cons:
Management apathetic towards employees. They will smile while telling you a lie and are willing to get rid of you while using the same smile. It makes trusting them very difficult and makes you constantly worry how long you will be there. Look out for couple of months before October. That's when they lay people off.

Work/life business becomes non-existent. Management only wants results, they don't care how you get there. Not meeting unreasonable deadlines results in not getting merit.

Software engineers overworked. Too many moving parts and not enough people. Code is built without actual coding principles learned from undergrad studies applied. Very fragile spaghetti code.

Last minute sponsorships and unrealistic to 40 hour week deadlines. Being senior on salary means you work for free when behind on deadlines.

No structure. There are product owners who don't know or are too lazy to figure out what they want. Makes it difficult to complete a product deadline.

Difficulty working with some designers. You have to constantly show them where there design doesn't work. This results in them constantly changing their mind because they don't know how the device limitations are. Even when they've worked on it long enough, they don't learn from the experience.

Promotions are almost non-existent. People got promoted only because there was a department merge.

If you work for quality assurance, don't expect a life and expect working weekends. Same thing for product owners on salary.

Working here will be temporary for you. Whether you like it or not. Eventually management will trim down all departments, contract out, fail, and start all over with new people. It's the historical cycle that I observed.

There is no job security unless you are at the decision making level. Keep that in mind if/when you get hired and good luck.

review_title: Working for the Mouse is not for everyone.
pros: Great benefits, fun IP, good facilities, ample parking and good location. Focus on work-life balance. Prestige at saying you work for Disney.
cons: Layoffs aplenty. Slow advancement, executives don't care much about people lower on the totem pole until you raise their attention or ire. Very vindictive attitudes. Hard to get recognized for quality work. Unhelpful HR. Low pay compared to other companies. Scant transfer opportunities.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Good benefits
-Company has a fantastic CEO
-Very hands on work
-Work with a lot of intelligent people
-Great location in southern california
cons:
-There is a culture of overworking employees late into the night and as well as on weekends
-It is difficult to feel valued working in the Corporate department, not familiar with culture on business side

review_title: Mediocre upper mangement, zero sense of job security, cliquey and often unprofessional
pros: Cohesive team, many employees have been there a long time, there are theme park perks, there are ways to move upward or lateral within the company
cons: The Management was unorganized and seemed to lack in communication skills. This led to mishaps, disorganization, and long periods of time with no answers. It is very clique oriented. There are employees who have been there for years and new hires. New hires vie for positions. In the beginning there is NO sense of job security. Every day feels like walking into a trap. There is no formal training and no designated people in each team to guide you through your tasks and duties.

pros:
Great perks including dental, private healthcare, Disney University (three days of inspiring speakers), discount and free park entry.

Lots of pro-social opportunities including volunteering, participating in charity fundraisers etc.

Good work/life balance

Chance to work with well-known, fun brands
cons:
Severe lack of career progression

Little investment in staff education to develop in chosen industry

Senior management not as inspiring as i would hope in such a creative company

review_title: Finance Director -  Strong Disney Brand and Work with Smart People
pros: Very creative company that leverages and exploits its brand very well.  Senior management does a good job to provide vision to employees and its investors.
cons: Work / Life balance is challenging.  401K compensation is very weak and its vacation time is also below industry standards.

review_title: Low pay, immature management not ready to fill roll, Good medical is about it.
pros: Good benefits, making difference in people's vacation, great co-workers
cons: Low pay- 7.80 for full time cast member isn't acceptable in today's world. Who can live on that? Management can be a problem, I was a coordinator in Tomorrowland and trainer- I couldn't take anymore and put in my resignation and went to a better company, both bigger financially and the way they treat their people

pros: Free admission to the parks is a benefit and when walking through them you feel like you are a part of something huge that doesn't exist anywhere else. Huge company lots of different roles to move around to.
cons: Poor planning by executive management in our division has lead to extreme work hours and wanton disregard for work life balance.

review_title: Start as an intern and work the ladder
pros: Great ways to move up in the company. All you need to do is find new ways of showing you add value to the company in creative ways.
cons: Others also wants to move up, and might create a bit of tensions between two competitors that are aiming for the same position.

review_title: High Standards & Rules VS Low Salary

cons: Salary was too low comparing to my expectations, not all departments have a high salary (Beverage department is difficult if you consider the amount of kids on board). High number of rules and freedom gap on board. Discrepance in types of people depending of role on board.

review_title: must be independent, multi-tasker problem solver
pros: great training, great team environment. dedication to company heritage, always having team builders. HR department always tries to keep people motivated with logo printed freebies.
cons: lots of red-tape protocol.  hands are tied by procedure and level of seniority. low pay.  time off for salaried is first come, first serve.  personal growth is challenging based on location.  some upper management is genuinely interested in improving their leaders, other managers only have a meeting with you to fill a check in the box on their part

review_title: Good work & life balance place for decent pay
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Good work & life balance. Decent pay. Perks and Movie review is very good. 

Quite a lot of different teams and uses almost all kinds of technology you can think of.
cons: The company is not technical oriented which means the its tech stack is quite messy. The managers are more business oriented than technical oriented. They focus more on the value of the product or service rather than the technical merit.

job_title: Merchandise in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The benefits were great. Free passes to the parks whenever. Free passes for your family and friends. Great discounts. I was part time so I didn't have health care our anything but there 's room for growth. After working for for months they already wanted me to apply for a coordinator position. You can go far. Great co workers. Positive pace to be. I enjoyed very much
cons: Bad hours if you want a family. That is really all.

review_title: It's been a Dream Job of all sorts working at Walt Disney but sometimes reality gets in the way.
job_title: Research Specialist in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The Cast Members have a passon for the company and you see it and live it everyday. Working in a vacation destination and helping people to experience the Magic turns any bad day Into a good day. The free admission for you and your family and discounts on merchandise are nice and a huge perk. Job security as the Company continues to expand its theme parks and other divisions remain profitable. Great job if you are young and new to the workforce or retired and looking for a no worries atmosphere.
cons: Being the largest employer in Central Florida sets the bar for low wages. Over the past few years cost of living has increased significantly in The Orlando Area while the pay has not increased. Cast members who have senority with the company are making at times the same or barely more than a new hire with little or no experience. Work life balance is hard for many especially with families as they need to work a second job or overtime to pay for daycare or make ends meet.  Recent changes in Heathcare coverage forced many employees to drop their trusted pediatricians and primary care doctors in order to keep their HMO or drop to lower coverages to keep those doctors. As for part time there is no more Heath care options, no paid holidays, and yet you still have to commit to three full days of availability the gives little to no flexibility.

review_title: Interactive Group -- great environment, but leadership issues
job_title: Lead Product Manager in Burbank, CA
pros:
How amazing is it to work in an environment of such creativity, and at a company with so much history. Disney has touched everyone's childhood, and most people's adulthood too.

I was a part of big, awesome projects. The name recognition on your resume doesn't hurt either. 

The people I worked with are still some of my closest friends, and in the tech sector of LA (which is a surprisingly small world), I've run across many of them again and again in different companies. There's a lot of talent in that company. 

Full time employees get a silver pass to the Disney parks. I miss that thing -- really.
cons:
When I was there, we burned through so many projects that were conceived because of a perceived market opportunity, though nobody in senior management ever stopped to ask whether the lack of competitors in the market was because nobody wanted a product like that. It killed morale to work on things that launched and immediately died.

Everything was meant to impress Bob Iger (CEO) rather than the users, and he was never interested in iterating and improving on launched products to get them to a place of great usability. He just wanted things launched, then more new products launched afterward. That's not how good digital development works. 

I was there through a couple of massive re-orgs. Jimmy Pitaro brought in a bunch of lackeys from Yahoo with no idea what they were doing, and they drove our division into the ground. I think they're all gone now (with the exception of Jimmy). 

People I still know at the company say it's much better now.

pros: Tons of experience working as first response to incidents on the property.  Work closely with APD and AFD, and there's nothing better than helping lost parents find their kids.
cons: Management is bad.  They pull management from other departments.  Who wants a security manager who spent their time making pizza?  Everyone is afraid of the computer system - if it says you did something bad, nobody questions it.  Too easy to get fired (I didn't get fired)

review_title: Great company, great experience, low pay, low room for growth
pros: Great company to work for, and great brand to support.  Flexible work options are company policy.  A lot of opportunities to take development classes that are incredibly helpful.
cons: low pay, no raises beyond annual 3-4%, very hard to grow in the company.  hard work does not equal more pay or a higher title.  often those who do less work get promoted, and those who do more dont.

pros: The people are top notch, friendly and positive.  The benefits of the parks, stores, and working with the brand can't be beat.  The ability to work with some Creative greats is amazing as well.
cons: Difficult to learn new things since everything is compartmentalized, and moving around within the company is non-existent.  Motivation to excel is low, but enough is here to be "content".  Benefits and perks with Disney are great but pay is rather low with no huge increase in sight.

pros:
Great team members, friendly and always lovely to work with fellow Disney fans
Amazing sample sales
Good discounts and free Parks entry
Good work/life balance
cons:
Super clique-y
Can be difficult to speak up for yourself due to arrogant personalities
Limited in their range as they're North America led and can't develop any product which is a shame as NA and Europe are such different markets

review_title: Happy, but not always happiest, place
pros:
- Powerful brand and content/products you can believe in
- Generally good business direction
- Relationship-oriented and collaborative (can also be a con)
- Smart people who care and are passionate (mostly)
cons:
- High bureaucracy and red tape in some areas; not very entrepreneurial
- People leadership is highly variable; don't always practice what is preached
- Relationship-oriented business can create lots of barriers and insularity
- Upward career mobility is limited, even with size of company

pros:
Without doubt the greatest part of working here are the films.  They are the best and most relevant in the industry.  Star Wars, Marvel, Pixar, Disney Live Action, Disney Animation...each of these are the gold standard of movies worth going to the theaters for.

It is always exciting to be a part of these campaigns and there are plenty of talented people on the team.  It can be thrilling and inspiring seeing your work come to life and feeling like you're a part of a movie's success.
cons:
Politics and workload.  There is not much community beyond your own individual team and everyone is constantly trying to prove their worth.  This means that collaborating on projects is difficult because everyone wants to claim the glory for themselves.  Sometimes this can even result on your own team as you see others take credit for your work.  This is not a place that allows people from all levels to have a spotlight shine on them.

There is a very high (and sometimes seemingly impossible) expectation.  Upper-level executives have high demands and expect to see their wishes and visions executed.  Standing up as a voice of reason is oftentimes looked down on as being subversive or lazy, even if it's not either of those things.  Due to the high volume of work, don't be surprised to see yourself working late, getting in early, working from home, or working weekends with some amount of regularity.  To be fair, there is a somewhat new initiative to find an appropriate work-life balance, but in over a decade of working for the company, the bottom line is and will always be the work and employee satisfaction will take a back seat to that.

Promotions and raises are also extremely hard to come by - if you're someone hoping to be rewarded based off your good work alone, that is far from guaranteed.  This is not a meritocracy.

pros: You create some of the most magical and unforgettable moments with guests from all across the world.
cons: The managers have turned this company into such an operation, all they care about at numbers. They will measure your guest numbers and if you are lower than 113% they will call you out. Some people take pride in rushing through interactions and dont care about the guest.

review_title: Decent media job for starting out and building a resume, but not one to stay in long-term if you are looking for growth.
pros:
Very laid back and accepting environment for an office.
Decent pay for what job is.
Flexible scheduling with proper notice of conflict.
GREAT healthcare plans.
cons:
Low and infrequent raises.
No room for upward growth.
May be asked to do several different jobs outside of your job description for no increase in pay.

job_title: Safety in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Park access; Great relationships; Comp tickets
cons:
Not performance based
Relies on relationships heavily
Good Ole Boy mentality

review_title: The role as a Bus Driver at the parks at Walt Disney World
job_title: Bus Driver in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Easy work, once you get the hang of it. A somewhat helpful union. Gain experience handling customers (called "guests", at WDW).  A number of free admissions to the parks for friends and family, where that is usually the number one reason to work there. Bus drivers also get paid half way decently, as hourly jobs go at WDW, more than other roles, such as being a security guard. The Bus driver position is also about the easiest job at WDW (once you get the hang of it), and it is the easiest job to get too!!!
cons: One works late hours in the the part time position. Full time can be booked 6 days a week. It is very hard, almost impossible to get a day off, unless you trade or give away your shift, which oftentimes with a little effort isn't too difficult to do. Some managers are are "by the book" and will scare you by being pulled in if a customer (a "guest" at Disney) complains about you. However, the Union does a half way decent job of protecting you, so do sign up for the Union if you decide to work there! If you have good people skills, you should be okay, and is a cinch. If you don't, don't worry, you will develop these in time. Another big hassle is their new 5 minute clock in, clock out time constraint with their point system. That can take some getting used to, if you haven't worked in that kind of environment. You get half a point for being even just a little outside that 5 minute window, and you cannot get more than 3 points every 3 months, or you get a reprimand. I think you can only get 2 reprimands, and on the 3rd, they let you go. You also do not want to have a "signal 4", which is running into something. You can only have 2 of those, and on the 3rd, they let you go.

pros: get into Disneyland for free, medical benefits were not bad, 401k,
cons: no work-life balance, not provided the resources to accomplish what is needed to be produced,  cliquey high school back stabby environment.  Was told by my management when we pushed back for continually working the team 60+ hours weekly and burning team out "too bad if they want to keep their job they will work otherwise we have 200 other people wanting to take their job and work for Disney".      They are great customer facing but very different employee facing.

review_title: Politics hinders teamwork and morale. Lack of communication breeds a toxic environment.

pros:
The final product, for the most part, was something to be proud of.
Some of the perks are nice. For example, silver pass into the parks, movie nights on the studio lot, lots of knick knacks from premiers.
cons:
The pay is low compared to the industry average and 
The politics hinders teamwork and morale. Lack of communication breeds a toxic environment.
Disney Feature Animation is the step child after the company acquired Pixar. They're cannibalizing their own products.

review_title: A great place to start your career, but not a place to stay for a long time.
pros: It's fun to create magic, and if you get in the right area with the right people it is a lot of fun.
cons: Pay is not up to par and the work life balance if off.  It seems that you have to leave your area if you ever want to get promoted.

pros: The benefits and perks are very good, including a very valuable perk of free entry to the parks for you and three other people.
cons: Career advancement is nearly impossible unless someone in a position that you want leaves the company, and even then the position is most likely going to be filled from outside the company. I've actually had managers tell me that the only way to advance is to leave the company and then hope to be hired back at a higher level.

review_title: Not the most magical experience, but still an experience
pros:
- get to be part of a massive brand and create fun and creative things for kids
- perks were good (free passes to disneyland, discounts with various vendors like Apple etc)
cons:
- a lot of unnecessary politics and power plays
- can be very cliquey, and this affects professional judgement

review_title: Great if you have management support!
pros: I really liked Disney until the last year.  Autonomy to build my team and program the way I wanted. Most supervisors helped me to remove roadblocks.  Empowered to learn and grow.
cons: In 4 years, there were at least 4 rounds of layoffs.  Upper management was a revolving door.  I never had the same boss for more than 1yr.

pros: Creating innovative products and projects that challenge and excite while working in professionally with truly the best of the best is what happens here. The magic happens when expertise, meticulous planning and great people intersect to super serve and provide a world-class Disney experience.
cons: Since technology is constantly changing, our business continues to evolve and change with it. It's just the way things grow not a "con."

review_title: Great leadership and investment in staff make this an awesome place to work!
pros: The company invests in the development of its employees. There is great work life balance, friendly people, 3 weeks paid vacation, good benefits, and the silver pass that gets you into almost any Disney park in the world for free! (with the exception of Paris and Tokyo)!
cons: compensation is not quite as competitive in terms of talent market.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: Steady employment. Health Insurance. Park admission.  Lots of talented, fun people to work with.  Occasionally interesting work, sometimes with state of the art equipment.
cons: Stifling, often petty rules born out of a fear of litigation.  Current Disney culture has created the most mediocre, demoralized workforce out there.  Good employees aren't rewarded, bad employees aren't punished.  Senior management doesn't seem to understand the business (entertainment) that they're managing.

job_title: Seasonal Cast Member QSFB in Orlando, FL
pros:
There is no better feeling than being able to create a "Magical Moment" for child, teen, or adult - on their special trip to the most magical place on earth! I truly felt like I was making a difference when I would go out of my way to sprinkle just a little more Pixie Dust around Magic Kingdom. After work, I would write stories about my magical experiences that day, and one of them involving an elderly man who was on his anniversary trip after his wife had just passed away, was even sent up through an email chain and made it's way into many people's hearts. 
Working for Disney can be a life changing experience - if you choose to let it be. All companies have their ups and downs - it's all about what you want to get out of it everyday.
cons:
As a seasonal employee, I traveled 2,000 miles each summer and during various holidays to met my 150 hr requirement. I did this successfully as a full-time student for 2 years. Then, at the end of the March collection period, one month before I had planned to return to the Magic Kingdom, I was let go for being 4 hours short of the requirement. 4 hours. I do not make money out there, as it all goes to travel, lodging and food. I do it because I LOVED to do it. I was one of the few employees working at Pecos Bill's (a quick service restaurant that most do not enjoy working at) that actually enjoyed and looked forward to creating magic for someone each day. I was released because of a minor 4 hour oversight. I even offered to fly out immediately to make up the 4 hours. But, no flexibility. I was told by the head of scheduling that she had let someone go for being 30 minutes short - it didn't matter. 
Walt Disney Company will always remain a cherished memory of mine, and I will always value the company, but this was truly a heartbreaking experience.

pros: Very engaging IP and work, and the company puts a lot of effort into making new experiences/films accessible to employees.  Solid benefits.  Pay is about average.  Lots of pride in representing a great brand.
cons:
Very large company with lots of bureaucracy and some units that basically function as different companies, e.g. Parks & Resorts.
I can only speak to my department, not corporate as a whole, but: Toxic work environment with very slow-moving change.  Lots of nepotism, resulting in positions from managers to SVPs being filled by underqualified employees.  Opportunities for advancement are limited for those not on management tracks.

review_title: Guest Service Manager  (Walt Disney World Resort)
pros:
Excellent opportunities to focus on career development.
Great benefits from Insurance, 401k, and free admission into Disney Theme Parks in Florida, California, and parks across the globe.
Supportive peers and opportunities to work with some great people (based on my experience with the company)!
cons:
Long hours (primarily during peak periods).
Although there are great opportunities to step into new roles within the organization. It can be challenging and extremely competitive at times. I've seen deserving people, and qualified people not receive support for positions. I have always believed this is due to the large size of the organization.

review_title: Great company and benefits to work for
job_title: Cultural Representative Program in Orlando, FL
pros: Of course, working for Disney means having to deal with many people every day, but the reward (if you like the Disney mood) is that the atmosphere is great, people are in general in a good mood and the company is very well organized. I have had a great experience with Disney and I hope to get back one day.
cons: Pay is a little low at the entry level and it might be highly stressful at times. But if you can make it there are many chances to grow and get a career.

pros:
The company really does some of the best work in and around the area that they are in. Always seeking to be innovative and create new ideas... and you get to be a part of it. Simply put, it was amazing to be surrounded by the work that you did.

The people who were making it happen were also some of the brightest in their industry. It was fun to collaborate with people and trying to make next generation technology with such interesting constraints.

Benefits-wise, the company is super progressive and definitely one of the top places to work at. Paternity/Maternity leave, PTO, sick days, WFH... by the time I left, I had over 5-6 weeks of time built up - even with taking sick days, that's how generous they were with the time. Obviously, Disney perks were great as well - free admission to the parks (including your partner and dependents), ESPN/ABC streaming, discounts, etc... Obviously retirement, health insurance, and additional onsite perks were available. (ie. cafeterias, on-site gym, nursing rooms, etc.)
cons:
Not everyone's experience is the same and I certainly will admit that I'm an anomaly in the group - My time there was spent trying to play a lot of politics. I was in the same role for over almost a decade and was not able to move up in either position or pay. By the end of my time, management was starting to make attempts to move me up but it was already too late for me. I had certain life events that had happened that forced me to make a move out of the company.

In addition, I was in a very hostile work environment for almost half my time there. The combination of the right cast members, lack of upper management supervision, and my own personal attitude contributed to the hostile work environment. Lots of closed door meetings, yelling at partners, and lack of cooperation caused the environment to be tense. Thankfully, I got out of that specific environment a year before I left the company and am glad to say that is not the norm for Disney.

I was paid really poorly, but I came from the bottom - literally - working hourly in operations and moving up. I had multiple conversations with my leaders about my pay and all of them denied me. Either due to budget constraints or there were other people who were ahead of me that they chose to move up. If you choose to go the internal route, be prepared to fight for your worth. As mentioned above, playing politics is the game. 

Also, if you were hourly, it was really difficult to perform professional-level jobs while sticking to 40 hours. Many people took their work home to finish writing e-mails, creating documents, etc. While this was openly discouraged, most of us found it hard to figure out how to fit all of our professional work into 40 hrs a week when we were tied up in collaboration meetings for half the week.

review_title: Great company, not all departments created equal
job_title: Senior Manager, Strategy & Operations in Burbank, CA
pros: Great company to work for, industry leader, opportunity to work on the best titles and products in Entertainment
cons: Internal career progression is painfully slow, promotions are rare, length of tenure prevents staff from moving up within the company - you may have to leave and come back at a higher level

review_title: Seniority based not Performance based=unfair system
job_title: Quick Service Food and Beverage in Orlando, FL
pros: Free park tickets for yourself and guests. Meet people from all over the world.
cons: Company is seniority based not performance based & sometimes (depending on the manager) employees with high seniority ranking get away with things, such as getting to leave the shift early for no good reason, call offs without receiving points or reprimands, and get away with poor work performance solely because of how long they’ve been with the company. Managers are moved around constantly, so cast members with seniority sometimes run the show at the location. By this I mean managers allow them to get away with things other employees don’t. Seniority has priority when it comes to transferring locations. If a full time position becomes available & a full time cast member with high seniority is on the transfer wait list, they will get that position regardless of their work performance, which can screw over a part time cast member already at that location waiting on a full time slot to open. Management has no say in who gets the full time slots or any position, it’s done threw casting, so even if a manager wants to move one of his cast members to full time, he has NO say in it at all, the computer automatically fills the slot with the next eligible employee by seniority. This seniority based concept allows and enables cast members who have been with the company for a while to slack off and throw the work load on the other cast members, with zero consequences. Seniority basically grants you immunity at Disney. I have seen cast members with high seniority leave shifts early, and receive no points for call outs. I have seen them basically tell the managers how to run the shift. Managers do not say no to them, they will let them leave a shift early for no good reason while we were busy, but force college program or part time employees who are sick (which is a health violation for food and beverage) stay the whole shift. I have seen managers at the wilderness lodge not give points for call outs for high seniority employees, and not accept doctors notes from part timers and still give them the point. Very unfair system

review_title: A very proud place to be a part of!
pros: It's Disney. The heritage, the culture, the characters. You can believe in your company and products they way you would your own child. It's that level of commitment I have for this company.
cons: It's a big, political circus like all other corporate behemoths. Sometimes you can navigate the water and sometimes you can't. Change is the only constant. That and layoff season.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Hollywood, CA
pros: As part of the Walt Disney Company you will be working for a corporation that is world class in media and entertainment. Great health benefits, free access to the Parks and learning opportunities through the Disney University.
cons: This division has struggled for going on 10 years. It has never been profitable and a succession of layoffs has left the division a shadow of its former glory days when the division was first created. It is still suffering from the upheaval of the majority of its senior management team being laid off and replaced with outside Yahoo executives two years ago. Another layoff of 115 people in September has left those remaining employees with too much work to handle. If you are working for a technology company, look for other opportunities.

pros: This place is one of the funnest places on earth to work. You meet thousands of people everyday that more or less are in their vacation hence enjoing their time off from real life which makes them amazing guest. The workforce is extremely diverse which makes learning about new cultures not only easy but enjoyable. amazing benefits
cons: As a part time worker you get very small amount of hours a week, sometimes less than 7 which is very inconvenient. The hourly wage is also beloew neraby competiton which makes it extremely hard to have a lavish life while working at disney.

pros: The people really make this place. Everyone I worked with was genuine and there weren't any egos. There are great benefits and the hours are perfect for someone who doesn't enjoy the longer hours you experience on the agency side.
cons: It takes a long time to get promoted (think 3-5 years on average). There are annual layoffs, the most recent reduced the staff by 700 employees. This leaves the existing employees feeling resentful and overworked.

review_title: Disney Italy. Good learning field, badly paid
pros: You might have a chance to work and learn beyond the responsibilities traced by your job title. Though, don’t expect to be paid for it.
cons: Company values are only for compliance, not put in practice or embedded in the culture. Lack of professionalism but that gives you room for learning and getting your hands at work everywhere if you want to. Even though, don’t expect to be rewarded for it. The only reward would be your learning.

review_title: Good place until you find something better
pros: The coworkers are like family. You form relationships that last forever. Good training great health benefits and park entry benefits
cons: Management will try to get rid of you by making your life hard if you disagree with them. Can't get a promotion to save your life, and benefits are good because pay wages for regular workers are next to nothing. You will need 2 jobs to work here, and tat can be hard to do with Disney's strict availability policy

pros: You are employed by a Fortune 100 company, I have been hired with this experience alone at many great places since leaving the company and meeting and working  with people from different cultures and walks of life is an unforgettable experience.
cons: As an intern, you get the worst hours. But this worked in my favor as I am a night owl.  Could be a downside if you are a morning person who can't stay up until 6am.

review_title: A place where you can make magical experiences for Guests to remember in a lifetime!
job_title: Hotel Front Desk Agent in Fullerton, CA
pros: The people you work with your fellow Cast Members!  The Cast member exclusive events!  Great teamwork environment!
cons: Very limited promotional opportunities!  There are some office politics in the organization.  Not the right leaders for the right locations.  There are some average leaders that stay for a long time!  We are so busy that it does make it hard for the front line Cast Members to deal with unhappy Guests.

review_title: Great perks, but the money is not there
pros:
Great perks. You get free park tickets, discounts at Disney Store and get to be a part of Disney Magic.
Pretty relaxed corporate environment, with flexible working hours, etc.
cons: As it's Disney, they expect you to work with below industry average wage. They really don't pay you well. Also, you barely get inflation rate pay increase, regardless of your performance.

pros:
Being surrounded by people on vacation is fun!
Working with people who are all there to serve others and make life more fun is great too.
cons:
Well, the pay is not the reason people go to work for Disney. Few will get rich working in the Vacation Kingdom.
Upward mobility seems to be rare too. Lateral, yes, to pick up extra shifts and whatever. But climbingthe ladder doesn't seem to be in the cards.

review_title: Disney is the place you love to hate!
pros: Free entry into Disneyland, Disney Store Discounts, The Disney Brand is a familiar and stable brand. I really like the people I work.
cons: Corporate Politics, HR is only there to protect the company and not the employee, and Low Pay

pros: Some great consultants to work with.
cons: Politics everywhere. Especially, within the Corporate  HQ in Burbank. You have better do a good job so your boss does not have to do anything. However, you have better not do too good of job and make him or her look bad. Got the  picture? This is why everything takes forever to complete.

review_title: A company that continues to remain true to its founding mission
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: An incredible diverse group of people who are the top of their field. A wide range of talent to pull from and collaborate. The quality of the work produced is why Disney is still a household name and a brand that can be trusted.
cons: A corporate feel in a creative arena makes some things a challenge. Often decisions are not made by what is best for the guest but how will it affect the bottom line.

job_title: PhotoPass Photographer in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Great experience working around guests who are happy to be there and you take part in "making magic" and memorable experiences for them to remember for the rest of their lives.  Free entrance to the park for you and family (limited times).  Working at the most "Magical Place on Earth".
cons: Pay could be better, but OT is always available and easy to make it up if your willing to work.

review_title: A great company but not so great for software developers
pros: Feel as part of history. Strong culture related trainings. Company cares about its brand.
cons: Does not have culture of developing its own software. Rather just babysitting purchased third party products. Software development managers do not have basic understanding of software development. Asking dumb questions are highly valued as social skills. Solving problems on one's own is viewed as trouble-making.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Orlando, FL
pros: Lots of room to grow, expansion means opportunity for transfers to learn other roles, strongly encouraged to get to know the product - which means team outings to the parks and movies
cons: Still working through the new management structure so all moves and promotions have been frozen for over a year, some workers and managers are incompetent (but I guess that everywhere)

review_title: Decent experience, nice company perks, but different groups are probably better
pros: Having a large corporation on your resume is typically a good thing, the benefits are pretty good, Silver Pass is pretty awesome
cons: Not a lot of mentorship or career growth option, VPs and above stick around too long, not a lot of upward mobility, not an innovative company, HR protects senior leadership and not the other lower-level employees

pros: Office culture was always great, lots of opportunity for promotion and experiences, great people, and always fun to work for Disney.
cons: Poor leadership which continues to get worse. Too much removed corporate structure without a real understanding of the value of the people they have. Inability to actually make profitable games stemming from a desire to mash together mediocre game concepts with Disney IP.

review_title: Fun, great atmosphere, talented people who know how to enjoy their work.
job_title: Lead Artist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, and fun perks, free food,  theoretical access to work on exciting IPs.  Career growth wasn't too difficult for myself, but I could see that changing depending on the individuals situation.
cons: Upper management seems to play musical chairs every 6 months, constantly realigning goals.  Division seems to be in a do or die situation right now.

review_title: I loved my job, even though I had numerous leaders in 2 decades I never had one lead the way a "Disney" leader should.
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: If you are hired from outside the company you will be paid what you are worth. Great options for health benefits & 401k opportunities. If you like Disney you will enjoy the comp pass & silver pass perks.
cons: If you start with WDW a young age/right out of college you are financially punished for your loyalty of only working at WDW -numerous managers will tell you to leave WDW and come back after you have worked somewhere else a couple years. One manager who had been at WDW 7 yrs longer than me made $26k less than me for the same job because she worked at WDW since graduating college. If you have a salary sales job, most managers expect you to check your work email 24/7 and be available for any client/cast member work call 24/7. WDW is so large there is no one to hold directors/managers accountable for hiring practices, i.e. hiring their best friends or reorging their dept to bring in their friends -or favoring a few specific clients who are their personal friends. No one says or reports anything because everyone knows if you do they will get rid of you. I saw it happen numerous times.

review_title: If you love talking and working with people it's perfect.
pros: You literally create relationship with coworkers and customers almost every shift. You create so many magical moments for people that it seems unreal. Also, the discount is very good! Working with products you know makes the job so much easier. Coworkers are friendly for the most part and it feels like you are working at Disney World sometimes. Making children happy makes work feel like nothing and that talking to people at the till, though.you do run across stiff heads, it can be quite enjoyable to have a great conversation simply about a Disney franchise.

For example, TV exec producers who like to 'get started' at 8pm and work until midnight or 2am, when the editing crew has been there since 8am already.  It doesn't have to be this way, and many show runners and EPs I've worked with "get it" that they are not going to get the best creatively or technically if they work their people into 20 hour days.  The insult / injury is when they pressure you to falsify your time sheet so they don't have to pay OT.  We in the Editors Guild often complain about our weak union, but in the end, it often comes down to the individual having the self-respect to say, "You asked me to work those hours, and so I did, and now you must pay me for my work, according to our contract."  But workers fall for the old 'divide and conquer' strategy and compete against each other for advancement, selling themselves and everyone out at the same time.

review_title: I put up with it because I needed money to pay for college
pros:
The perks are spectacular - free access to parks, discounts on merchandise and food, and tickets for your friends and family.

The co-workers are interesting- I was a lifeguard working summers part-time to give myself some spending money for college. The kids I encountered who were in the International College Program were literally from all over the world and it was really cool to get to know them and learn about where they come from.

The guests- while some guests were a pain to deal with, by and large you're surrounded by people who are having a good time and are friendly. Occasionally I would run into someone who would give me career advice (I'm in school for engineering) and talk to me about their experiences in industry. It was a lot of fun to interact with the happy guests.
cons:
Management- as a lifeguard I had SIX different managers to report to. It was very VERY hard to get anything done because communication broke down constantly, and requests to be cross trained in other areas or to do ANYTHING other than maintain the status-quo were nearly always forgotten or denied. On one occasion, I traded a shift with another lifeguard (a perfectly acceptable thing if you get manager approval) and the manager who approved the change forgot to tell anyone - I received a reprimand for a no-call-no-show, even though it had been approved, and when I asked the manager to fix it, he said "don't worry about it, it'll fall off your record by next year." Not cool.

Ultimately, my employment was terminated because of a policy change which occurred while I was at school and which NONE of my SIX managers bothered to tell me about via a phone call, or email. I still have my badge and my uniform because I had to call Disney to find out I didn't work there anymore. That is completely unprofessional, in my opinion.

The culture also rubbed me the wrong way. I was treated with very little respect, and as though I was always trying to get away with something. Supervisors spy on you from the bushes (and not necessarily for lifeguard auditing purposes). There seemed to be no (or at least, a seldom used) system in place for rewarding good behavior, only for punishing bad behavior. I was talked down to, as though I were a 13 year-old trying to get away with something, rather than an aspiring aerospace engineer in college.

Finally, while I understand the need to appear happy in front of guests, it was almost as if many employees were two-faced. Employees would smile as they walked past you and scowl as they walked back stage. Managers were unapproachable and seemed to work to make themselves more intimidating.

pros:
A lot of these benefits have decreased since I left,  so keep that in mind:
1) Great for families because you get a pass that lets you get into Disney for you and your children. It has blackout dates, but it is a nice thing if you can make it work. During the holidays, you get an additional set of tickets so you can let additional people in. 
2) Health Insurance is on par with a lot of other companies. You have your range of options HDHP, PPO, HMO, etc. 
3) Vacation is set to 3 weeks and increases after 5 and 10 years. You get 10 sick days that is separate from your PTO days. 
4) Retirement is a standard amount (3-4%, but I forget the exact amount)
5) Free moving screenings for you and your family. 

The total benefits package is pretty standard, but good. 

Now anyone who reads a review for Disney should factor in that the company is so large and your individual team can have such an impact on how you feel about the company. Personally, I was on a great team and enjoyed my time at Disney. At the same time, other peers in other groups worked much longer and did not enjoy it nearly as much. It is a crapshoot whether you might enjoy working at Disney.
cons: The biggest downside is the constant change through acquisitions or process improvements. This results in layoffs being frequent. It felt like there was always some sort of reorg on a yearly basis that resulted in some group being impacted. This is business as usual for a large company, but something to keep in mind.
