review_title: Good place to work if you don't need the money or want to advance up the corporate ladder.
pros: Excellent benefits package for full-time employees including; medical, dental, Park admission for you and your family, discounts on merchandise and rooms, and work uniforms "costumes" are provided. For the most part coworkers are friendly and you can have fun at work. It's encouraged that you use your imagination, play with the guests "customers", and engage everyone you meet. It's a great place to hone your customer service skills. You will meet people from all walks of life, all ages, all countries, and temperaments between completely amazed to rude and angry. However Disney gives you all the tools you need to deal with most situations. Training courses on diversity, in-depth training in customer service techniques, access to software for learning different languages, all internal communication is in both english and spanish, and a wealth of self paced learning online. Probably one of the best jobs if you don’t need to live off you own wages, just need the benefits, and/or have no interest in advancement.
cons:
As I just mentioned its a fun and rewarding job, just not financially. Average starting pay is barely above minimum wage and with the exception of peak times, they usually give you a minimum number of hours. Part-time has to give 4 days of availably but may only be worked 1 day a week. This and the fact that schedules are only posted a week in advance make it hard to get a second part-time job. Full-time is required to give "full availability". This means you have to be available to work any shift on any day, literally you have to be able to work 24/7 if needed. The minimum number of hours for full-time is 32 which can make budgeting tricky. Pay raises are small, between 1-5%, and in no way keeps up with inflation. It can take years to transfer from part-time to full-time not because of a lack of need but because upper management just won't make the opportunities available. Even if a full-timer leaves they don't fill the vacancy with an eligible part-timer looking to move up. They just back fill with another part-timer. However if you have a spouse who makes good money and you are working there for "fun" or to get medical benefits than non of this matters.

The management structure is very limiting for growth. There are very few levels between front-line castmember "employee" and upper management. This means it's hard to move up and extremely difficult to get into a middle management role. There are things you can do to enhance your pay like becoming a trainer or facilitator but the boost in pay is only in effect when you are officially scheduled for that role. None of these will help your chances to advance and if you're really good, could even hurt them. Managers are salary positions and tend to work more then 40 hours per week. Consideration for new manager candidates isn't done by performance or job knowledge but by favoritism. If you're liked you move up, if not you're stuck. Your direct manager holds your fate in their hands. Any kind of advancement or transfer can be blocked by them.

cons: Many of the interesting projects did not come to fruition.   A lot of executive churn made for lots of "new initiatives" leading to a loss of mission at times.   The department changed its name 3 times in my 4 years as an employee.   3 CTO's as well in that time.

review_title: Disorganized since Fox Merger, Virtually no Transparency
pros: I had great immediate supervisors who were supportive and invested in me, and extremely pleased with my work performance as a Fox employee. I became part of a hand-selected team which was slated to transition from Fox to Disney. I immediately immersed myself into the Disney culture to the extent in which it was made available, completing all required webinars and attending all meetings. Management verbally offered me a job within a newly restructured division of Disney in fall of 2019 and I received a decent salary increase. Some Disney perks were extended to me beginning 1/3/2020 including Main Entrance Park passes and generous employee discounts.
cons: Despite was I was told about my status with the Company in early fall 2019, by January 3, 2020 several red flags were raised. My position was yet to be properly formalized with HR department and I was never fully integrated into Disney corporate, evidenced most notably by a post-merger "wall" which continued to exist between former Fox and Disney employees. Essentially, Disney presented a dangling carrot to keep me and other department members working to meet critical 1st Quarter financial goals. A newly appointed department head that I now found myself reporting to had what I would call a “major avoidance” management style, slow to respond to emails and deliberately withholding information so I could continue to do my job. The division’s organizational structure was kept purposely vague, no one really sure of job titles. Senior "leaders" would routinely set and then cancel daily and weekly video conference meetings. One instance I recall was a flurry of 6 emails in one day for an on-again/off-again team meeting, I surmise because they were busy trying to figure out who to eliminate and how to save their own positions. Eventually, pre-COVID-19, my position, along with others in my former Fox division and department, had been eliminated. I was told I could apply internally for the position that I had been already been doing for Disney for the past several months, which I did. A total waste of time, even though my resume matched 90% of the job description and I had already been doing a great job. Disney HR is terrible too, my HR “partner” offered nothing but a vacant look and plastered on smile when I was handed my exit package. It is very sad how former Fox employees have been treated post-merger. Disney’s intention all along was to eliminate older pensioned employees who earned higher salaries. Not a magical place. At all.

review_title: It's a great place to work if you want to have an entry level job.
job_title: Location Planning Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Good incentive and benefits package. Good pay for experience. Depending on the role you will find your leaders have balance between work and personal life.
cons: Sometimes they look for things in people and the people don't even know it's expected of them. That is difficult when you are doing what you think is a good job and you aren't getting any performance feedback.

pros: Everyone at Disney is treated with the highest level of respect, from executives to interns. People seem truly happy to be there, and not to mention, there are incredible perks - concert events, movie screenings, speaker series and behind-the-scenes previews of upcoming projects.
cons: NONE. Don't ever turn down a job with Disney - it is named number one company to work for year after year for a reason. The only Con I can think of is that so many people want jobs there, so it's very difficult to get in.

review_title: Disney World placed me in the worst and most mindless job where you are not allowed to speak to cast members
pros: They finally switched my mind numbing job to costuming at the Magic Kingdom.  There I was training to help open a new parade called Move it Shake it ....i forgot the rest.  That was fun!  I also loved staying at Vista Way because there were always events going on as well as fun activities they would organize for us college interns.  Also, the Disney buses can take you to fun bars and restaurants and you never have to drive!
cons: Minimum wage is less in Florida than in California. I absolutely despised the job they first placed me in because I was supposed to work in costuming. Instead, they placed me in the building where all the cast members bring their sweaty clothing for us to take care of.  I would then spend at least 5-6 hours straight putting clean cast member  costumes away allllllll dayyyyyy loooooong.  I wouldnt have been so upset if I was a high school graduate who needed any job.......but I was getting my college degree then and knew I needed to be challenged ten times more than just putting clothing away in their rightful place.  Also, they are very very strict on dress code......even though no one could see us because we worked behind the scenes of the Magic Kingdom.  If i recall correctly, you may only get three or four reprimands....and then you are terminated.  I had received two reprimands. One was because my makeup didnt look "natural" enough because I was wearing red lipstck. The second time was because my eyebrows did not match my blonde hair.  i was forced to dye my eyebrows blonde which made me look even less "natural".  When I grew my eyebrows out to their natural brown color, I decided to cut bangs so they could be covered....thus having no more reprimands.  I am now almost done with my masters at CSUN, and applied for a professional internship with Disney.  They really liked me on the phone, and I had made it to the last cut for a management internship.  The reason why they called me back to tell me I wasn't considered anymore was because they looked back at Disney records and realized I had those two reprimands.  If i knew these reprimands were a big deal for a future with Disney, I would have never worn red lipstick or had naturally brown eyebrows.  Although Disney is a great company to work for, I had an unusual experience.

review_title: Great company with its own downside

review_title: "The place where dreams come true, for customers, not employees."

job_title: Guest Service Associate in Anaheim, CA
pros:
Perks are great (park entry tickets, discounts, and free self-entry with guests)
It is a fun atmosphere. Obviously not like working in a grocery or bank for instance. People come to have a good time so it is fun to interact with guests and to make their stay more memorable. Cast members really make a difference in the small things they do with guests and that is very gratifying.
cons:
Management plays favorites a lot. Even though most managers leave locations and switch to another land/location every so years, it is still very click-ish. There are some great managers here too, but I seem to get stuck with the ones that happen to play favorites/be click-ish. I still get good evaluation scores, so no issue there. But its an uncomfortable feeling to be around.
Also, pay is low. Could be better.  I have had other equivalent jobs and this one is the record lowest paid for me.
If you are not fully available for overtime at anytime when management approaches you, it can reflect on you poorly. Nothing bad will happen, it will just reflect on you poorly. I can do overtime, but there have been days when they asked and I couldn't in that moment, and it was not looked highly on. This can be a pro too if you need the extra hours very badly and can drop things on a moments notice (or of course have 0 other obligations).

review_title: It is one of the biggest company that mostly helping residents like me. Give anybody an opportunity to serve the communi
pros: I want to try something new. Also I would love to help this company. Because they take good of guests and employee.
cons: Speed service, Guest attitude and start something different

pros: I worked at Disney a few summers ago and can honestly say that it was a fantastic internship.  Some of the pros include: excellent pay, great learning experience, and future connections

review_title: Great place to work but for the politics!

pros:

job_title: Human Resources in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: No pros I can think of.
cons:
Worst company you could ever imagine working for. I worked in a professional field and from day one was not provided mentoring or guidance one would expect from a company as big as Disney. 

I have worked for another Fortune 250 company prior to Disney and it was far superior. One major con is the fact the leaders criticize yet don't help you improve. The term "feedback is a gift" is regularly thrown around to sugar coat the constant berating by colleagues and leaders. If you are offered a job here, think long and hard before accepting. I can honestly say it was the worst professional experience of my life.

review_title: Good company and people to work with. Stay below the VP level for security otherwise watch your back.

review_title: Disney is a tough place that does not take many chances, but if you fall in the right group, you can succeed.

review_title: Disney is an outstanding place to work
job_title: Vice President, Business Development in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Disney is a large company, and bureaucracy and politics come with the territory. Sometimes you have a tough time navigating through it to get things done.

No control over your schedule at all. Every week your schedule will completely change and even those people who have been working with Disney for 4 to 5 years still have very little seniority.

pros: Huge company with the perks you’d imagine such as park tickets etc, in house cinema too!
cons:
The biggest problem is that senior management do not listen. They delegate work constantly but do not seem to care about lack of available resource. They expect you to work long hours through the month.

Also, the company use the brand to attract potential employees and therefore seem to pay less than the market rates.

I would not recommend working here.

job_title: Disney College Program Intern in Orlando, FL
pros: Fun atmosphere, and guests needs are first priority. Extended continue learning oppurtunities, seminars, self-improvement talks and etc. Good networking opportunities available. Many job oppurtunities in all kinds of fields in one company.
cons: High volume, and non-traditional work hours. Disney opens 365 days, that 's mean we all have to work on thanksgiving, Christmas and etc.

pros: Outstanding help throughout the company. They try to place you at a job after your internship.  It was great being given work to accomplish, but also knowing that if I needed help of had questions there was always someone to help me.
cons: There is a lot of competition since everyone wants to work for the company. That means really needing to network and leave a lasting impression

pros: Fun, Friendly place to work.  They truly impower you to give the best guest service all the time.
cons: If your not a Disney fan you won't like it here.  You live and breathe Disney here, so you better like the mouse.

review_title: Great perks, but Mickey Mouse is a cheapskate.
pros: Best perks of any company, anywhere: free tickets to the theme parks!  Disney is a huge company, so advancement opportunities are plentiful.
cons: Mickey Mouse is cheap.  Starting pay is lower than average for the same jobs elsewhere.  Plenty of overtime is offered, which means they don't staff at adequate levels.

review_title: Great place to start a corporate finance career
pros: Lots of movement with 1-2 years in a given role being typical before a move is made. Friendly atmosphere, matrix structure. Promotions usually occur from within making it easier to rise up in rank. Finance is home to many younger analysts both male and female. Coworkers provide an intellectual and driven environment to work in.
cons: Compensation packages may be slightly below industry average but demand for jobs is high.

review_title: A unique experience working for a great brand
job_title: Ad Sales and Promotions Manager in Moscow, Moskva
pros:
Lots of great and diverse experience, many great high quality products 
Overall nice young team 
Good social package
International trips, including Head office in Los Angeles
Very nice office and great location in Moscow
Additional work expenses paid by the company - Amex credit card, free taxi, paid phone
cons:
no career growth inside the company for almost all the staff
no serious education for further growth
enormous amount and scape of work
not really a very good allocation of responsibilities between the staff and not well arranged communication inside the team

pros: Sr Management works hard to create a fun workplace.  The on-site cafe and IT support is some of the best Disney offers.
cons: The cold, windowless, dark  building suffered thefts while I was there and felt unsafe.  Management allowed some high level employees to engage in behavior that was unsanitary and unprofessional and wouldn't be acceptable at other Disney departments.  Some employees are more "entitled" than others.  Some  get free Disneyland passes and some don't, so make sure you ask about that.

review_title: Fun on outside, terrible on inside
pros: Disney is a great, well-known brand, so it's fun to be part of a company that everyone knows and loves.  Working on Broadway has its perks, including regular interaction with celebrities, free shows, free Disney movie screenings, and working in Times Square.
cons: Cut-throat environment.  Colleagues are not afraid to throw each other under the bus to save their jobs.  Every 2 years, my colleagues and I identified a "mass exodus" when people would get so fed up of the environment or understand there was no career advancement and leave.

job_title: Hotel Engineering Technician in Anaheim, CA
pros: To start off, the job was excellent and the people are very helpful and professional. Management works with the engineers and ideas are shared company wide!
cons: some trades have specific talent needs. Some, don't share ideas or their expertise in fear of losing seniority... nothing is further that the truth . some assistant chiefs are not as smart as they think they are.

pros: You get a lot of good benefits like free admission for yourself and others to the theme parks. The housing for interns isn't too bad either.
cons: Management does not care about interns. You will work lots of hours or no hours. There is like no in between. Transportation provided is not the greatest it sometimes does not even show up.

pros: The amazing people you get the chance to meet and those special guests that make an impact on your day or sometimes even your life
cons: Hard to advance if you haven't been with the company long even though you may have outside experience to back it up. You do and handle a lot for the little pay you receive

review_title: Working for DVC is the Best!!!
pros: Working at DVC is so much fun! I've been with the Walt Disney Company over 20 years. It's a Family Organization and I strongly believe in their Product. The WDW Co. Offers the best Benefits around. I enjoy the fun and friendly Guest and Cast Members.
cons: You need to be Flexible- working Weekends and around the clock. This is an Entainment business and so the Show Must Go On!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I worked at Disney for over 10 years and in several different divisions of the company. Once you get in, it's much easier to move across departments and try out new roles.
cons: Some departments and I worked in were great. The ones that weren't were really bad. Stay away from the Interactive group unless you're ok with losing your job at any given point in time.

review_title: Only the happiest place to work at if you’re happy too
job_title: Attractions Cast Member in Anaheim, CA
pros: Great employee events, discounts, and exclusive merchandise. Very easy to learn the attractions and hours are plentiful during holiday seasons.
cons: During peak seasons, traffic to the cast lot/to travel to backstage gets very backed up. Must plan your travels to work strategically. Policies are very strict and will be recorded on your record that can affect your hours. Favoritism is heavily played between leadership and team members. Hours will be cut drastically once peak season is over. Hours/schedule preference are based on seniority.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Burbank, CA
pros: Fantastic place in the studio. Relaxed, good benefits including silver pass ("unlimited" access to Disneyland with guests), good brand name.
cons: Nothing much against Disney itself. It's a great place. I however had the misfortune of working with a manager and only co-worker who were bullies and good friends. Didn't help that the requirements were vague whereas deadlines weren't.

pros: Disney has an excellent benefits package and contrary to pouplar belief, compensates their management level employees very well from my experience. The prestige that comes from working at Disney is also a nice benefit.
cons: Disney, like all fortune 500 companies isa very political place to work. The expectations are very high and there is very little room for mistakes.

review_title: Favoritism is a problem within various departments. There is a glass ceiling.
pros:
Company brand and theme park magic is held with the highest regard.
It's something to be very proud of the quality that Disney continues to offer.
cons:
Although about to change, the Studio organizations are a mess. 
Home Entertainment has a very broken process and is lead my some questionable practices within the creative. Pictures Marketing is completely out of touch with industry best practices.

review_title: Amazing , fun and gained an insight into how things work in a legacy company.
pros: The company is very well established. People are very friendly and personable. Senior management organize events and conferences at least 1-2 times a year to communicate important developments within the company and answer questions
cons: Promotions take a long time, years sometimes. Full time opportunities are less as compared to part-time / temporary project based positions.

pros:
Good benefits (Silver Pass gives you unlimited access to Disney Parks most of the year, great 401K, health insurance)
Part of a great tradition and a great brand
Great IP's to work with
cons: There has been a great deal of turnover at the top ranks of the studio the past few years.  That has resulted in shifting mandates where one head appreciates one approach and then that work is invalidated by a new mandate.  However, all appearances show that the management has finally reached a stasis.

job_title: Resort Operations Assistant in Orlando, FL
pros: Free park admission, working for one of the best companies in the world.  Making a difference in peoples lives, Making people happy all day every day.
cons: Lower pay on average compared to other companies

pros: The value of the brand, the connection to storytelling, the creative opportunities, the global reach, the scale of the efforts, the impact on the audience.
cons: The politics. The emphasis on perceptions,  over value. The fear of functioning like a digital company in a digital age. Management does not put their money where their mouth is when it comes to growing talent.

pros: Overall it is a great company. It was impressed with friendly employees and a laid-back work atmosphere. It was a great experience to work there.
cons: It is hard to say there is something needs to be improved... I did enjoy working in such a great company and working with awesome people.

review_title: Once in a lifetime experiences that most will never get the chance to experience.
pros: Working for Disney is a great place to preform for people that came to forget their life outside the gates. You get the chance to make memories for people from across the world! You get to experience cultures from all around and work with such a well renowned company.
cons: I work my butt off doing 40+ hour weeks and still make a little more than the minimum. Hard to move forward in life while trying to pay rent.

pros: The environment and most employees are supportive of each other.  It's wonderful being a part of the happiest place on earth and being a special part of someone's vacation.
cons: If you weren't full time, sometimes you didn't know when things had changed with areas until you get reprimanded for doing something wrong.  Communication is necessary even to those who don't work full time.

review_title: It's a great place to start your career in research, but definitely consider moving on.
pros: In research, the varied duties day-to-day.  There is a lot of opportunity to support different departments within the company and you learn a lot in a short amount of time.
cons: Oh there are some downsides!  The pay is mediocre and frequently, the hard work you put in gets little recognition from Senior Management.

review_title: Great Place to start, but requires hard work and a little luck to move up.
pros: A great company with global brand recognition and respect. Challenging work that keeps you engaged in the business. Co-workers are also great with a lot of high level talent within the company.
cons: Very strict company culture within a matrix organization which sometimes blurs the lines on who reports to who and who make what decisions.

review_title: Not the Happiest Place on Earth
pros: work/life balance (at least in my role), only special thing about benefits is the free access to the parks (less blackout days)
cons: no career advancement, politics, would probably want to work in Florida to get more exposure.  surprised that a big company like this would have NO job rotation program.

pros: Perks perks perks!  Free Admission, discount stays, discount meals, special free tickets to events.  The list goes on and on and on.
cons: No work / life balance (one of their so-called core values), Favoritism, Typical office politics, Honesty is not smiled upon (another one of their so-called core values).

pros: Enjoyed generous benefits while working with fun, ethical people on projects with huge long-term potential.  Recently discovered that their layoff benefits are pretty generous too.
cons: Frequent shifts in strategy may mean your fun project with huge long-term potential can be canned at a moments notice and you may be out looking for new employment much sooner than you wanted to be.  Also, the internal technology policies and procedures are 5 or 6 years behind industry best practices.

review_title: Talent Coordinator Disney Entertainment - Disney Resorts, CA
job_title: Guest Talent Coordinator in Anaheim, CA
pros: Fun people to work with in a constantly changing environment. Guests are there to have fun and it is a fun job and place to work!
cons: Low wages, not given enough hours and no real chance for advancement. Working at the parks you better be willing to completely give up your nights and weekends.

job_title: Senior Manager, Marketing in Burbank, CA
pros: Great training ground - super smart people, great products and you are a part of an amazing legacy
cons: work/life balance is not great and there is not a lot of stability since there are frequent re-orgs. Pay is not as high as competitive places and promotions are few/far between

pros: Here are Disney there is never a dull moment. Working here you meet a lot of people from around the world. Works will with school schedule and the benefits.
cons: Off seasons are just horrible. We opened from 10 to 8. Which mean I get out late. It's all about seniority when it comes to hours and preferences. There are 40 plus of in just one day on the ride this mean there are probably over 200 that work the ride. This give you less time with management.

pros: Great benefits . Pleasant work environment. You can get friends and or family in the park for free up to twelve times a year. Felt like a family working there.
cons: Mostly there are no cons. We were a training hub for lots of new managers. Some of them had no experience in bartending so it could be a challenge when we needed help.

job_title: Front Entrance in Palm Coast, FL
pros: I met some of the best people I know today during my internship at Disney.  The work was long and sometimes a little rough due to weather, but I'm glad I did it, and would do it again.
cons: It's an internship so the pay is low and hours are long.  I was offered a full time position and many quality references at the end of the internship though.

job_title: Disney College Program in Joplin, MO
pros: Good experience. Meet a lot of people. Free admission to the parks. You can take classes through the company. Looks great if you want to continue to work for the company.
cons: Housing isn't the best. Bottom of the ladder. Terrible hours. You get all of the bad hours that the full time people don't want. Zero benefits. You will work on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years.

pros: Schedule was always out on time, open communication with your supervisors.  Great work environment.  Great benefits.  Was able to take family members into the park and receive great deals and discounts.
cons: Peak seasons meant you couldn't request any time off work, no matter what the situation is.  Could not change availability during summer season.

pros: Park perks, friends and the people you meet. I enjoyed working with young college students like myself and I made a lot of friends.
cons: The pay isn't great, the hours are horrible and some other coworkers take the job too seriously. They can extend you without asking and it's usually for hours longer than planned. The managers spy on employees which is really bad.

pros: You're able to focus on the needs of the guests and make magic for them. The focus on customer service teaches all cast members how to go above and beyond in any role.
cons: In order to focus and give everything we have to the guests, the needs of the cast members often get overlooked.

review_title: Good experience with some downs on Leadership
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Columbia, MO
pros:
Worked with great individuals at the Palo Alto office with great talent.
There were nice perks like catered food and company parties.
Just like with any Disney company, the access to the parks.
cons:
Affected by top tier decisions which are made by numbers and kill products that could have been successful, but got cancelled and instead of launching it and at least get some success, instead wasted all that development time.
Cross company decisions may affect lower tiered employees with layoffs.

pros: A fun place to work where you meet a lot of interesting people, free access to the parks and resorts.
cons: It's a lot harder to move up then they would have you believe. In order to move up it had more to do with your rank i.e.  seniority a pose to your merit and ability.

job_title: Senior Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Disney provides a respectful, pleasant work environment. Senior managers are encouraging, diplomatic and have my best interest in mind constantly.  My skills are fully leveraged and the projects I am assigned are interesting and keep me busy.  I am satisfied with my current role, but there are plenty of internal opportunities should I choose to pursue them.  The company also provides me with great work/life balance, including a flexible schedule, work from home and plenty of time off.
cons: I like everything about my job

review_title: Excellent money at the right restaurant.
job_title: Fine Dining Server in Orlando, FL
pros: Cash every shift, don’t take work home with you, easy to pick up or give away shifts, avg shift is 5-8hrs, fact-paced shifts, you definitely get your exercise, lol. I’m lucky enough to work in fine dining but if you work at a ‘turn and burn’ restaurant in the parks, you’ll make at least $200-$300 a day after tipping out. I love that I get to make magical moments for appreciative guests.
cons: Working nights and work holidays, no benefits at all for part timers

pros: With the new senior management team, there's been an increase in healthy risk-taking, moves towards creating a meritocracy, and other changes that have created more optimism within the org.
cons: Very complex to find ownership and execute, as many things are driven by cross-functinal committees. With multiple business goals at stake, finding agreement can be difficult and there's risk of watering down a project's vision.

review_title: Cool products but terrible work culture
job_title: Senior Software Test Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: You get to work for a well respected brand name. Free park tickets plus other Disney discounts. Good work/life balance.
cons: Lack of ownership of products. Info and designs are received top down not allowing for further discussions. Heavily contingent staff. Most folks just care about logging 8 hours of work instead of going above and beyond to make products better. Full time employees focus more on moving up the corporate ladder.

review_title: Friendly people, but not great professionally
pros:
Great benefits (getting into the parks and employee discount are awesome)
Friendly coworkers
Great chance to work with very valuable intellectual property
cons: Disney is a product focused company, meaning that the fellow software engineers are far from the top in their field. You'll come across quite a bit of incompetence and it can be very frustrating. There's also not a clear path for how to advance your career here.

pros: You are able to create magic and truly change peoples lives and leave a footprint on their hearts. You learn incredible guest service if you apply yourself, and are able to connect with people from all around the world. It truly is a dream.
cons: It is extremely hard to move up, a lot of negative experiences with politics with the company, and hard work isn't what will get you to the top.

review_title: Alan Bergman is leading Walt Disney Studios to a better place in The Entertainment Industry.
pros: Entertainment Company.  They have a great history and company stability.  The Walt Disney Company is a good place to work as a family.  They have a strong commitment to quality and provide a fun place to work most of the time.  Disney gives back to the community in many ways by supporting schools, non-profit organizations, and opportunities to volunteer.
cons: Very large and hard to navigate around company.

review_title: Poor management caused additional costs in time and resources
pros:
The environment is generally friendly and the people / colleagues are good to work with.
Flexible hours.
Nearby lot is fun to visit.
cons:
Terrible managers, created additional cost from poor decisions, failed to value direct reports. 
Poor processes created additional work.
No innovation.

review_title: Great branding, cool perks (park admission), little loyalty to workforce
job_title: Mid-level Technical Manager in Burbank, CA
pros: One of the most trusted brands, free park admission, commitment to excellence in creative/business areas.  Tradition of providing a total experience in family entertainment.
cons: Mediocre pay, diminishing benefits, expectation of long hours, eroding loyalty to short-term or long-term workers (layoffs cavalierly and capriciously handled).

pros: Disney's brand and products are so relatable to all people.  The culture is extremely collaborative.  Management is supportive of initiatives.  Plenty of opportunity for exposure into multiple areas.  Most departments are well-established so process and system infrastructure have been in place.  Management is open to considering changes sa the industry evolves.
cons: Poor work-life balance.  Team members are challenged to learn the ropes on the job.   Annual review process tends to occur after merit increase discussions are already in progress.

pros: Silver Pass, Insurance for both dental/eye exams and medical adequate.  Laid back work attire.
cons: Pay is horrible and raises are embarrassing.  PPR is a joke of a tool for employee performance.  Supervisors/Managers are frequently abusive and un-caring.  Overall, a gossip mill where people who don't deserve promotions get them and the ones that really work hard are ignored or worse even berated.  Very abusive management in the area i work.

review_title: Fun place to work, unfair promotion policies, management lacks skills/knowledge
job_title: Concierge in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Fun environment, lots of perks such as party admission and discounts, opportunity to cross train in other areas, meet other cast members from around the world
cons: Pay is low. Mandatory overtime including 6 day work weeks. Hard to advance - management shows favoritism and allows those with little to no experience to advance

pros: Love the atmosphere. Very friendly, and makes you feel like you're in a totally different world. Employee benefits are great
cons: Pay. Some of the casting directors make it difficult to move up/transfer to other departments.

pros: Working on the enormous hit title, Infinity. AAA home run game with more to come. Great people. There's creative input you won't find at other studios. Work hard, get your stuff done, you'll be okay.
cons: Don't fool yourself, it's the game industry. If this is the career path you've chosen be aware things can change quickly, always be prepared.

job_title: Promotions Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Pros are everyone is very was very friendly, you get to meet a lot of people on the job. Kids from all over the world look up to you and want to dance and sing like you. You give out free stuff and see smiles on a family faces. It was a super flexible job, you can call off at any time.
cons: During the summer you work under the sun for hours. Not enough hours were given to employee's. Some people worked twice a month.

pros: Benefits at TWDC are top-notch, and the perks are unmatched if you have a family. Being able to put employment with this company on your resume opens a ton of doors when it comes time to seeking a new opportunity.
cons: The company is very siloed, so it's a hard place to solidly expand your skills. Additionally, the company doesn't promote from within as much as you would initially think.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It would be difficult to come up with 20 pros words  for DIsney Interactive.I guess I found some good  colleagues to work with.  They have nice offices.  If you consider free PARK passes as a benefit, they would offer that.
cons:
No organizational direction, lots of politics. Lots of back channel communication.
Technical upper management has no clue what would work and what would not.

pros: Great Company to work for.  It was a dream come true.  They took us to Disneyland constantly.
cons: Cheap.  For a company like Disney, I was surprised at the lack of events/food.  If they did have something you usually had to pay for it.  A lot of the employees are reluctant to teach you since they fear losing their jobs to someone new.  Management can be terrible depending on the department.

job_title: Guest Information and Ticket Sales in Anaheim, CA
pros:
- It's Disneyland! The perks are amazing
- Lots of Cast Events and exclusive memory-making experiences
- HR is very good about hiring "Disney" people - everyone has a great attitude and morale.
cons:
- Scheduling can be a hassle if you don't adequately prepare
-

pros: Great place to start your career, fun perks for family and friends such as park tickets and movie marketing events and viewing prior hitting theaters.
cons: Everybody loves Mickey so management and above positions rarely become available for someone trying to climb up the ladder but anytime you spend with Mickey looks great on your resume. Also, telecommuting is not available to all employee levels across the company.

pros: Best brand, "Disney" perks and lots of great people.
cons: Politics, limited mobilty, constant organization changes and lack of transparency from senior management.   Imagine inviting an entire team to coffee to discuss future opportunities with the company just to have HR tell that same team a week later that their roles were being eliminated.  Unfortunately that's typical at corporate Disney.

pros: working with this company gives you a chance to meet new people and learn many new style of work within the same location.
cons: the wages are pretty low for the amount of work they demand of you on any given day. Would be nice to start the position at better wage

pros: Perks from Disney (* not from Disney ABC TV itself)
cons:
Politics
Secretive closed door meetings
Un-transparency 
Finger pointing and non-sense blaming of others

pros:
Easy to pick up more hours/give away shifts
Paid weekly
Lots of different roles so lots of opportunities to work in different places
Free park admission
cons:
Large amount of employees so hard to find a manager with time
Dealing with angry guests in the heat
Held to a higher standard so everything feels very tense and "fight or flight"

pros: The best part of working for Disney is watching the faces of kids, young adults and the young at heart light up when they first see the castle or their favorite character!  That pure joy and love is priceless!
cons: The pay has to be the most difficult part of working for the company!  Although personally I work a ton of hours to make sure I can make my bills, I'm not here for the pay, it is the love of the job that keeps me here

job_title: Financial Analyst in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Brand name recognition, free park entry
cons:
Terrible terrible terrible "management". Amateur at best. Favoritism and a serious lack of diversity. 

The problem with the Business Planning and Analysis department is that there is no real work to do, so they fill the time with petty projects and petty feedback. The amount of time wasted is appalling. They will also make you sit there till sometimes 9pm even if there is no real work to do. The two female managers are at each others throats and are both horrible at managing people. Please do yourself a favor and stay away.

pros: Work with fun and exciting people. Great camaraderie in and outside work. Make connections with guests. Perfect for anyone focused on customer service.
cons: Late hours and open on holidays. The company will take away from family and personal time with extended hours and last minute schedule changes.

pros: Benefits are good, paternity/maternity leave, park passes, and you work with good people.
cons: Pay is not on scale for the work you do and Leaders are not at 'Disney' as front line cast members.  Not many opportunities to move up in the sales environment.  My Job was a facilitator and I got paid hourly where as any other Full Time Facilitation Position in the company is Salary.

pros: Fun company to work for, lots of perks like movie screenings and staff discounts.  The people I worked with were fantastic, we worked hard but also took time out to laugh and have fun which is so important for staff morale.  Career opportunities are there if you want them.
cons: Lots of overtime at a low level in the organisation in order to meet deadlines.

review_title: Not the happiest place on earth
pros: Free entry to the parks and discounts
cons: There's so many cons about working here that I can't list them all. Very low pay, they don't care about you or you're scheduling needs, horrible hours, many mean people and leads, dirty break areas for cast members. You're basically a slave worker to Disney. It seems all magical until you start working here you see the ugly side of Disney. All they care about is money and they cut hours and wages and people. You can tell others cast members aren't happy working here.

pros: Hey, it's Disney! Lots of corporate perks, park admissions, great benefits.  Yes it is fun to tell people that you work for Disney.  Liked that they are an environmentally conscious company, and promote it across the company.
cons: It is a very large company, with diverse divisions, and there seemed to be a tendency to try to treat each different entity of the company with the same policies.

pros: Amazing employee benefits /perks, resources and family atmosphere
cons: Inexperienced management in directing ideas, many people feel as though they do work that doesn't get used because projects were switched so often. Not a big deal, as you always get paid for what you do... it's a job but it's not inspiring to contribute and then feel like you wasted time and energy for nothing. Again, not a deal breaker and over the years things started to sort themselves out as leadership gained experience in the industry.

pros: Disney is a very good company to work for. They have good benefits, nice offices and lots of opportunities to learn about othe divisions of the company
cons: Video games play second (third(fourth!?)) fiddle to the other media types Disney has it's handed in. Disney's not interested in making innovative games, rather they focus on creating already created games with a Disney coat of paint. That's not for everyone (including me) but given the volatility of games a business it's not a bad choice either.

pros: Great Vacation and Educational Location
cons: This is a Customer focused organization to the detriment of the Cast Members [employees]. By slighting Cast Members and in some cases abusing  them with a low compensation rate and extreme working schedules, the guest experience IS compromised. The reverse of the intention actually becomes apparent.

pros: Great brand to work for and excellent diversity within the teams.  Disney does a good job of creating a sense of community and collaboration.
cons: For most departments, Disney is on the lower side of the pay scale.  Because of their world class brand, many people want to work for Disney giving them leverage with salary.

pros: Disney is a company with a great brand.  The size of the organization provides opportunities to grow and devlop.  Leadership makes an efort to communicate with employees on key issues.
cons: Companies going through change may experience a work/life imbalance.  Disney Studio's recent reorganization has created a temporary imbalance that hopefully will correct itself soon.

review_title: Not the Happiest Place on Earth
pros: It's a stable job, but at a big emotionally destructive cost.
cons: Incredible political, fear-driven and micromanaged work atmosphere. Nepotism rules. Very hard to move up unless you're good friends with/in with senior management. VERY LOW PAY. Only directors and above bonus. over worked and under paid, with little to no growth opportunity. Management never held accountable for their actions and bully employees.

job_title: College Program Intern in Orlando, FL
pros: Great experience to have under your belt. I've gotten so many questions in previous interviews about my time at Disney. Great pay. What more could you ask for 6 months in Florida working at Disney World, getting paid and free entrance to the parks.
cons: Depending on where you are placed. The regular employees seem stuck up when it comes to the CP's coming in and doing there job. They will work you to the bone if you let them.

review_title: Working for the Walt Disney Company has been an amazing, eye-opening, creative endeavor of development and opportunities
job_title: Communications in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Everyone you meet is happy and loves their job, because this is truly one of the most fun and exciting places to work in the world.
cons: Communication teams are small and headcount is not often created, making it more difficult to find a permanent position.

pros: Great group of employees to work with. Very family oriented. Wide range of project types. Free admission to parks a good perk if a fan of Disney
cons: Work loads do not match the pay. Non-competitive salary to outside world. Very, very political. benefits are not as good as the rest of the industry

pros: Everyone is super friendly and it's almost like you become a family after working there so long.  You can go to Disneyland whenever you want for free.
cons: The pay isn't that great and you never really receiving any promotions.  You get stuck in one position and feel as if you're doing slave work.  The managers are never around to assist you.

job_title: Quality Assurance Tester in Glendale, CA
pros: Great modern facility with lots of parties and food. Pizza day, pie day, cake day, and M&M machine. Arcade and game table on every floor. Lots of overtime available
cons: Infested with spiders due to imported plants, many co workers unfriendly and impersonal, very low hourly pay. Disposable position with whole studios getting cut

pros: Good career path if you stick around.  Do need to work hard.  Just like other places there is no guarantee that hard work will 100% pay off but that's a must
cons: People of significant positions tend to hang on for a long time and promotion (especially after certain level) is hard to come by

pros:
Weekly pay, depending on department there is OT available. 20% from 1st day of employment.

cons: At time has a high school mentality, instead of a professional environment. There are a lot of a workers who are over looked for what they do.

pros: Huge company with a strong culture. If you have the right personality, and if you don`t mind a lot of strict rules, you can excel at this company.
cons: Union. You get lost in the middle of dozens of thousands. You feel like you are just one more and get lost in the middle of a huge crowd. Internal growth is very difficult. Entry level pay is poverty level.

pros: Name recognition, lots of benefit options.  Other areas within the company to move.
cons: Virtually no growth potential in most divisions.  You will get hired as a coordinator and stay a coordinator for 20 years.  Attitude at the studio is "you're lucky to have a job" and if you don't like it they'll just hire your replacement.

pros:
Working with world-class filmmakers and producers. High level of creativity. 
One of the first company other companies want to partner with. You see a lot of first in different industries. Intellectually challenging.
cons:
Extremely political environment. Be ready to get stepped on your feet. It's a mix of House of Cards and Shark Tank - a lot of excitement but cut-throat atmosphere.

review_title: Not as Magical as they want you to think
pros: The people are fun, you get to spend your time with people enjoying themselves, neat environment
cons: No time to do anything but work really and at the end of it you don't get paid much. Unless you really love Disney I wouldn't recommend it

pros: If you love Disney then this job is perfect for you, however, your role will make or break your program. Pick something you love and if you can't handle criticism then this program is not for you. Your co-workers are your family and you have to love being close to others.
cons: The rent is very expensive, Disney technically isn't supposed to be charging rent since the housing was donated by Coca-Cola.

review_title: Disney-ABC Domestic TV needs new blood.
pros: They hire for entry-level positions from outside of company, and there is opportunity to learn. They are many software and management classes open to everyone at every level.
cons: Employees are promoted slowly mainly b/c of senior management not retiring when they should be. Disney-ABC lags behind its competitors in the new media space mainly b/c senior management doesn't push to do things with new technology.

review_title: The former Disney Internet Group/Disney Interactive Media Group is a good place to work.
pros: Great location in downtown Seattle; Workplace environment is a mix between corporate and startup feel; Things seem to be on the upswing.
cons: Lack of options for promotion in many areas; Hires external candidates instead of looking within; Lack of cross training and communication between the different departments.

pros: Good people, smart, knowledgeable, hard working, well intentioned, polite.  Great brand, exciting space (technology and new media), lots of optimism for future.
cons: Could take more risks, could definitely be more organized, execution needs work, integration of different groups (bureaucracies) and product leaders.

review_title: Working for Disney has been a rewarding and life changing experience.
pros: The people are great, proud of the products and what the company represents,  love the perks ( park passes,  discounts,  etc.) and benefits.
cons: Some divisions have limited growth opportunities,  less of a work/life balance, and long hours. Industry changes and restructuring in the last few years has led to several rounds of layoffs throughout the company and job uncertainty.

review_title: Overall really great experience! Learned a lot and networked with some key individuals in the industry.
pros: Benefits, ability to move laterally, incredibly friendly working environment where creativity is always encouraged.
cons: Pay is not competitive, long hours, full time work is not guaranteed even after 5 years of working full time hours at part time status.

review_title: Awesome experience, as fan of Disney, this was a dream come true.
pros: They have lots of benefits, discounts, gifts. I felt very happy and comfortable.
cons: The only cons is that me and every team worldwide were laid off. The same day they told us "today is your last day at the company" so it was a completely surprise for everyone. But "things" happen, I am very grateful for the experience I had.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Hollywood, CA
pros: Very creative, talented team. Incredibly strong brand recognition and many strong brand assets to work with from beloved animated characters, TV shows, and studio films. If at the Director level or above, comp plans are much more attractive due to additional executive benefits/perks etc.
cons: Challenging internal systems and bureaucracy. Very difficult and long turn around times to get new ideas approved. When the new executive team came in, many were hopeful they would have the expertise to turn things around, but they are really struggling.

pros: Company has nice perks and tries to create a fun culture for its employees.  Benefits package is good and great to have free passes to Disney parks, especially when you have a family.
cons: Such a large company that you need to be very proactive about networking in order to grow.  Upward mobility is slow. People tend to be very silo-ed by office locations.  If you are located on a campus experience will be much better than satellite offices.

pros: Used to be great. Free Disneyland tickets, screeinings, sales. Dental and medical plans. Some of these are now gone as company's saving money.
cons: Lack of progression.  Complaints to HR can lead to sanctions instead of solving issues. Constant change of systems. Multiple redundancies and cuts to perks/benefits to save money for acquisitions.

pros: Working for Disney was overall an acceptable experience.  A large corporation has the financial backing for job security.  A good work life balance.
cons: Such a large corporation it is easy to get lost in the shuffle.  Sometimes it feels like upper, upper management is really not looking out for anyone else but themselves.

review_title: Interesting place to write software --- solving problems of massive scale for ABC,ESPN,Disney Online.
pros: Interesting scaling problems to work on.   Well recognized brand name.   Financially stable company.   Great location.
cons: A bit chaotic.  A bit buerocratic.   Frequent changes in strategic direction.   Half baked product architecture makes support issues difficult.

pros: The people you work with. This isn't "just" a job, everyone here wants to be here. Great benefits and perks. Salaries are decent. The facilities (depending on your location) are top notch.
cons: Annual layoffs. Like clockwork, at the end of January there will be layoffs. If you survive it, don't breathe easy - there will be another round of layoffs in March or April.

pros: Working for a well known brand is a good resume builder

review_title: If you're wanting to be surrounded by Disney magic and get discounts through the Walt Disney Company
pros: You get free theme park tickets 50% off hotels and get to be surrounded by the Disney magic all the time.
cons: Not many hours working no benefits for part-time cast members no paid vacations for part-time cast members it hard opportunity to grow within the company

pros: The first reason is because I love Disney characters and this would be a dram come true to work for Disney company, also like the way the employer treat the customer with a lot of respect and they always know the answer for the questions, this shows how well trained  and intelligent they are, I being to Disneyland Paris ones and I was completely fall in love with everything.

pros:
You get to "work" on some of the best film IP there is. Marvel, Lucas, Disney Animaion - all top notch. 

The commissary on the lot is ok - but, it's cheap. There is a Starbucks on the lot as well. 

Disney offers ok benefits. I have had WAY better medical options at smaller companies before. 401(k) w/ company matching. Lower level employees don't get stock or wellness perks.

You get the occasional screening and swag - but, anyone over 30 shouldn't be excited over a Mickey plush toy. So like, there's that.
cons:
Where to start? Room for growth is literally non-existant. They foster a culture of "move out to move up". Meaning.. if you want a promotion.. you'll have to leave the company to "gain experience" and then come back in a different capacity. 

As for the free park pass - they block out virtually every weekend due to revenue guests complaining about park crowds. So, if you want to actually enjoy the park - you'd have to call in sick on a random Tuesday. Yet, your Silver Pass is included in your "total rewards package" so, technically, you still pay for it. 

Complacency is also a huge issue. It should really be studied. People are willing to go years without a promotion, being reconginsed, no raises (just 3% for cost of living) all to say they work for Disney. TBH, I don't get it. HR knows they have the power of the brand on their side and that they have someone else waiting in the wings. They constantly hire from outside the company as opposed to looking within. 

Compensation is rigged. Much like the US economy - everything goes to the top. Executives get 6 figure bonuses at the end of the year, while lower level employees are often told by their leaders they had to "fight" to get them a 3% increase. We got told to cut back on ordering office supplies a few days after we received an email notifiying us that another film crossed the 1B box office line. Comical, much?

They rolled out a "flex" working policy. But, you literally get shamed like Cersei Lannister if you even think about using it.
